148576551.review:
I really want to recommend this game, but despite the phenomenal writing, intricate map design, and a host of other great qualities, it just won't be fun for a majority of people, I reckon. That said, the steam reviews for this game are 70%+ positive as of writing, so maybe I'm completely wrong here. Here are a few more positives to help you make that decision for yourself:
- The animations are spectacular. My understanding is this game was mostly created by a solo dev, an accomplished 3D animator, so that makes sense, but also the amount of work put into this game in most respects is seriously impressive.
- The characters are diverse and complex, especially for such a short experience. They're easily my favorite part of this game, along with...
- The world-building. There's an enormous sense of history and context outside of the small story told here. I'm usually bored by lore dumps, but I read every single highlighted text entry in this game (sometimes multiple times which gave me additional insight) and enjoyed all of them. I wish the developer and story writer had been given a larger team to work with to really build out the world and the mechanics, they're both frighteningly talented
- The music is gorgeous and adds greatly to the emotional impact of exploring each area

So, unfortunately that leaves the rest of the game as a bit of a mess. Your character, a mouse, coexists in a world with numerous other species who are nearly all significantly larger and more powerful than you. You're therefore encouraged (forced?) to rely on stealth and cunning to survive. If this story and world were paired with a thief style stealth system, it could be perfect. As is though, most of the stealth mechanics quickly become a chore to engage with. Enemies are on simple fixed patrols and the limited methods of incapacitating them are severely time limited. Certain disguises later on give you the ability to ignore stealth entirely, and at that point the only remaining gameplay mechanics are managing resources like fuel for your lantern (not difficult or strictly necessary) and some abysmally finicky 3rd person platforming. All of your deaths in this game will likely be from failed jumps or accidentally slipping off a piece of awkward geometry. Without those, it's practically a walking simulator with a sprint button.

Every single quest in this game is a fetch quest. Contextually, from a story perspective, practically all of these quests are meaningful, which is great in theory. Mechanically, however, they're a chore, and seriously bog the game down very early. There are no objective markers, no fast travel, and you only unlock a limited 'thief-o-vision' partway through, so without a guide you're basically scrambling all over the map trying to interact with everything multiple times like the most tedious point and click adventure game you could imagine. What's worse, it's very easy to miss out on optional quests and dialog if you're not constantly going back through old areas and repeatedly checking in with numerous NPCs, some of which add crucial details to the overall story. I bounced off this game multiple times and eventually completed it using a 100% guide which ended up being a far more enjoyable experience, though not without frustration at the platforming sections. So much of what this game could be from a gameplay standpoint is clearly limited by the resources of a one-dev team, but that doesn't change how unpleasant it feels to play without an omniscient knowledge of where and when all of the key items appear.

A note about the story (spoilers ahead):
[spoiler] As well written as the story is, it also just ends almost without warning. It feels like watching the first and only season of a cancelled TV show. You find the path to your missing wife, assemble your resources, and then get into a boat to find her and... the credits roll. It's not the kind of ambiguous ending which leaves you satisfied, but with more questions. It just feels like there wasn't enough time or money to finish the game. I would love to see a sequel done by a larger team but with the same quality of writing and characterization. [/spoiler]

So, that all sucks, especially when it's hard to do justice to how good the writing is in this game. All of the dialog is delivered through text boxes with the game paused in the background, and yet certain moments made me laugh out loud while others had me almost in tears. You'd just have to wade through 10-15 hours of multiplying fetch quests and trivial stealth to experience them.

Its unfortunate for this game that I have to choose between thumbs up and down. The game definitely isn't horrible and there were definitely some redeeming qualities. However, the core game-play loop just isn't fun. The game basically is just a series of fetch quests with the occasional, relatively easy puzzle sprinkled in. Do I regret playing the game, no. But I can't "recommend" the game when there are plenty of others that cost the same or less, are more fun to play, and hit the same notes that this game is going for. 

The stealth elements are relatively easy and are pretty much optional apart from the very early game. Getting caught is hardly a nuisance because you can easily just sprint past the gaurds. Additionally you get a suit of armor disguise relatively early in the game that negates the need for sneaking entirely. So ultimately this game pretty much turns into a walking simulator. This isn't improved upon by the fact that it can take a while to get from A to B because the map is both large and tricky to navigate at first.  The game attempts to get around this by littering the map with shortcuts that reward you for learning the layout of the map. However, dispute this it can still take a while to traverse the map, especially with the way your sprint stamina recovers. 

I ended up doing both the main story as well as the side quests, the story is mildly entertaining, though nothing spectacular.  However, it is told almost exclusively through text dialog, which can be a turn off for some people, and I'll admit its not something I usually gravitate towards in games. Still, the story, along with the art style, are the few redeeming qualities of this game.

143113022.review:
I must say, the game looks wonderful: the protagonist is incredibly cute, the environments are impressive, the music is beautiful, and the lighting and day-night cycle engine immerse us into the world of a falsely accused minstrel mouse. I wish, however, that the gameplay matched the game's visual brilliance.

Positioned as a stealth game, it quickly undermines its own foundation right from the start, allowing players to wear enemy armor and completely forget about stealth. Even if you choose to forego the armor, you'll soon realize that running past enemies is faster than sneaking from cover to cover. Moreover, if you are spotted, the punishment is minimal - you may get hit once or twice, but once you hide from the enemy, you can continue running past their comrades with ease.

The quests in the game are quite dreadful. About half of them involve either waiting for a specific time of day or going to bed to skip time. Approximately 75% of the quests require collecting unnecessary trinkets like mushrooms, maps, clothing, flags, and other items, turning the game into a monotonous fetch-quest ordeal.

The primary mode of transportation seems to be sprinting from one short path to another to minimize the time spent on quests. In an apparent attempt to lengthen the game's duration further, the developers severely restrict stamina regeneration required for running during walking - stamina regenerates only to a "normal" extent when completely stopped. Even with the stamina regeneration upgrade (though there are ability, health, and stamina upgrades available, stamina being the most useful), players still have to come to a complete halt and wait for 10 seconds to regain enough stamina to sprint for 5 seconds.

Unfortunately, the gameplay remains stagnant even after obtaining upgrades and the infamous armor - enemies continue to patrol the same routes, and they don't recognize you when you're in disguise. Neither the opening of new passageways nor the narrative reveals about your disguise changes the guards' perception of you. You can leisurely move through empty locations where there were never any enemies and steal from patrol pockets while remaining undetected - there are no consequences for these actions.

The only real development here is in the narrative: characters' opinions about the protagonist change, they move from one place to another, and even the final location undergoes a transformation due to malevolent forces, which were hinted at early on and easily forgotten. The secondary characters are interesting, and interacting with them is enjoyable, but the quests they offer often ruin the overall experience. Adding to this frustration is the fact that players are denied the chance to conclude the story they were promised at the outset; it abruptly ends only midway through, dampening the enjoyment.

I recommend getting this game on sale if you want to experience a charming tale, but keep the following tips in mind:
- Don't attempt to complete all quests immediately; many are locked behind story progression and cannot be finished until the final act.
- As soon as you get the chance to speak with the prison commander, equip the armor and complete his quests to level it up and move faster in enemy-infested locations.
- Pay attention to button prompts for term explanations, steal handkerchiefs, open shutters, and learn the names of rats - they all reward achievements.
- If you don't mind the extra content, try to find the Rangr costume that increases stamina regeneration and complete at least one quest for the two thieving mice - they provide an opportunity to boost stamina regeneration.
- Spend money at the blacksmith to find quest items, as money won't serve any other meaningful purpose.

Good luck, scrunts!

142311460.review:
Almost a fantastic game.
 The art style is wonderful, the world building is top notch, the lore is enthralling, the writing is solid and leaves a lot of subtle hints for you to work out certain lore details yourself like what happened to King Rodrik.
The gameplay.... is okay. The enemy AI is incredibly dense, Although it's funny how the game justifies this by making how stupid the guards are part of the world building, it leaves a lot to be desired.

The movement is quite good for what it is. It took me a bit to figure out jumps don't carry your momentum from the ground but instead are affected by whether you're holding sprint while airborn or not. But once I did, I never had issues missing any jumps. The running animation is absolutely fantastic and everything except climbing feels really responsive. Climbing is a little fiddly but not really used or needed often.

 The gameplay loop of stealthing around and exploring to find the items you need to progress is not going to be to everyone's tastes but it's not awful in concept... in execution however it has some serious issues. The game is very, VERY bad at conveying where you're suppose to go, and in some cases even what you're suppose to be looking for, leading you to just constantly aimlessly wander around the map for hours until you get so frustrated you have to look up what you're suppose to do... only to realize you walked past the thing you needed 17 times and didn't notice cus it just looked like a bit of decoration or was hidden in some dark shadows. 

 This game's limitations on light are pretty frustrating. You're rarely given a means to restock on oil or candles where it matters, including locations where enemies carry around lanterns which is really odd both from a level design and world building perspective. This creates a feeling of scarcity that makes it feel like you shouldn't use it just because you don't wanna run back through half that section, or even to an entirely different section, just to restock your light sources. And this can lead you to missing quite a lot of stuff because it was crammed in a dark corner somewhere and you didn't wanna waste fuel checking it or spend too much time exploring a dark space you can barely see anything even with a light source out. You have two sources of infinite light you can obtain through side quests but one is significantly dimmer than the lantern and candle, and the other replaces your headwear meaning you can't wear it with a disguise and drains your stamina to use which....

 Stamina management is endlessly frustrating. Stamina drains quickly while sprinting and barely replenishes at all while walking. It goes up fairly quick while standing still but it takes about as long to fill up as it does to drain so you ether deal with the minimal stamina regen while walking, or spend half of the game standing still waiting for your stamina to refill. Yes if you walk "really" slowly with an analogue stick you can get it to replenish at max speed while still moving but this is it's own kind of frustrating and requires a controller. On top of this you later get a much needed ability to highlight intractable objects, and using this ability also consumes stamina. On a second playthough of the game when you know where everything is, the stamina issues are barely noticeable. In fact I think the game makers specifically balanced it around this experience because, as the game makers, they knew where everything was. But in a blind playthough, given the earlier issue of how unhelpful the game is at telling you where to go and what you're looking for, you end up spending hours running around in circles through the whole map at several points in the game, and this is when the stamina limitations are really egregious. It really feels like there should've been some secret outfit in the game that just gives you infinite stamina to make exploring the map and cleaning up unfinished tasks before ending the story much more manageable...

 Which should have been the gilded armor. This is effectively the secret best outfit in the game, obtainable just after you get locked out of a few side quests unfortunately, but they're all fairly easy ones you'll probably have done by then. It does still make completing unfinished tasks fairly trivial, but having it also eliminate the stamina issue would've been grand... Until you do a second playthrough to get the ghost, untouched, crash diet, and/or scholar achievements, where it suddenly becomes unobtainable for some reason. A bug that's been in the game since it's release as far as I can tell and been reported several times.

Despite that egregious bug, the game's actually surprisingly replayable if you really enjoy the story. There's a lot of dialogue trees that reveal different lore depending on what you say to who, and the order you do some quests in can lead to you having different knowledge at different points in the game leading to dialogue you wouldn't otherwise get. Through a second play through I learned a lot more lore, clues to certain mysteries, and the direction the currently-in-production sequel will likely take, that I hadn't gotten in my first play through due to different dialogue paths. And I found navigating the game much more enjoyable once I actually knew where I was going.

Overall, despite it's flaws, it's a pretty lovely game. I just wish the development team put a bit more long term support into ironing out some if it's issues.

This game is a unique experience. It's kind of a medieval stealth game in a tiny world (literally, you'll have to play the game to know what i mean lol), which is actually kind of immersive. There's some RPG elements but not too much to make you feel overwhelmed with stuff. 

First, let's talk about the positives. Like, I said, the game is very immersive considering it's only ~20 hours long (including beating all side quests). Characters are well designed. They sometimes react differently to different things you say, and you might not get some of the side quests if you don't offer help. Your choices don't matter all that much compared to games like Life Is Strange, but I didn't mind it. The story was well written. It's the strongest aspect of the game in my opinion. The plot advances smoothly and there are some really interesting twists. There is no real combat in the game, aside from the spiders in the catacombs. If you get spotted by an enemy, you'll have to run away which makes sense since you're a prisoner escaping. Navigating the maps was pretty annoying at first but after you get used to it [spoiler] and unlock some secret passages [/spoiler] , it becomes more fun. I really wanna see a fast travel option tho, in the sequel (if they ever make one).

Now the negatives. Escaping from the guards is fun, but they're REAAAALLY stupid lol. Rats are your enemies, and as long as you're wearing their armor, they won't care at all. Even when you're not wearing the armor, when they come after you, losing them is way too easy. Hide in the nearest cupboard while they watch you do it and they'll come and be like "what? where'd he go?". Game performance is not good at all. Frequent stutters and fps drops, and overall a bit clunky. The real issue with the game I had, tho, was this. The first time you run it, using the mouse in the main menu is a nightmare. The cursor won't click where you want. And you can't navigate using the keyboard. Why? I don't know. You can fix this by Going into Options>Video, scrolling all the way to the bottom, and turning on Vsync. Then, scroll back up and select the proper resolution for your screen. It was fine for the period i had the game open. BUT, the next time i launched the game, guess what? It crashed on launch. Verifying integrity of game files did nothing, neither did reinstalling the game. What i had to do was to go to the "cog" on the game in my library > Manage > Browse Local Files, and run the file called "GoaT_ClearPreferences.cmd". That opens up a command prompt. Press Enter and after it's done close it, then you should be able to run the game again. This resets everything (except your save data) so you'll need to turn on Vsync, fix your resolution, all over again. This will reset your key bindings too so you'll need to modify them again if you don't like the defaults. You essentially need to do this every time want to play the game. Very annoying.

Overall score: a very generous 7/10. The game is fun but the main thing that knocks it down is its performance and instability

This game looks beautiful. The writing and animations are full of character. The story is really fun. The game play mechanics are also really solid. Overall I think this is a really well put together game, but I don't think it's for everyone.

The game takes place in and around a labyrinth of a fort and you will spend a lot of time sneaking around trying to avoid guards and unlocking new areas. There are maps, but you will need to learn your way around and you will spend quite a lot of the early game feeling quite lost so, if you don't have the patience for that, this could end up being a frustrating experience. Up until you are able to blend in with the guards, it can also feel like you are just constantly alerting and trying to run away from them, which can also feel frustrating. It does calm down a lot once you are no longer forced to sneak everywhere but that doesn't happen until you are a chunk into the game.

I only really have one gripe with the game. You need to steal keys from some guards and the pickpocket ability is really fiddly. Firstly, because of lighting it's sometimes impossible to see when a guard has something of value, and secondly, even if you know they do, you need to be in just the right position related to them in order to grab it. After trying to pickpocket one rat multiple times and giving up (assuming I must have been wrong), then checking a walk through to work out where to go next, I did just end up knocking them out and standing directly on top of them before it would show me the item I needed. This happened to me on two separate occasions whilst playing. Seriously, do not be afraid to use a walk through if you feel like you are getting stuck. Aside from the pick pocketing, the game is sometimes really light on signposting and without help it does sometimes feel like you are just trying everything with everything until something happens.

I held off on this for a long time because of other reviews saying this was full of bugs but I only experienced one serious problem where I accidentally accessed a part of the fort that I hadn't unlocked yet and I got stuck there. Fortunately I wasn't just using one save slot and once I realised I was stuck, I could go back to an earlier save. 

Overall I really enjoyed this one and went out of my way to do all of the side-quests, just because I didn't want the game to end yet!

Ghost of a Tale is a charming game. What really stood out to me was the interconnectedness of the areas. Lots of hidden doors and entrances that bring you back to areas you are familiar with. Really reminded me of the level design in Dark Souls 1. I kinda feel like this game could be vaguely described as a mini Skyrim - both the good and bad.

I loved the characters in this, from Tilo - the protagonist - to Kerold the frog and Ravik the magpie. I liked that there were many side quests which made you get to know the world and characters better. Plus, these side quests can grant you some "upgrades" to your tools and clothes. 

There is no fighting system, which doesn't need to be a negative. You've got sticks and bottles to use as a distraction and throwing weapon. You can set certain things on fire, though as I remember, not in combat - which I believe - was kind of a missed opportunity. The overall controls felt both very adequate but also clunky at times. The menu, specifically, was buggy and frustrating to navigate. Scrolling through dialogue options is way too slow. Sometimes there was a menu box over another and you clicked on something in your inventory but at the same time confirmed a dialogue choice. Or there were dialogue options only to find out that you can't say anything besides "nevermind". I'm paraphrasing here. But the menu could need a proper clean up. The stamina was drained way too fast and regenerated very slowly, even after the perk that you can unlock. 

However, the world which they created, along with the lighting is absolutely gorgeous. I say it again: G-O-R-G-E-O-U-S. This game looks so beautiful. You can tell how much love went into this. For such a small studio, this had some triple-A-grade graphics and animations. There were a lot of lighting glitches, however, along with lots of popups from bonfires to rock walls.

Speaking of animations: I wish there were more cinematics. The same goes for voice acting. I wish the game would've had it. I know, games can have their own charm by relying on text boxes but I wished the dialogue was voiced. The same goes for a couple scenes that should've had animations but were instead narrated by a simple text box.

Ultimately, with all its flaws I perceived, I hope there's more to come. With improvements to various aspects from gameplay variation, to controls and overall quality of life improvements, a second game from those devs would be a delight. Whether it would be a sequel or a whole other story. I still would gladly recommend Ghost of a Tale.

[spoiler]The final fight can suck a duck, though.[/spoiler]

126683854.review:
This is truly a hidden gem, albeit a rather unpolished one. Ghost of a Tale is a narrative driven adventure game set in a quirky castle populated with talking anthropomorphic rodents sprung from a grim yet heroic fairytale, visualizing a clan of Skavens in a Redwall setting gets you pretty much spot on. In this fabulous fable you play as Tilo, a minstrel mouse of the highest order with a sneaky nature and an uncanny ability to hide in cupboards. After a rather unsuccessful performance due to his Wife Merra refusing to perform for a local Rat-baron, Tilo is knocked unconscious and thrown into the dungeons of a nearby keep. It is up to Tilo to find out what happened to his wife and save the day!

Overall I truly enjoyed this game, the atmosphere is spot on, the setting and storytelling sublime and overall the gameplay is decent enough. At its core this is a stealthy adventure game with a bunch of side quests tied on mostly circling around fetching this or that for the local retainers at the castle. Overall the gameplay and inventory management is fine even though the stealth parts might feel a bit unintuitive to followers of the Thief-style of stealth action. The fetching of items for quests is slightly obtuse at times but that's not the biggest problem. Sometimes quests that you think about completing might be softlocked until you progress far enough in the main storyline, a bit of a nitpick but quite annoying after you searched every nook and cranny the 5th time looking for the last piece of a puzzle you can't complete. 

Considering this is a project with a few dedicated souls behind it I can see past a few of the more glaring design decisions and overall I really enjoyed this cute and charming tale of a mouse desperately searching for his loved one. The story is by far the most endearing part and for that alone it gets a stamp of approval. Ghost of a Tale is just the kind of fairytale this bleak regressive society needs, hope burns bright in the smallest of things.

123945517.review:
Do you remember when you were young, with not a care in the world, watching classic animated movies like [i]The Secret of NIMH[/i] or [i]The Last Unicorn[/i]? Do you remember the sense of wonder they instilled in you? This peculiar mix of optimistic adventure and melancholy? The way in which they weaved together thrills and humour, but also mystery, sadness and some genuinely scary bits?

Well, the truth is: You and I, we will never get those days back. But [b]Ghost of a Tale might just remind you a bit of the stories we grew up with[/b], when children’s entertainment was still willing to examine all the facets and complexities of life.

With his tragic backstory and desperate quest to find his kidnapped wife Merra, our main character Tilo is a great example of this, though he’s far from the only one. As you explore the stunningly beautiful environments of Dwindling Keep, [b]you’ll come to know a number of unique characters, all with hidden depths that you may not have expected at first sight[/b]. Allegiances will be questioned and your opinions about these characters will shift – in some cases perhaps quite dramatically, as their (very believable) motivations become clear. [b]The lore of the world is likewise deep and full of mystery[/b]. You may never even find out which of the many songs sung about the past are true, which ones are embellished and which ones are straight-up propaganda.

A word of warning: Ghost of a Tale does tell a self-contained narrative of the occurrences at Dwindling Keep, but it doesn’t conclude the wider narrative. I can’t tell you more than that without going into heavy spoilers, I just wanted you to be aware of this before you try the game. But I also want you to understand that this story has resonated so deeply with me that I’ve found myself scouring the web for information about a possible sequel every single year since I first played the game in 2018. As of late 2022, [b]it looks like that sequel may be coming[/b], though it’s probably years off still. But I’m gonna be honest: Even if the sequel never materialises, I’ll still be glad to have experienced this story, incomplete or not. I’ll just occasionally be reminded of this wonderful little game, look to the sky and wonder what became of Tilo, Merra and the others…

116052521.review:
[b]My Playtime:[/b] 17.3h (100% achievement, finished the game)
[b]Grindy Achievement(s):[/b] No.
[b]Optional Achievement(s):[/b] Yes (16 achievements).
[b]Difficult Achievement(s):[/b] No.

[h1]Intro[/h1]
[b]Ghost of a Tale[/b] is a mix of stealth and collectathon where you play as a mouse in a place full of rats. It offers a lot of side quests where you have to find objects in secret areas and shortcuts to travel between maps quickly.

[b]Pros:[/b]
- A lot of sidequests to finish
- Beautiful-looking scenery and models

[b]Cons:[/b]
- Very low sound
- A lot of bugs
- Quests can be hard to finish since area names are never explained properly

[b]Specs[/b]
Intel Core i5-9300H 2.40GHz, 8GB RAM, NVIDIA GeForce GTX 1650

[h1]Should you buy this game?[/h1]
[b]No.[/b]
[i]Unless you like the visuals and don't mind the cons, do not buy this game.[/i]

[hr][/hr]
[h1]In-Depth Review[/h1]

[h3]Visuals[/h3]
One of the best things that the game has to offer lies in its visuals. Despite being an indie game, the visuals are on par with high-budget games, offering realistic-looking backgrounds and models. The main character looks similar to how mice looked in real life while still being cute with his big eye. The backgrounds are so beautiful, to the point that you might have to resist pressing that screenshot button all the time.

[h3]Story[/h3]
The story isn't interesting at the beginning. You'll be playing as Tilo, a mouse that has just escaped from his cell. The game will then info dump you with a lot of new terms that you are not familiar with. Sadly, they don't seem to matter at the time, and I don't think that I would be playing long enough until it mattered. It turns out that I was right. There might be some moments when you need to know some terms to understand the story, but most can be safely ignored.

The worldbuilding doesn't seem to matter until you reach the middle half. It will then try to correlate some of the in-game terms to the escape plan, although sadly, it doesn't seem to finish what it tries to tell. Most mysteries are left unsolved, and the world that you will explore is only limited to the island where you were being jailed. All those talks about the other regions seem to be a waste since you won't be exploring it - it's as if the developer decides to cut the game short and planned to tell it in the sequel. That being said, I enjoyed some parts of the story, especially the backstory of each character.

https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=1338399579

[h3]The Game[/h3]
[b]Stealth[/b]
The game will introduce a stealth mechanic at the beginning, forcing you to avoid enemies while traversing the area. Sleeping enemies can be avoided by walking and stopping from time to time, although others need to be avoided by walking whenever they are not looking. Since the camera is close to your character, you need to move the screen while moving to scout ahead. Objects like barrels and chests will also be available in some spots, allowing you to save and hide from the enemies. However, loading a save from that point will force you to exit your hiding spot, and you might be seen by the enemy if you are not careful.

There is no penalty for being seen if you don't care about an achievement. Enemies walk very slowly, and there is no way you will be caught if you don't foolishly approach them. However, trying to finish the game without being seen can be problematic, especially since one map is very vast and you need to distract or knock out some enemies to progress. The thing is, the throwing mechanic is bugged - it won't allow you to throw an object despite being in the right range sometimes; it's as if the game wants you to be seen at least once. 

https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=2169672030

Instead of making the stealth mechanic more accessible, it tries to adjust what happened after you are being seen instead. This was made more obvious after the game introduces an armor set in the main quest to eliminate the stealth section. Since the game is also a collecthaton, the set is helpful to explore the area while avoiding being seen. However, wearing the armor will reduce your walking speed, dragging out the playtime.

[b]Collecthaton[/b]
The latter half of the game mostly consists of fetch quests. You need to explore the same areas several times to find items. Areas might be easily accessible because of the numerous shortcuts, but it can take time to remember where everything is, even with a map. The in-game map doesn't separate between upper and lower floors, and area exits aren't written there. Those who have a short memory term and/or play the game in short bursts might spend most of their time running in circles to figure out where they have to go next.

The quest descriptions aren't helpful either. Some areas will require you to go to a certain place, but instead of marking the location on the map, the NPCs will only say the place with some vague direction at best. It can be hard to figure out where they are if you don't know about it beforehand, especially if there is no clue of the location except the word.

https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=733133892

Collecting objects can be hard to do. You need to figure out hidden paths or even jump to unexpected places to find them. There is an NPC that can mark the objects in your map if you pay them, but as I said before, the maps tend to be not helpful. Since most of them are required for clearing quests, it can be hard to finish them because of this.

[b]Enemies[/b]
The game might eliminate the stealth section from the middle half, but other enemies will show up later on, forcing you to kill them by throwing objects. However, throwables are limited, and you will be forced to run very far to restock them. Although some objects can be restocked in some places, others have no such thing. It's easy to run out of them if you're not careful.

[b]Length and Difficulty[/b]
I finished the game in 17.3h. The game isn't difficult if you don't mind achievements, although trying to finish the game without being noticed by the enemies might be annoying since you need to reload your save a lot. The thing is, the game tends to be bugged if you do it. I even had to restart my laptop several times for it.

[b]Others[/b]
The game has a lot of bugs, especially when played on full screen. The screen will tear from time to time, making it hard to navigate the area. Moreover, there are also a lot of times when you can't target an enemy without using pine cones. Several intermittent bugs that force me to restart the game or laptop also exist, which I assumed to be triggered from reloading a save several times. Lastly, the game hardly has any sounds - the sounds are so low even after I turned my speaker to the max.

[h1]Conclusion[/h1]
It's hard for me to say this, but I couldn't seem to enjoy [b]Ghost of a Tale[/b]. The first half was terrible because of the stealth mechanic - I had to restart the game several times after I was caught for an achievement since I wasn't familiar with the mechanics. The second area also gave me trouble since it was difficult to hide in such a vast area. Clearing areas without being seen become frustrating because of the difficulty and the bugs.

I started to enjoy the game more in the latter half, but I did it by using the guard set that made my walking speed very slow. The unclear map and collection-based gameplay forces me to run around the same place several times to fulfill the quests, including the time when I got lost. I felt like wasting my time running around.

I admit that the game has a good quality considering the budget, though. Despite the issues, the visuals are good enough to keep me playing until I got interested in the story. However, with the gameplay being as it is, I don't think it's right to recommend this game, especially with the weak ending and the fact that I spent most of my playtime getting lost.

[h1] Ghost of a NIMH [/h1]

 I went with completely different expectations to this game, wasn't even well aware of how exactly does it play, and while this resulted in a rough start with some initial design choices and gameplay that frustrated me a tiny bit, I am so glad that I decided to stick with this game because, wow, this was one marvellous adventure full of charming characters, a deep story, and a perfect balance between whimsical and dark somber fantasy.

  Assumig the role of Tilo the mouse-minstrel, you navigate an old derelict castle after escaping from its dungeons, in search of your wife all while you are trying to deal with various puzzles and problems that affect not only you and your quest, but the inhabitants and shady characters that live around said castle. 
As you navigate the different areas  you will slowly uncover more areas and I was surprised to discover a much larger world than what I initially expected, with lots of variety and different problems to solve. From the dark prison corridors and  the calm shores right to moist deadly catacombs or lush forests, the care that was put into designing the environment is exceptional and it's always a bliss to discover a new shortcut that makes the entire island an interconnected - almost metroidvania - affair.

  Gameplay consists mostly of stealth , with Tilo trying to remain hidden from his pursuers (but sometimes you can aid him with the use of various items that can be even used as weapons that will knock out enemies temporarily - or with the use of various skills that are learned throughout the quest) and although the A.I. is far more simpler and basic than what I'd like to, it serves the game well in the way it's designed. Perhap smy only big gripe is that the enemies' vision doesn't seem to be affected by night or day and they seem to be able to detect you easily no matter what.
But later down the line - without spoiling too much - stealth can also become optional through the use of other means of navigation that trade safety for more restricted movement.
 
There is no combat involved!

  Keep in mind though that another big aspect of the gameplay and how you handle the quests and navigation through the map is having many fetch-quests and backtracking. A lot of backtracking, (admittedly things improve tremendously once you unlock more shortcuts) but with very little handholding - which I initially disliked and then appreciated and ended up being thankful for it - making you work a bit and having a great feeling of satisfaction every time you suceed.
  Of course if you still want a little help and handholding, the game is very generous and offers help through a specific NPC who offers maps, hints and solutions, so don't be afraid to use this.

  The game is also far longer than what I expected with tons of sidequests that complement the main story and let you discover much more of the deep lore and character motivations in a fairly nuanced way with all the different plot threads advancng naturally over the course of the game. Unfortunately there's no speech in the game but that doesn't stop you from imagining it while reading the dialogue, to add more personality to the already colorful cast!

  The music while not as prominent (strange when you think about it, you control a minstrel after all, so I thought music would play an even bigger role) is equally well done and enhances that "epic quest in a strange land" feeling whenever it plays as you navigate and discover a new area.

  The story was pretty engaging and once things started coming together I was fully immersed in the world and characters. Unfortunately, [spoiler] while the story reaches a satisfying ending point - it is not a proper ending but more of a "to be continued" one, a sort of "Chapter 1 end" to a much bigger story that opens up , leaving some important aspect inconclusive and I hope one day the story will continue. It's not a complete cliffhanger, but not a clean tidy ending either. But it was a good ending for the part of the story this game wanted to tell. Let's hope for a sequel so we can see what happens next! [/spoiler]

  Sometimes there were a few janky moments and some bugs that thankfully didn't really break the game. Could have used perhaps a tiny bit more polish in some parts but overall, it wasn't anything gamebreaking for me.

  Ghost of a Tale is a very impressive little indie game (and even more impressive being almost a one-man-project/work of love) with marvelous art direction and atmosphere, with a very focused and engaging small open world filled with monsters, stealthy action and a heartwarming story. What it tries to do, it does it well and it is a very promising start from a new studio that manages to produce an inspired and high quality experience with only a fraction of the budget others use.

This is one case where I really wish there was a middle rating on Steam. 

You play as a small wrongly imprisoned mouse, escaping from a rat-controlled fort to find your wife, from whom you were separated.

Pros:
- The premise is really interesting and the gameplay functional. 
- The plot is fine, and the text delivery is good. 
- Characters you interact with are fun. Art is good and the dialogue portraits, while static, change from line to line giving conversations a sense of depth.
- Music is good

Cons:
- Navigation can be quite complicated, requiring you to go the long way at least once before unlocking a shortcut - as a result, there are several different ways to get to where you need to be. If you have a poor sense of direction, this might be an issue as the maps are not very helpful.
- Quests go [i]very[/i] heavy on the 'collect [i]x[/i] items trope'. Collect 12 cards. Collect 50 mushrooms. Collect 3 passes. It gets tiring.
- Encountered several bugs. I got stuck in the catacombs trying to get a mandatory item, and the final quest also bugged out requiring a reinstall.
- The game advertises 'stealth' but this is mostly a flat out lie. You play stealthily for perhaps the first 30 minutes, before finding a suit of armour that magically dupes [i]all[/i] guards into thinking you are also a guard, despite being less than half their size and being the only one wearing a chainmail facemask. You move extra slowly while wearing this suit, so you get to gut the stealth aspect of the game entirely while waddling around. It's farcical. And before you think this is a concession to more casual players and the intended way to play is by stealth, you actually do have to interact with guards quite frequently and thus have to switch armours back and forth. Honestly, it's a pain.
- The game is too slow paced. You'll have to go from one end of the sizable map to another, and even wearing the stamina-boosting armor this takes an absolute age. I know exactly where to go and there aren't even any enemies in my way, let me hurry up please.
- Quite possibly the worst final quest I have ever experienced in a videogame. You're trapped in a small area with infinitely respawning skeletons you cannot damage, and have to carry explosive barrels to a chest and light them. Said enemies also have a permanent drain effect on your stamina, so you walk at a snail's pace. You also have to do this 3 separate times, [i]and[/i] there is a time limit. You have two allies who help out but you're at the mercy of RNG as to whether they'll actually take the heat off you or get stuck fighting skeletons half the area away. To add insult to injury, the latest automatic save point is half the map away. I would genuinely be interested in asking the developer what the hell were they thinking adding this as an ending segment.
- Ending is rather disappointing, and [i]very[/i] sequel-baity. The whole driving force behind the plot is to find your wife, and at the end, you don't find your wife but instead sail off towards a mystery island to find her. The calamity which causes the above-mentioned infinitely respawning skeletons is also still out there. A more satisfying conclusion to at least some of the main plotlines would have been nice.

In summary, I don't think this is worth the asking price. The premise, artstyle and ideas are all there but the execution falls short in several respects. I hear this game is getting a sequel, and I hope the developer learns from the current issues, as there is potential here. If you really like the premise, get this on sale.

A charming little game, though I must emphasize that it is not particularly big.  Indeed, the playspace is only a fortification and some of its immediate surroundings, and the game's runtime is padded a bit by backtracking and find-the-thing sidequests.  That said, the small game world is pleasant to look at and, over the course of playthrough, becomes familiar and home-y - even though some places will remain mildly dangerous to the end.  

Light spoilers for the game's flow ahead:

While the trailer tends to play up the stealth gameplay, this isn't a stealth game - the stealth components will fade more and more into the background as the plot opens up and the game becomes less about survival and more about the character quests.  I cannot say this is a bad thing, as it is these character elements that give the game most of its charm.  Indeed, it is quite the statement this game makes where you go from cowering in boxes and around corners from guards to chatting them up, joking with them, and even gambling with some of their ilk.  And to be sure, it is not a case of simple enemies-to-friends, no; it is more nuanced than that.  Still, this does mean that the endgame is far, far less challenging than the earlygame.  This is not a game to play if you are seeking merely a challenge of skill.

If the core gameplay loop is not particularly game-y, then what does this bring to the table?  As said before, charm.  The writing is good.  The core plot is good.  The game introduces its lore through several avenues: topical explanations the player can click on during dialogue to know what the protagonist knows, snippets of literature and weathered inscriptions throughout the game world, and most notably the protagonist's songbook which he will break out at points throughout the plot - and which the player can peruse from his inventory whenever they wish.  Attentive and trope-savvy players will figure out some, if not most, of the game's mysteries as or even before they approach their reveal, as almost all of the game's lore ties back into the plot.  It is a very efficient story, and by my measure very well-told, while still being robust enough to twist about itself with grace of depth and timing.  Characters are fleshed out, dialogue is well-crafted and, at points, clever.

That said, the game is not perfect.  While it looks beautiful in stills and snippets, there are rough edges to the world.  There are some persistent portaling issues which can create odd behavior with the lighting engine and hostile NPC AI.  Also, parts of the game's questing structure are a bit of a mess.  This, point requires more detail: 

The front half of the game loads the player down with quests that they cannot complete until well into the back-half of the game.  In most cases, the player can begin work on the quest and complete several of their objectives, only to be unable to find the rest, or run upon an obstacle with no indication how or when they can surmount it.  Only unrelated events farther down the main plot will grant the player the means to continue down these side paths.  This, perhaps, would not be such a hiccup if the player could trust that they could come back and complete those quests, but there -are- sidequest lockout points if you progress too far (albeit not many, and they are fairly late in the game).  For players determined to experience the whole game, this may frustrate your experience.  

Also, the game ends on a (mild) cliffhanger/sequel hook.   I will not call it an unsatisfying ending, as the hero's trajectory is clear, and for a game that trades in discovery, leaving a little bit of mystery on the table at the end manages to feel right.  

Despite my talk of its flaws, this game rates highly for me.  This is a great little world to spend a few hours in, memorable and - I cannot stress this enough - charming all the way down.  The creator's competence throughout goes a long way to sell me on future adventures.  I grabbed this game on a whim when it was half off, and now I am inclined to jump on whatever comes next at full price.

Short Summary:
Ghost of a Tale is a game that’s reminiscent of the good old day’s of PS1 and PS2 platformers. The overwhelming majority of the game is based around fetch quests as you team up with other mice and rats to escape Dwindling Heights Keep. With captivating dialogue (text only), wonderful visuals (including animations) and an appropriately sweet soundtrack, Ghost of a Tale is a charming and characterful game that’s well worth a play through.

Story:
Playing as Tilo the mouse, a Minstrel who has been separated from his wife and is now imprisoned in Dwindling Heights Keep. You awaken in a prison cell with a small note and a key to door, and here’s where your adventure to find your wife Merra begins. Using stealth and disguises, you’ll sneak, thief and cheat your way past the rat guards that control the keep. Throughout the game, you’ll meet a number of characters who will assist you – Each of whom is well written and likeable in their own way. Some are funny, others are mysterious and most of them will harbour surprising secrets.
There is a great deal of lore and history that you can read too. Whilst conversing with any character, if a word appears highlighted in yellow, you can click the “read footnote” button to get an in-depth background of the subject in question.
The overwhelming majority of the dialogue is well written gives each character personality. There are two moments in particular that stand out to me as surprising and funny as they are. One involved asking a character for some money, to which they offer you five Florens. If you respond with “You’re too kind”, the character will respond with “okay then, here’s three Florens instead”. It’s little details like this that catch you by surprise and add to Ghost of a Tale’s charm.

Gameplay:
At its core, Ghost of a Tale is a game structured around mild-platforming, stealth and fetch-quests, with a healthy dose of dialogue options thrown in for good measure. Controlling Tilo is rather straight forward, with WASD+LShift for movement, right-click to sneak, left click to interact and the E key to throw (MMB is needed for actions later in the game, but it can be rebound).
The game plays like an old-school platformer, but with a bit more freedom. There are many areas of the game where you see a rocks, rooftops or ledges and think “is there a secret up there?” – only to find your going out of bounds.
There’s no real combat in Ghost of a Tale, although you can distract and temporarily knock out guards and critters with throwable items. The gameplay is rather simplistic, with stealth being very forgiving and, in many cases with speed and some well-placed jumps, avoided altogether.
The game includes quick-saves and quick-loads, playing like a mash-up between Dark Souls and Dishonoured. Its handy to drop down quick saves, just in case you die, but I didn’t find any point in the game where I needed to reload manually myself.
There are some simple puzzles in the game too; nothing too complex, and some are rather creative in ways I haven’t seen utilized before. One example being a wooden post that you can push through the wall to create a platform outside.

Visuals:
The characters are wonderfully designed, with animations to match. Rat guards will stomp around heavily with their armour rattling. Their large weapons, heavy breath and intimidating presence make chases in the early game rather thrilling.
Tilo himself is wonderfully cute, with a sweet and traditional-looking design. His tail and ears bounce as you walk and sprint around the keep, with a myriad of costumes you can mix and match to change his appearance (bonus points for the [spoiler]Jack O’ Lantern[/spoiler] Mask).
But it’s not just the characters that steal the show. Dwindling Heights Keep is a masterclass in level design, with secrets in just about every nook and cranny you can find. The combination of highly detailed environments, lighting placements and swaying foliage create a wonderfully immersive world.

Audio:
With a wonderfully playful and adventurous soundtrack, none of the music felt out of place during my entire playthrough. It invokes a sense of mystery and danger, whilst remaining playful and light-hearted.
As for the sound effects, there were some interactions that felt a little flat. Mechanisms moving, impacts and occasionally some of the environments would have benefitted from more sound effects. But, on the whole, what’s there is good and works very well, with the majority of the enemies and Tilo have great motion sound effects. A certain tune sung by a certain moustachioed rat was especially funny with the offkey musical notes at the end of each line. 

Issues:
Unfortunately, my playthrough wasn’t smooth sailing the entire way through. There are a few mostly-minor issues that need addressing:
• Getting stuck – There were a couple of instances where Tilo would get stuck in cramped spaces. However, jumping repeatedly resulted in Tilo eventually ‘un-sticking’ himself and I was able to continue on.
• The AI – Whilst I would put this down to being a more casual experience, the AI still has some issues. Sound doesn’t have any bearing on the guards at all, and they’ll quite happily ignore a creaking door right behind them. They’re also incredibly easy to pass by. Simply walking up the rear of the guard and standing slightly off to the left-hand side of them allows you to pass by completely unseen.
• Guard stuck in an alert status – At one point, one of the rat guards was stuck in an alert status, regardless of me leaving the area. This made in impossible for me to speak to a certain character until I went back and knocked the guard out with a bottle.
• Gaps in the terrain – Quite often it’s possible to find cracks between the static-meshes and see into the abyss.
• Climbing ladders – Unfortunately, in most cases, Tilo will not grab the ladder at the height at which they’re jumped at. Combined with the slow climbing speed, this can make ladders feel unnecessarily slow to traverse.
• Honey Bees are Wasps? – I never received any honey from the bees throughout my entire playthrough – Not sure if I missed something or if it was a bug (…sorry).
In total, these issues are minor and, in most cases, don’t affect the experience all that much.

Tips:
• Check every storage container. Chests, cabinets, chamber pots – Check them all. 
• Make sure to also check around every corner and behind each door/archway you walk through (especially in the [spoiler]catacombs[/spoiler]) as there are many items hidden around the place.
• Use a candlestick to burn the purple “Red Paw” banners as you go along.
• The dying light [spoiler]requires a wooden stick thrown at it.[/spoiler]
• Collect all the Urns as soon as you can.
• Read conversations and your song lyrics carefully.

Overall:
I felt compelled to write this review as this game pleasantly surprised me. It had been on my wish list for a great deal of time and I finally picked it up in the Humble Bundle with Hitman 2. I now regret holding off for so long as I can honestly say I enjoyed Ghost of a Tale far more than the game I’d originally purchased the bundle for. The game isn’t necessarily challenging or difficult, and you will re-visit the same areas frequently as you complete your quests.

Ending (mild spoiler):
[spoiler]Unfortunately, Ghost of a Tale isn’t complete. The main story leaves you on a cliff-hanger, and I can only hope that there’s a ‘squeequel’ in works.[/spoiler]

This game does have a lot of strange bugs, and it seems like everyone experiences different ones, so some people may complain about a bug you'll never encounter. I'm going to review the game from my experiences, after playing through the game three times.

The "world" isn't huge (although fairly large), but it does feel immense as there are many hidden paths and passages back and forth between areas. It takes your brain a bit of time to learn your way around, and maps are not handed out easily - you have to find them! THE GOOD:

I thought this was a straightforward way for those looking for more in-depth story rather than the traditional way of scattering audio/text logs around.  

THE AVERAGE:
+/- The first half of the game, specifically the very first two locations are frustrating if not terrible. The guards are very sensitive to sight and sound so you get caught very easily. The second half of the game is incredibly easy, once you find the armor suit, guards no longer notice you at the cost of reduced walking speeds, and the game essentially becomes a walking simulator. The first two areas of the game have tight corridors and tons of guards while every other subsequent area is more open and a lot less guards.  

+/- Almost every side quest is about collecting a certain number of items. You are given very little information as to how to find these items so a walkthrough becomes necessary to complete them.  

+/- A variety of different gear with different stats but most of them don’t seem to make any significant difference. Guards will still see/hear you just as easily regardless of what you are wearing. Almost all other gear becomes pointless once you have the armor gear with upgrades.  

THE BAD:
- This game has some really odd bugs; Every time I start the game my video settings are not saved, forcing me to go into my video settings to correct the issue.  Certain side quests are bugged as well. 

- I’m not sure if this is a bug or just terrible design choice, but when you save your game, enemy guard location/placement is not saved, so you could save your game with no guards around only to reload your save and an enemy guard is standing right next to you. This is somewhat alleviated by the fact that you can only save when you enter a hiding spot like barrels or cupboards.  

CONCLUSION:
I was going to give this game a thumbs down because of how awful the first half of the game is but it does manage to redeem itself somewhat as the game progresses. The foundations of an amazing game are here but some frustrating stealth elements bring the game down.

First of all, this isn't my actual play time. I finished the game, but apparently Steam doesn't log play time in offline mode.

As for the game... It's definitely a hard game to recommend, but bear with me. Yes, it's riddled with bugs. Yes, the primary gameplay is running around aimlessly searching for items and almost every quest is a fetch quest. Yes, you'll have to sneak past the same guard like 20 times as you keep having to go back to the same place and it gets frustrating (pro tip - just run past them and then hide. It's faster). And yes, had I known this is what the gameplay is like, I probably would not have bought the game.
But I'm glad I did - Because the story is worth it, if you can tolerate everything else.

More in depth:
[h2]Gameplay[/h2]
[b]The Good:[/b]
+ Dwidling Heights Keep is a really well designed place which feels like a confusing maze at first but gets more familiar and easy to move around in as you unlock all of the secret pathways. The play area is really well designed and fun to explore.
+ That's genuinely it. I didn't like anything else about the gameplay.

[b]The Bad:[/b]
- Extremely shallow stealth mechanics for a game that mainly relies on stealth.
- Guard AI is stupid, they never even alert other guards if they see you and they forget about you in about 3 seconds.
- Too many fetch quests, very few actually engaging quests
- Too many times you aren't told explicitly what you need to do next, leaving you to wonder if you're missing something or the game's bugged. I had to google things way too often to keep myself from being overly frustrated.
- Too many bugs. Even had 1 game breaking bug where a dialogue that was supposed to start on its own didn't start, in a main quest. That nearly made me abandon the game, before I found a thread somewhere online where someone suggested to reset the game's settings file manually, from the game's installation folder, and that fixed it.
- Only being able to save in hiding spots is pretty annoying, because when you progress enough you'll reach a point where you hardly ever need to hide, which makes it easy to forget to save.
- Many side quests require you to progress with the story before they can be completed - but many other sidequests require some kind of hidden item that can be found somewhere. It's impossible to know when you've missed something and when you just need to keep playing.

[h2]Graphics & Audio[/h2]
[b]The Good:[/b]
+ Beautiful art style and design
+ Pretty minor hud leaves most of the screen free
+ Really great soundtrack
+ Sound design in general is very good, the little tippy-tappy of Tilo's feet when running is very cute.

[b]The Bad:[/b]
- Very short draw distance causes annoying pop-in of distant models. No way to improve this in the game's settings
- Objects start looking blurry and pixelated when they're a little bit far from the camera
- Music seems to swell up and die down at random intervals, regardless of what's happening
- No voice acting
- Disappointing photo mode

[h2]Story[/h2]
[b]The Good:[/b]
+ Extremely rich and inventive lore, much more so than expected
+ The world feels realistic and grounded yet pretty magical. Draws you in very quickly
+ Many really fun, well-rounded characters
+ Good writing overall
+ Story is told really well
+ Mix of children's-story vibes with painful reality

[b]The Bad:[/b]
- The ending gives no closure, but instead focuses on building up to a sequel (that will probably never happen)

[h2]Bottom Line[/h2]
The gameplay really gets in the way of a very good story, but overall I think the game does deliver a satisfying enough experience to be worth your time and money (though probably on sale). 
I do hope a sequel will come some day (preferably one that improves on the many flawed mechanics), but with no words from the devs after 3 years, I kinda doubt it. As a stand alone game though, the story is still good enough to hold it's own.

Taken on its own merits, the game is half-baked. Many reviewers have already commented on the unfinished feel of the 2nd half. A compelling, well-written, and beautifully animated beginning drags a bit after the first 5 or so hours, giving way to bug-ridden environments, collect-a-thons, a complete shift in mechanical focus, and a sloppy ending leading to a cliffhanger that may never get a resolution.

[b]HOWEVER[/b]

There are a few [b]very[/b] important points to consider:
[olist]
[*] When I say the beginning of the game is compelling, well-written, and beautifully animated I am committing an [b]enormous[/b] understatement. It only takes the game 1 minute to establish the defining lore and tone of the in-game world. It takes another 40 seconds to introduce the main character, his background, motivation, and character. Every item has a delightful piece of lore attached to it. Each character is lovingly designed and written. The environments are grounded yet fantastical. The lighting and textures are pure eye candy.
[*] The gameplay is a very clever use of stealth mechanics. I read how the developer initially tried to make it a 3rd-person combat game. Demo testers informed him his combat was clunky and unpolished (i.e. it "kinda sucked"). So instead he focused on the strengths of his protagonist both as a mouse (speed, agility, stealth) and a minstrel (performance, deception, music). I'm very fond of stealth games and this scratched that itch very well (that is until the point where you get a particular disguise that negates the need for stealth anywhere).
[*] This game was built almost entirely by one guy, Lionel Gallat. And he wasn't even a developer by trade. His story is very interesting and I would recommend giving it a read online (I referenced [url=https://www.gamedeveloper.com/design/how-an-ex-dreamworks-animator-imbued-i-ghost-of-a-tale-i-with-character]this article[/url]). It's a testament to how anyone can try their hand at game development these days, bringing a unique take on the medium every time. I'm honestly staggered by how much he managed to accomplish. It far outweighs (and explains) the issues in the late game.
[*] Gallat is a film animator. I think this actually explains some of the issues seen in the game, most obviously the wealth of environmental and dialog bugs in the latter half. More broadly, though, I believe it has to do with the differences between film production and game development workflows. Films have clearly defined pre-production, production, and post-production phases. Game development, especially when done by very small teams, doesn't always have that same predefined schedule (though it probably should). Ghost of a Tale demonstrates how easy it is to begin making a game from the beginning, get to the middle, realize you don't have as much time/money as you thought, and rush the final chapters. Why game devs don't give themselves more of a post-prod editing phase, I couldn't say. I guess that's why so many games are "early access" these days.
[/olist]

All that to say, this game is an extremely well-done passion project that suffers from the same issues as pretty much all passion projects. In my opinion, the developer, despite his mistakes, has more than earned my respect and support. I hope a sequel is in the future.

This is a very charming game. There's scarcely a better way to describe it. I quite enjoyed it, and once I finished it, I was kind of sad that there wasn't more. It's mostly because of that feeling that I have to recommend it; I figure they did a good job if I am left wanting more.

It doesn't really do anything new or revolutionary. Instead, it focuses heavily on telling a narrative. You don't really play the main character, you guide him, and along the way you learn his story and come to care about him. The writing is quite good, from the actual text/dialogue to the lore it represents. It is consistent and clever, and quite enjoyable. It's easy to get into and I found myself caring about the world and the characters very naturally. That's the focus of the game, I think. It's simple and fairly easy; just a conduit for the lore and the story, and I think as such they succeeded quite well.

That said, the game does have some flaws that can't be overlooked. There are a few bugs in the game (and not just the creepy-crawly kind). The biggest flaw, I think, is the integrity of the physical world. The levels are beautiful, but quite poorly constructed. Terrain holes abound, through which you can see the void beyond the world. Almost everywhere you look, there are holes into the void or objects misaligned, exposing their invisible inner sides. I never found any that I could fit through, but it's a pretty glaring problem. You get used to it a bit, but it definitely detracts from the immersion.

There was also one particular floor that I actually just fell right through once, dropping through the world and actually landing below in an area I shouldn't have been able to access yet. It only happened once, but every subsequent time I crossed that floor I could see the character sink in a little and/or bob up and down a bit through the floor as I moved on it. I was never sure if it was going to happen again, which was a bit nerve wracking.

 I also ended up getting to a couple of areas by cheesing my way across areas of the level that I was never meant to see, much less traverse (one of which led me to a further part of the level that I wasn't ready for and from which I couldn't return). The ability to guide/restrict player movement to ensure valid gameplay progression is important, and they missed the mark there a bit.

Still, overall, it was very enjoyable and I do highly recommend it. One of the most charming games I've played and I hope they'll do a sequel. I'd love to spend some more time in the world with Tilo and company.

This is an amazing game! How can such a small team make such a great game?

At first I wasn't completely convinced. It took some getting used to the game mechanics, and also I didn't know much about the story and its background. I started getting worried when I realized I couldn't kill any guards, only get pass them undetected (or eventually knock them over for a few seconds by throwing a bottle to their head).

Then I realized it made sense: I play the mouse Tilo, a minstrel thrown in prison without understanding why. I'm a weak, peace-loving mouse, why would I start killing giant rat guards armed with military equipment and lances?

So I had a great time defending my little heroe "Tilo" the minstrel mouse, and I loved the fact that you get attached to the characters (the heroes, but also a few of his allies). In Ghost of a Tale, you play as Milo, a mouse who has been imprisoned by the Rat Guard under an oppresive government. As Milo escapes from his cell, he must explore the prison and the surrounding areas in search of his wife Merra, all while avoiding the rat guards, as Milo can't fight.

Right from the start, the game impresses with the quality of its presentation: its medieval world looks absolutely gorgeous and feels full of life, especially with how well-animated and well-written all characters are. Even the guards, who might seem like random emotionless lackeys in the beginning, eventually show their personality, adding to how rich the game's world feels. The soundtrack is also great at immersing you in this world, with music that's reminiscent of fantasy animated movies, awakening a certain feeling of magical wonder.

Gameplay-wise, you will spend most of the game exploring every nook and cranny of the map as you complete main story quests and sidequests alike. It's an indie game made mostly by a single person, so don't go in expecting a map on the scale of Witcher 3 or something of the like, but the work that has been done in Ghost of a Tale is impressive on its own right. Not only is the map quite large for an indie title, but it's also rich with content, which's much more important than the size itself.

The game has no combat, so there's a big focus on avoiding guards through the adventure. The stealth mechanics are very simple to grasp; to stay undetected, walk slowly near enemies and use cover and hiding spots wisely. Every area is cleverly designed in a way that you usually won't have to spend too much time waiting for enemies to walk past you, especially in the mid to late game.

One negative aspect of the game is that sometimes the guards can feel rather stupid; if they spot you, it's fairly easy to outrun them, and they often won't go after you for long distances. I've played through the entire game without ever receiving damage from a guard's attack. However, being spotted does mean you won't be able to properly explore the area until you're in the clear, so it's something you'll want to avoid either way. And the stealth mechanics are simple enough that it never really feels like a chore or more effort than it's worth.

All in all, Ghost of a Tale is a beautiful game with a very rich, immersive world that is a joy to explore. Even if it's not a terribly long adventure, what's there is very much worth experiencing.

Ghost of a Tale is the work of one person, but you’d never be able to tell; this is a straight-up beautiful game that features sophisticated lighting techniques that make the day/night cycle meaningful, and character animation that really sells the all-animal cast. The writing is top-notch fantasy, avoiding generic dragons-and-sorcery for a grounded medieval tale, in which you play an imprisoned mouse bard in a land ruled by (literal) rats. It does a good job of sidestepping the moustache-spinning villainy of Redwall; even the jailers are well-rounded characters, and the dialog is replete with wit and good humor.

True to mouse form, this plays as a stealth game; combat is best avoided and in many cases impossible (you don’t have a real weapon). But this is more exploration-and-puzzles than Mouse Gear Solid. There are some clever puzzles, and a lovely disguise mechanic where you can (for instance) dress up as a mouse soldier and talk to (and even work for!) your jailers.

If it has a downside, it’s that the one-person-development seems to have led to bad signposting and confusing objectives; a number of times I had to look up a walkthrough, and learned that I couldn’t advance the game because I had missed one small object, or passed by a single corridor. Eventually these issues caused me to bounce off, but I fully intend to finish this game.

Very fun adventure game which focuses more on exploration and interacting with NPCs than on combat and hostile confrontations. The world is the game's strongest point imo. It's compact and lovingly detailed with lots of thought and care put into connecting areas in interesting ways. Each of the 7 areas have 2-4 different paths connecting them and towards the end of the (fairly short) game you'll be familiar enough to go from one end of the map to the other in under 10 minutes.

+++ World detail and level design.
+++ Character writing and the fact that you decide if you want to engage with lore. You're not forced into dialogues that take forever to sit through. Everyone is quick to the point without it feeling weird.
+ Simple stealth mechanics that "just work". Not realistic, but it works well since a short game like this shouldn't have needlessly complicated gameplay mechanics.
+ The ambiance is stellar. You have to rely a lot on your light source and managing fuel to get by, but it's never too restrictive.
+ Character progression is simple and affects gameplay directly. No talents or unnecessary systems like that.

- Some of the quests feel too "fetchy". "Gather every mushroom" could just as well have been "gather one of each". Other quests are much more well-designed, where you need a specific item that makes sense to get.
- The two most open areas feel somewhat empty in content, even if they're still really pretty and detailed.

Okay so, *ultimately* I will recommend this game, but I give it more of a 6/10.

The graphics are gorgeous. I love the environments, and the characters are well animated and expressive. Even early on, there are a number of memorable encounters (the big frog stands out to me for some reason). The inventory system is well-designed, the protagonist seems relatable, and there is a unique balance that I don't see often in that the combat works well despite the game generally discouraging trying to fight one's way out of danger. There's lots to like here.

I gave it a 6/10 in that it's very much a "know what you're getting yourself into" kind of a game. The game is very heavily stealth-based. I understand the game design isn't intended to be able to be won based on bigger gun diplomacy, but between the maps being a bit confusing to navigate and the fact that being spotted by a guard can very easily put you in a situation where you have to fight an enemy that only needs to get one or two hits in before you're dead, I found myself dying *a lot*, and replaying the same stealth-past-those-eleven-guards section for a while, to the point where it stopped being fun and I basically gave up. I understand that that's part of the point of the story - the protagonist /is/ weak compared to the guards, but when it's easy to get spotted by a guard across the map and stealth mechanics mean that it's possible to spend ten minutes trying to make it through a room and then get killed in the last 30 seconds, again, it does tend to suck the enjoyment out of playing the game. Then again, stealth mechanics were never my forte.

So, if you have any skill with stealth games, this one is well worth it. It's a solid indie title that most definitely swings above its weight class. If you aren't a fan of the genre, you're going to find yourself a bit less-than-thrilled at the amount of work some sections take to progress.

Looking past the simplistic (and frankly lazy) approaches the game has for set pieces and world design, there is a lot I like here.

I am a sucker for a well developed story and world and GoaT ticks that box beautifully, with a variety of likable characters each having their own story you uncover throughout their quest lines that actually made me feel for them. The environments and character models are well detailed and the character model idle animation loops are surprisingly fluid and intricate, especially from the indie scene. The environments themselves are varied and atmospheric when they need to be. The puzzles aren't very difficult and the stealth moments are quite cheeseable but I put that as a good thing because you quickly learn how best to end an encounter as fast as possible so you can progress and not worry so much about traversing the world.

I mentioned early how the game design was simple. well.....
Mostly every objective in the game is a fetch quest or some variant there of. You don't actually fight enemies; the stealth is either run past a patrolling guard and turn a corner before their chase protocol can kick in or you duck into a hide-y hole and wait for them to go away. The set pieces are very scripted and the character models act more as triggers for a text dialogue system rather than an organic part of the world (though the artwork in the dialogue is very nice and varied) and when it's time for characters to not be in the locations their in or in a different position, there is no movement or transition.
*pop*
The game uses the same character model for all the mice characters and rat model for the rat characters but change the movements, clothing and accessories in order to tell them apart. While this does work for a little while, it becomes jarring pretty quick. And that's nothing to say of the rat skeletons that are too big to fit inside a rat's body, or when you find said rat skeleton and report he's only been there a few days.

Looking past all that, though, the game has a lot of charm and there is a level of care that went into crafting this that deserves praise.

Easily my favorite game I've played this year. I spent 12 hours straight the first day just absolutely absorbed by this world.

The level design is top notch. Some of the best level design I've ever seen. The only other games I can think of that have worlds like this are soulsborne games. The areas aren't huge but they are dense. You will get lost but if you stick with it, you will eventually figure out the layout of things and where all the shortcuts are.

Exploration is fun and rewarding. You will often find new armor sets and shortcuts if you go off the obvious path and look around more. The game encourages you to take your time and really look around.

The story is interesting and wasn't too hard to keep up with. That said, there is no spoken dialogue, so be prepared to read a lot of lore if you want to know what's going on. The game helps you constantly with that though. Any time a character mentions something lore related to the world, a button pops up allowing you to learn more about that subject. It's a great way to learn about this world's story and is totally optional if you don't want to bother.
