76279405.review:
Ghost of a Tale harkens back to the Sierra 'Quest' adventure games (Quest for Glory, Kings Quest, Space Quest) with a completely original story and excellent art and storytelling. It is the first game in a long time I found myself completely invested in to the world the makers envisioned, and can only hope for future installments.

You play as Tilo, a mouse minstrel who is trying to find his Wife. The game takes place within a rat garrison and the surrounding land, which is bursting with character and a loving attention to detail. Navigating about the keep starts off as tedious, but the inclusion of passages and shortcuts that become unlocked means it gets easier. As you progress throughout the story, you'll quickly realize that the area the game takes place in is only a tiny part of a much more grand world the makers realized. 

Progression comes in a simple quest system. Over the course of completing the main storyline, you'll be given the chance to complete additional side missions for the various NPCs scattered about, with many coming by way of simply revisiting them frequently. Each and every character is fleshed out to an almost obsessive level; you could learn the names of every single NPC you see, including the guards! While the majority of these quests are optional, the benefit comes in learning skills that make the game slightly easier, and in earning experience.

Exp gains are the most minimalist I have ever experienced, and yet crafted skillfully into the game. Raising a level gives you a bit more health, and nothing else. The kicker is, that your Stamina is tied directly to health. So being able to take a hit and still scamper far enough away without needing to recover is a worthwhile boon

speaking of taking a hit, combat is near non-existent in the game. As a small mouse in a Keep controlled by Rats, any single guard can easily take you out if you let them. It falls to stealth and guile for navigating past them. You can knock out a guard a couple of ways for a brief moment to get past them, but the items needed are scarce and do not replenish. Learning to utilize blind spots and the guards patrol routes is key.

My only gripe comes in the quest tracking. Early in the game, you'll be loaded with side quests without a single hint that they can't be finished until you proceed further in the main story. Proceeding further may complete one or two quests, give progress on others, as well as toss a few more your way. Thankfully, the game was written in such a way that you cannot unintentionally lock yourself out of a quest, but my desire to complete every side quest before moving on brought about some frustration. Combined with the quest help in game coming in the form of dialogue that is not logged after the conversation, I found myself frequently stuck trying to find the one thing I needed to progress. And unlike the 2D games of yore, where you could just click randomly around the room, navigating a 3D space with little to no sign that you're near what you're hunting for, can be maddening.

My runthrough, completing all discovered sidequests, took me just over 14 hours, which I could shave down considerably now that I won't be running around in circles. I still highly recommend this game, especially to those who enjoy a strong narrative, a well made game world, and most importantly, who are not swiftly frustrated.

69698115.review:
[quote][url=https://steamcommunity.com/groups/SirAlexandersReviewClub]Follow our curator page[b] Alexander's Club Curations[/b], if you like and want to see more reviews like this one.[/url][/quote]
[h1]OVERVIEW[/h1]
[i]Ghost of a Tale[/i] is a 3rd-person stealth adventure game released in 2018. Play as a mouse named Tilo as he embarks in an adventure set in a well-crafted open world full of secrets and inhabited by many interesting characters. Some minor lack of polish does not hamper the fun and sense of discovery this game has to offer.

[h1]The Good[/h1]
[list]
[*] Superbly made, small, but dense open world to discover and explore.
[*] Strong art direction with excellent animation bringing the world and characters alive.
[*] Surprisingly deep and interesting world full of lore to be learned.
[*] Likeable cast of characters filling the world
[*] Excellent soundtrack

[/list]

[h1]The Bad[/h1]
[list]

[*] Can be unpolished especially the terrain hit detection, where in some areas you are prone to fall off the world.
[*] Over-reliant on collectibles/fetch quests.
[*] Enemy's AI is too forgiving and too easy to exploit.
[*] No voice acting
[*] The story ended in a cliffhanger and the main plot doesn’t get resolved.

[/list]

[h1]Gameplay[/h1]
There aren’t any complex mechanics in the game. The gameplay mostly involves finding a way to certain locations in the world or finding items. There are several tools given to you to navigate the world, and I will elaborate on them in detail.

[b]Stealth[/b]

The stealth element is simple. Enemies have a basic vision cone and hearing range. When Tilo is inside their vision cone, or walk inside their hearing range the awareness meter rises and they will chase him if it fills up. Guards will chase you until you find a hiding place or run outside their search perimeter.

Stealth is also affected by other mechanics like what armor you wear. Some armor is quiet and raise your sneak stat, while heavier armor will attract guards easier as they make a lot of noise. You can also throw items to distract guards and slip while they are searching. Some items give you the ability to knock them out temporarily.

Overall the stealth system isn’t really that deep or engaging. The enemy AI are far too dumb and they are slow that you can mostly outrun them making it trivial.

[b]Navigation and Level[/b]

In [i]Ghost of a Tale[/i] the players are thrown into an open world where you unlock more areas as you progress. The level design is reminiscent of [i]Dark Souls[/i] where shortcuts and secret routes are unlocked as you explore. The world itself is really well-designed. It’s memorable that players can navigate without maps and there are tons of worthwhile secrets they can find. 

Every time a new area is unlocked, you are basically blind as the game doesn't immediately provide the map. You have to find a map hidden in that area, or buy them from a merchant in the central area that Tilo will often visit. The game also doesn't give marker for quest objectives. it gives a general direction of the objectives, but if you get stuck you also can buy hints from the merchant who will put objective markers on your map.

[b]Armor and Disguise System[/b]

The biggest reward in the game for exploration are the armor and clothing sets. Each armor set provides Tilo with stat bonuses that makes him tougher or less detectable. A complete set give special effects, like being undetectable or giving Tilo immunity to poisonous gas. This can open up previously inaccessible areas.

The disguise system is one of the biggest mechanics in the game. In the story, the player are given a guard’s armor set. When you wear it, every turns guards into talkable NPCs. They can give quests, minigames or give hints instead of automatically being hostile.

The drawback of the armor is it is heavy and restricts your movement. Tilo can’t run or jump with the armor on. Later, he can obtain upgrades to his guard’s armor by completing quests until finally it gives him full options of mobility. Most of these quests are optional, but being able to jump or run in full armor set is worth it.

[b]Quests[/b]

Most of the quests are actually fetch quests, but due the hand-crafted level and item locations, most of them feel more like a puzzle or treasure hunt. they are usually placed in locations where it makes sense, that fetch quests feels like organic process of discovery. In my opinion it is fundamentally different than typical RPG fetch quests like “bring 10 of certain random items” and similar lazy design.

There are also quests with interesting storyline like exposing a smuggler organization or solving a murder. The rewards of quests are usually very useful items like armor sets and new skills Tilo can use in his adventure.

[b] Progression[/b]

The progression is simple. When an objective is achieved, you get experience to level up. Each level up gives you increased stamina and HP, which allow you to run longer and survive longer. Obtaining skills however is separate mechanics as skills are rewards from NPC for completing their quest. In my opinion the levelling system is kinda redundant because of how shallow it is.

[h1]Technical Issues and Performance[/h1]
[u]Specs: Ryzen 3700x, GTX 1080, 16 GB RAM, 1440p 60Hz[/u]

The game mostly runs at full 60 FPS, but it would dip into mid 40's when there are big particle effects on the screen.

The biggest problem in the game is its lack of polish, especially in terrain detection and general enemy hitboxes. There are 2 areas where you are really prone to fall off the world. The game provides a brute-force solution that it detects if you are falling off the world, then a prompt appears if you want to teleport above. It sometimes works, however one time it just teleports me to a blank ground that it makes me fall over again.

The other issue is the enemy hitbox. Throwing is a big mechanic in the game. Tilo can throw various items to distract enemies or make them unconscious. In narrow hallways, it often happens that the items he throws don’t hit the target even when the auto-lock is on.

[h1]Story[/h1]
Having been imprisoned and separated with his wife, Tilo must find a way out of prison and find information about his wife's whereabouts. As he makes his way out of the prison, he learns secrets and forgotten truth about the history of the world he lives in. In my opinion the story is pretty good, and there are good amount of interesting lore that ties directly to the plot. The characters have believable motivations and goals and their dialogues are generally well written. The only problem with the story is it ended in a cliffhanger with the main plot point goes unresolved. 

[h1]Graphics and Visuals[/h1]
Lionel Gallat, the mind behind the game is an animator worked on famous titles like [i]Despicable Me[/i]. His skills resulted in a radiant world that makes the locations look like sceneries. The characters are also well animated, from Tilo’s tail waves as he runs, to the intricate details of the guard patrol routines. Visually, it is one of the best looking indie games I have ever played.
https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=2106990258

[h1]Music and Sound[/h1]
The sound effects are well designed. you can hear armors clinking, or ambient sounds in the various areas of the game. With headphones, you can hear guards slowly approaching and that information can be used to evade them. Soundtrack rarely plays, but when it plays it’s usually powerful and sucks you into the mood they are trying to convey. Overall the game has an excellent sound design but none of the lines in the game are voice-acted. This can be a turn off for some people, but it’s an understandable compromise for a team this size.

[h1]Conclusion[/h1]
[i]Ghost of a Tale[/i] is a flawed, yet still a highly charming and captivating game. Its strengths simply trump over the dents and scratches left by the limited resources the developer had.

An absolutely beautiful piece of visual art and storytelling which I can't believe came from such a small team. I would Kickstarter the s*** out of a sequel.

Pros:
-An all-around lovable cast, partly because they're ridiculously adorable animals but they also have a surprising amount of depth as you get to know them.
-The writing is genius. Everyone's personal stories tie together in such surprising and satisfying ways, and the broader universe they hint at has incredible potential for exploration.
-Everything's just so pretty. I've never been this content to just dally through the forest picking sidequest mushrooms.
-Satisfying stealth--I love having a good sneak, and this plays pretty intuitively. The lack of direct combat is a unique twist which forces you to keep creative, and a few quirky little mechanics like your disguises and songwriting keep it diverse.
-The game handles collectables well, which isn't something I thought I'd ever care about. There are plenty of goodies scattered around the landscape to keep you exploring, but everything either has practical value or plot relevance--even mushroom picking never felt like grinding just for the sake of completion.

Cons:
-Pretty poor signage for such an intricate world. Definitely wasted a lot of time poking through the fortress because I had no idea what a certain room was called until I was told to go there, or sprinting on needlessly circuitous paths through several environments because I knew exactly where I needed to be but couldn't remember which bloody cave led to which exit.
-Enemy AI a bit predictable. Felt nicely balanced in the beginning, but as you start levelling up the giant fearsome rat guards become more of a mild inconvenience than a challenge. To be fair, the game's much more story-driven than brutal-skill-testing-driven, so it hardly ruins the experience.

 -Get the Red Mist skill as soon as you have the chance to minimise the time you spend backtracking for missed collectables later!

-Honestly just make your own map.

A wonderful, at times even lovely game, that could have been great. It feels like its development budget didn't match its ambitions.

As it stands, it's an astonishing achievement for its graphics as well as level and system design. [I]Ghost of a Tale[/I] is an excellent yarn of a tale with twists and turns, charming characters—of which you are one—and diverse locales. I also wish the music were better: it's adequate, but rather mundane, which is especially unfortunate because music is an important theme in the story.

The game world is by no means small, but it feels small for the density of quests, which tend to crisscross over the same areas and characters again and again. Around mid-game it turns into constant backtracking, which until you acquire a certain set of items involves annoyingly repetitive stealth gameplay.

There are RPG systems: an inventory, abilities, skills, and levels, and they are polished enough. But they don't matter. The game would have been better off without them. It's almost as if the game changed direction during development and these systems remained.

Otherwise, the rest of the gameplay feels very well integrated into its story. Exploration and stealth form its core, but there is plenty of interactive and delightful dialog, and even a teensy bit of puzzle solving.

The bottom line is that if you are not turned off by [I]lots[/I] of backtracking then you are in for an especially charming adventure.

Note: Many reviews complain about bugs. Indeed, the game was released before it was ready. But, since then, it seems the developers have fixed it and even changed significant parts of the game. I had a polished experience.

- This game has a freaking day and night cycle

[h3][i]Cons:[/i][/h3]

[h3][i]Notes[/i][/h3]

- Since this is a stealth focused game you can't use a sword or fight. you throw empty bottles and sticks most of the time so you can progress or distract a guard or enemy

[h1]Final Thoughts[/h1]
This game took me 14 hours to complete and I loved every minute of it, it is a really good indie game and worth the asking price

[h1]Verdict: 9/10[/h1]

63254219.review:
I purchased this game a long while ago after seeing a YouTube review of the early access release, and only just got around to playing.  I'm pleased to say that it was well worth the time - an engaging single-player stealth-focused adventure, and I'll be eager to replay to find some of the quests and secrets I missed.  

The game's atmosphere is excellent, fostering tension and feelings of oppression at every turn.  Most enemies are armored guards three times protagonist Tilo's size, and the heavy breathing and clunking footsteps are truly intimidating, helping to immerse the player in the daunting plight of the tiny mouse.  Combat options are minimal, leaving stealth and wit as the only means to survive.  The sense of danger is always tangible, whether in choosing the right moments to bolt past guards or trying to talk your way out of a sudden questioning; you are helpless against your foes, and you must tread lightly.  The risk is necessary, however, as Tilo fights not only to save himself, but to discover the whereabouts of his missing wife, lending a great sense of motivation while retaining the fear of being swallowed in the shady goings-on about the prison.  

Along your way, you meet a variety of colorful characters, each with distinct personalities and backstories which tie into the rich lore of the world.  The writing is excellent, evoking humor and sadness equally well, granting each new acquaintance their own depth.  Backstory elements and world-building are presented in lore entries, and though many are directly related to the plot, many are solely presented for flavor, adding to the immersiveness of the story.  The environments are beautifully crafted, with organic textures and colors and gorgeous lighting, and the maps are large enough to allow a sense of scope and variety without tiring the player too much with walking.  Each region and even many characters receive their own distinct musical themes, and your character being a minstrel, you can play various folk songs and ballads which tell stories of their own.  The character models look fantastic, lifelike in their detail and movements, but with a hint of whimsy that sells the fantasy setting perfectly.  

Regarding mechanics, the game was pleasant, with smooth control, minimal fuss with camera angling and platforming, and most importantly, a consistent stealth system which strikes a good balance between forgiving and intimidating.  Occasionally, the character would become a bit wedged between objects, but I could always wiggle out just by fiddling with WASD - no need to reload a save.  Puzzles and hidden items were intriguing and generally fair, with perhaps only two or three instances that perhaps needed some adjustment.  The player can learn new skills by completing specific quests, but every quest completed helps to advance the player's level, increasing health and stamina.  

Overall, I would highly recommend this game; it's an engrossing and exciting adventure in a fascinating world with delightful characters and admirable attention to detail.  If you've been searching for a solid pick-up-and-play single-player experience, you will probably be as refreshed as I was.

[h1][i]»All good Micefolk know to never
Put their saves in one slot–ever.«[/i][/h1]
[h3]- Old Mouse Proverb[/h3]

[quote][h1]TL;DR[/h1]
[spoiler][i]Ghost of a Tale[/i] is an Adventure game with (Action-)RPG and Stealth elements, a highly immersive medieval fantasy world, cute and endearing characters and a solid and engaging story. The stealth aspects of the game are relatively forgiving but very effective and the enemies can at times feel absolutely terrifying. The game also has a great sense of humor and a lot of attention to little details, as well as many optional unlockables, including costume sets. I can wholeheartedly recommend this game, especially in 2020, the [b]Year of the Rat[/b].[/spoiler][/quote]

[quote][h1]❕ Informational ❕[/h1]
[i]Ghost of a Tale[/i] has been developed and published by [i]SeithCG[/i], a French one-man studio with a focus on providing industry standard animation tools helmed by game designer and [b]DreamWorks[/b] and [b]Universal Pictures[/b] veteran Lionel "Seith" Gallat.[/quote]


[h1]🎮 Gameplay[/h1]
Much like in any [i]The Elder Scrolls[/i] game, you start your adventure as a prisoner, so your first task is to escape your cell and subsequently the whole prison. There are quite a few pickups littered around your cell tutorializing effectively how to interact with the world and how to use your inventory. The game manages in general to very effectively tutorialize most of its systems within the first few minutes without excessively holding your hand which is very much appreciated.
https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=1989671120
The core aspects of gameplay are exploration, minor puzzle solving, dialogue and of course stealth but there are some side activities that mix up the formula effectively.

What really surprised me is that the game even features dynamic day/night cycles, when the game could've easily gotten away with scripted transitions or none at all.

Another great thing is that you can actually see items that can be stolen on the enemies, meaning you have a realistic way of telling which guard might have the key you're looking for. Little details like that elevate the game in my eyes.


[h1]🔥 Difficulty[/h1]
For a game with part of its focus on Stealth Mechanics, evading the enemies is fairly easy most of the time, once you learned how to handle them, and even if you do get spotted the game is pretty forgiving in letting you escape. The main difficulty here comes from spotting the gaps in the guards' patrol paths, especially when more than one is present. At some point in the story the sneaking effectively becomes an absolute non-issue, though.


[h1]📖 Story / Presentation[/h1]
[i]Ghost of a Tale[/i], on a surface level, tells a story about the mouse minstrel [i]Tilo[/i], who is trying to escape a terrible prison and find and free his wife [i]Merra[/i]. However, if you pay attention to character interactions, footnotes and the bits and pieces of lore, as well as the more subtle aspects of the game, it becomes apparent that the game also tells a story about oppression and prejudice - in more ways than you'd suspect.

[i]SeithCG[/i] succeeds in crafting a compelling story and believable characters each with their own flaws, strengths and motivations. It also manages to create drama but it knows how to effectively use humor.
https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=1989681234


[h1]💻 Graphics / Art-style[/h1]
The game features anthropomorphic animals in an otherwise realistic world. You can easily see [i]SeithCG's[/i] expertise as I've rarely seen a game more realistically [b]adorable~♥[/b] than this. The game perfectly pulls off soft fur, shiny little eyes, pointy noses and curious round ears, as well as it does slippery stone, warm candlelight and cold, pitch-black shadows. Even more so it shows off the developer's skills when it comes to the animations, which all look very fluid and realistic but also extremely befitting of mice, rats, frogs and other animals. It may need some polish here or there, as climbing ladders for example would look even better if the little hands and feet actually attached to the rungs and guards would be more convincing if they didn't just repeat the same animation three times before moving on, but overall it's pretty amazing.

Another thing I very much appreciate is the [b]Photo Mode[/b], although it can be exploited to scout ahead. Perhaps the developer should've limited that function in some way.
https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=1989664531


[h1]🎼 Soundtrack / Sound[/h1]
The game offers both a beautiful soundtrack and a lack thereof, as it doesn't shy away from supporting its atmosphere with absolute silence at times, leaving you in a dank, cold, dark and dirty dungeon with just the sound of bare mouse feet on the hard, cold floor. Only very few games dare to leave the music off where it fits and it works extremely well here to make you feel isolated and lost. The sound design in general is amazingly believable in [i]Ghost of a Tale[/i], with the Rat Guards sounding especially menacing, giving the game just a hint of a horror game.

Additionally, you can occasionally sing one of the songs in your ever-growing book of songs and, while [i]Tilo[/i] isn't voiced, the melody that accompanies the lines on screen, makes it easy enough to hear the song being sung in your head. It's quite neatly done and I have no idea how they pulled it off that well.


[h1]👨‍👩‍👧‍👦 Target audience[/h1]
Both friends of [b]Stealth games[/b] [i](Outlast, Thief, etc.)[/i] and epic [b]Action-RPGs[/b] [i](Dark Messiah of Might and Magic, Oblivion, etc.)[/i] can sink some time into this gorgeous game. Of course, being a mouse aficionado also helps and friends of [b]An American Tale[/b] have something to look forward to in this game, too.


[h1]💰 Business Model[/h1]
[quote][u]Classic:[/u]
Buy the game, play the game.
No paid DLCs, items, lootboxes.[/quote]


[h1]📋 Conclusion[/h1]
You'd never guess that the developer behind [i]Ghost of a Tale[/i] wasn't a veteran in the business and the level of polish, wit and subtlety on display make this an easy recommendation. Couple all that with the gorgeous art-style, the more than decent graphics and the stellar animations and you've got yourself a winner. [i]Ghost of a Tale[/i] is one of the better games I've played in recent years and I can't wait to see more from [i]SeithCG[/i] - perhaps even a sequel and/or prequel to this beautiful piece.

[h1] Ghost of a Tale [/h1]
Ghost of a Tale is an action-RPG game in which you play as Tilo, a mouse and minstrel caught up in a perilous adventure. The game takes place in a medieval world populated only by animals, and puts an emphasis on immersion and exploration. It features stealth elements, disguises, conversations with allies and enemies, and quests. 
Heavy based on Stealth, so be cautious out there when avoiding those Rats while exploring the secrets of Dwindling Heights and navigate its dangers. 

[u]Includes[/u]
Hiding Locations are pretty much everywhere, you just need to be smart on how you move around. Side Quests + Main Story. Your Inventory contains the following > Tools: which you will unlock more of while progressing on quests and finding items. Clothes: (Cosmetic collectibles) required to be used in many parts of the game. Food: Overall easy to stack up on Food and will never leave you hungry considering on how much Food there are troughout the various locations. Books: Maps, Sigils, Emblems and Scrolls that shows Lore and Quest information. Misc: This is where all of your grabbed items and many Quest stuff will go into. There are much of it, so make sure you keep up with it. Keys: This is very important. Make sure you are not missing places because you can't risk to loose any of them. They are needed in order to progress with your quests. 

I don't feel like there's a need on explaining what's going on in this game. You're better off watching Guides, Walktroughs and Playtroughs on different Platforms to get a clearer picture and of course which can get you help if you ever get stuck on something.

[b] Pros [/b]
* Overall straight forward and easy game to play. Worth buying for full price considering the amount of time it offers + if you ever want to go for those hard achievements, you can replay the game. 
* Fantastic Movement and Jumping system. It actually feels like you're playing as a Mouse with the smooth Camera and visual game style. 
* Tilos is a adorable Mouse, well designed and interesting character. 
* You can tell that the developers have put a lot of effort and time into details, graphic improvements and visual style.
* Perfect amount of interactable items, including Save Spots. 

[b] Cons [/b]
* Excessive amount of Florins (coins) I wish they'd reduce the amount and make it more challenging to obtain.
* Sometimes when running from a Rat and suposed to jump up on something it can be 'delayed' or just slow. 
* Almost too easy when you're going to Hide once spotted from one of the Guards. 
* Short Main Story and I wish they added more Side Quests. 
* Not much Action at all, apart from the endgame, which is pretty cool. There's no fight system, even though I wish there was more than just dazing the guards with Bottles etc.

Ghost of a Tale will leave you with sympathic feelings towards endgame. We're living in a big World, especially when it comes to Tilo. Make sure you take your time to enjoy this game and don't miss out exploring and discovering various locations, items etc. I feel like this is a underrated game and a hidden gem. Maybe there will never be a popular era where games like these take over because I absolutely love them and wish they would create more wonders like this!
I hope they will release a Sequel to this game :)

Short and to the point: Great game. Looks amazing. Truly a great example of what the Unreal engine is capable of. Well written story and characters. Some small improvements needed. Definitely recommend, even at full price. Talent like this has to be rewarded.

Long and detailed:
The story is interesting and managed to keep me engaged for the entire game with some good twists along the way. There is no voice acting, but the conversation card are a good replacement. Especially the addition of the characters expressions at the corner makes it a great read. There are several story lines that come together at several points which is interesting. Deep and well fleshed out characters with several layers to dig through. No of them felt dull or uninspired, which helped make up for the small amount of characters(6). 

Gameplay is also really good. Of course not AAA game level, yet it never felt lacking. The idea of costumes to collect and use for different situations is novel. A neat little detail is the remarks the guards make when you are wearing your ranger costume. The skill and outfit progressions is packed neatly into the story. The detection system of the guards works adequate, although they could sometimes be mistake for teachers, because they have eyes on their back.
There are no quest markers, routes on maps of how to walk or explanations of where to find items. I like that, most quests are fetch quests or equivalent. Combined with the small size of the map, and great scenery it makes that the quests aren't boring or repetitive. 

And lastly some point of improvement.

The games sometimes rewards you or even requires you to jump and climb on and over things, but a lot of times it doesn't. Making you feel a bit disappointed you spent so much time trying to get up that ledge. A small Easter eggs or some florins would help overcome that feeling.

The quests do not log every bit of information given to you. And it is really hard to remember what the smith said to you about something three game sessions ago. If there was just a summary of all the information you are given during a quest, it will make a quick refresh.

The place is a complete maze. Even with the maps it is hard to find your way around the many tunnels. I spent many hours going in circles trying to get from one place to another. Here is what I think would help improve things. Once someone found the entrance to a new area for the first time, make it show on the map as such. Just a small arrow with the text "to harbour", "catacombs" or "shore" would have saved me so much time.

I like how stamina is related to health. I do not like the fact that it does not regenerate while walking. There is a fair bit of distance to cover and no fast travel(if you exclude the guards throwing the ranger into jail). Meaning that it sometimes takes a long time to get somewhere, especially combined with the point mentioned above. If you make stamina regenerate while walking that would make getting around a lot better.

It is really original how the player can only save when the character is also in a save location(hidden somewhere). It is however a nightmare when you have to stop the gaming session now because real life is calling. Some area's have plenty of empty cupboards to hide in, others have maybe two barrels. With the maze it is to get around sometimes and stamina not regenerating while walking, it can take a good 5 to 10 minutes before I finally found a place to save. And then it becomes dark, and your lantern runs out, and so do your candles and you are just wandering around aimlessly desperately trying to find that one ****** barrel. Just marking one or two save spots on the map per area will help so much to avoid this problem. Again, I like not being able to save everywhere, but I do like to save within a minute.

The music is great. When you enter Fartower or Northern slopes at sun rise, the sun rays shining through the trees and the music swells, amazing. Chills down my spine everytime. Everytime it plays though, which is about 50% of the time. Most time there isn't any music at all. Making the wandering around aimlessly really boring.

And lastly, small point I know but one that kept bothering me. Some of the noises the smith makes while striking the anvil are just to fake. It rings like a broken bell, but in an artificial way. And then it sounds like he hit a aluminium can. Just a dull thud is sufficient and much more accurate.

However, all of the above didn't stop me enjoying the game a ton and finishing it 100%(I think.) Really great game, would definitively recommend, even at full price. Talent like this has to be rewarded.

This is a very good adventure game although it has flaws. Still, it was worth it and I enjoyed my time with the game. It reminds me of a mix of The Thief Games, Skyrim and Dark Souls. I usually am not very good at stealth but it all worked out fine for how it works with this game, it's rather forgiving and if you blow your cover, can probably just run for it. There is no direct combat against the rats, but there are methods to stun them or distract them.

The game is also somewhat like a small scale Skyrim since it has loads of quests, many which intertwine together. If the story/world progresses too far, may lock self out of quests, so best to take the game slow, tackle as many side quests as possible before moving on in the story. Then when side quests seem stuck, probably need to progress the main questline.

Dark Souls feel comes from the presentation and the world mechanics. There are tons of passages and shortcuts to the point that there is multiple ways to get to each area. However, the design for some reason isn't always memorable and I still had a hard time remembering how to get to some places even at the end game. There is no fast travel. But the world is small so it's not that big of a deal. The game is also very hands-off and doesn't explain much on how to do things and doesn't spell things out. I've heard reports of glitches although I didn't encounter any game breaking ones. Saving is easy so as long as keep multiple save slots, will be alright. The sort of bugs I did run into were fixed from reloading easy enough. The game seems a little claustrophobic at first - after all you start in a prison. But once the game opens up with more areas and the ability to roam around in disguises instead of having to sneak past everything, the game improved significantly and transformed from an alright game to one I really loved.

Overall, really liked the game. While a little buggy, it was very charming and enjoyable enough to look past its flaws.

It's a wonderful game, with a few caveats.

Good things:
- Visuals are gorgeous, with mostly-compact, detailed environments (in contrast to nowhere-lands of many games).
- Audio is very fell fit, I don't think there was a single sound that'd get repetitive by the time I completed the game. Music is also great, though used sparingly (perhaps for same reason) - when nothing important is happening, you are mostly in company of footsteps and various environmental ambience.
- Writing is wonderful, with plenty of little jokes, lore side notes, and a couple impressive plot twists.
- Average length (~10h to complete), longer than that if going for quest completion or getting lost (more on that in a bit)

Not-so-good things:
- The game has this tendency of giving you quests that you can't complete until you progress more in the main quest line, so you might just spend good 20 minutes wandering around an area before you look up hints and find that the last item is going to be given out to you as an aside on another quest.
- Some quests are kind of just "wander around this area until you find all the items" [some of which might be out of plain sight]. Combined with above, the game left me lightly upset at the situation a few times.
- The ending is slightly abrupt/cliffhanger-y, although was managed much better than in other games I've seen - a good job at summing up and giving you a farewell. Still, I would have preferred full-er closure of the story, as it rendered a few of the quests/lore notes/items ultimately meaningless.
- Lack of conversation log for hints/important notes resulted in me doing 3 playthroughs total (~20%, ~70%, 100%), as I'd get back to the game after a few weeks and have no clue as to where I was supposed to look next / whether I missed something very important (ties to aforementioned #1/#2).

All in all, it is a worthwhile game to play, though I would recommend either not being too completionist around quests or looking up discussions about progression as soon as you start suspecting that something might not be doable at the time.

Overall: Pretty good game, but this isn't a story line that you want to rush through. Make sure you take your time to explore details.

Pro's: Ghost of a Tale sports a really unique idea - a bard or minstrel that uses disguises, wit and charisma to work his way through problems. A lot of the quests help tie the story together, really encouraging you to explore the universe. I especially enjoyed learning about Gusto and Fatale, a witty thief duo that encourage you to look beyond the surface of each story.

Although the game doesn't have the best of graphics, they aren't all that bad. The backgrounds are especially made well. I found myself staring out to the horizon on a couple of occasions. There weren't a whole lot of places to look out to, but where they were, it was great to see. I even found that you could travel to a couple of what I thought to be backgrounds.

Combat is very limited, which helps you to think your moves through a little more, rather than just trying to run through crowds of guards. You also have a limited number of supplies for the most part. You can only use bottles and slime to knock out the guards a certain number of times, and some of them are armored to prevent them from being able to be knocked out at all. Other necessary supplies, like candles and sticks are unlimited, but still a little challenging to come across. 

The controls felt pretty natural (I played on a wired switch controller) and not too confusing to pick up on. The game doesn't hold your hand, and the tutorial essentially tells you that you can hide, throw objects and sneak. It leaves things like climbing up edges, jumping, stealing, and inventory exploration out of the picture, which I would normally find as a problem, but they aren't too hard to figure out and it probably would have felt like you were a child being lectured if they had decided to write all that out.

The story line compels you on with a heart warming story about a courageous husband going to the ends of the earth to find his wife. I started to feel a little of the anxiety and despair that Tilo must be going through as the story went on. Of course, I'll leave you to find the details.


Cons: The world is very small - Tiny. There are more areas that open up as the story goes on, but they don't come quickly enough to make it a good thing. I got that feeling of relief when a new area finally opened up, but the feeling is quickly drown out as you realize that it isn't that big of an area to open. The only time I really felt like I got a new area was when the Shore and the Harbor opened up, but even then, there isn't much to see there. It's just that. Big, long to walk through, kind of feels railroaded through that area. Also, the quests will have you walking back and forth across the map. It would have been nice if they could have clumped some of the objectives together, but a lot of the time you will have to travel to the other end of the map to make any progress. I started to get that bored feeling you get, like when you've searched your fridge for the 5th time and you know there isn't anything you want to eat in there.

Some of the quests are just busy work. You don't gain a lot from them either, so I didn't feel like they were really all that important. The Skapp beetle quest was especially bad. It has you search every corner of the keep, just so Sillias can say "Good Boy." I'm not even kidding, that's exactly what he says. It's worth no more experience than any of the other quests, and there is no physical reward for it.

Despite featuring 5 costumes and a few other cosmetics, there isn't a lasting purpose to a lot of them. You use the Thief, Pirate and King costume once through the whole game. The Thief costume can come in handy as it muffles your movement, but that is completely negated by the fact that you can literally walk past any guard by wearing the knight uniform, which slows you down to the pace of a snail. Even though you move so slowly, it's still faster to use this thing than it is to try and sneak past everyone because of the patrol patterns. You are going to be sitting, waiting for an opening far longer than you would if you just put the armor on and walked past them. They let you upgrade the armor 3 times, increasing your speed in it, but you still move very. very. slow. It felt like they were just trying to drag out the completion time.

By far the worst offender here was the ending though. You work through the story to the climax, where you row off to find your wife. There is no positive affirmation that you make it through the perilous waters, no final scene in which you finally get to see your wife, no confirmation that she actually survived on the god forsaken island she was thrown to, and no confirmation that you made it back alive. I sat through 20 minutes of credits, expecting some sort of Marvel like ending, where they show the clip afterwards, to no avail (you can totally skip the credits if you don't want to see 1093 backers usernames). In fact, the only picture you ever get to see of the family is in the credits as it scrolls up the screen for 3 seconds, and it is a picture of before any of this happened.


Conclusion: Again, this is a great game, I just had those couple of gripes about it. I don't feel like any of it was unwarranted either; they had a very limited budget to work with, and they did the best that they could with the world that they could create. I mostly voice my complaints because I don't want to see some of this again in a sequel, not because I felt it made it into a horrible game.

I would strongly encourage a purchase, but wait for it to go on sale. I don't feel like it was quite worth $30, more like $20-$25.

54787293.review:
Ghost of a tale is a game I'm happy to have bought, supported, and all in all an amazing piece made by a team small enough to fit an average American garage. Charming, and at times witty, I was taken aback as I dug deeper into the lore, explore the well built world, picking mushrooms, doing odd jobs, and appreciating the fine artistic choices of conveniently well placed stools where a hidden item is out of reach.

The characters of this game is well thought out, with motivations clearly mentioned and if one goes through reading all the various books, footnotes, and dialogue, the world seems real. There is no black and white Saturday cartoon villains in this game. No gender stereotypes, every character seems to be, like real life, living within the lines of their own motivations.

The world is built to be explored, and almost every decal seems to be there for a reason. The shortcuts are made not to reduce your travel time, but seems to be there because of the characters in the game. You're just hitchhiking on a world that existed before you and functions well without you. Its not big, and with the many side quests, you'll be moving along this small bubble quite a lot but it never felt tedious. More than a few times I find myself moving around the keep, remembering intricate landmarks of where's where, not unlike exploring a newly bought double storey.

Artwork's splendid. The game is an impressive 3D spectacle considering how small the dev team is wtih an equally tiny budget. A small yet massive world was built on a tiny island that is far worthier of your time than a lot of AAA games nowadays.

There's more than a little criticism lingering.

There is no requirement to stealth despite this being a core mechanic; you can out run your enemies and since the AI clearly can't outwit a stick you can arrange a congo line of all your favorite halberd wielding rats all around the courtyard and hiding in a bucket in PLAIN SIGHT will baffle this well-trained army as they head back to their patrol route as though nothing happened. Spiders that can be kited and seemed more of an annoyance than a genuine threat. In fact, the stationary traps offers more of a threat than any enemy this game offers.

Bugs, yes, plenty, but mostly not game breaking. Many of the dialogue can be skipped by simply clicking the very obvious to progress the story, and hell, some of them don't even contribute to the lore. Kinda felt like it was there as filler . Plenty of items that have little to no use, food collected then forgotten, upgrades that you can easily do without, costumes that plays a role in the lore but in all honestly about only 3 from the available 7 is really required to progress the game.

Overall, despite my criticism, I still finished the game having a good opinion of it. So why is my thumb staring straight down? Its not so much the game as much as my disappointment over how the story, or more specifically, the final moments of the game, has been handled. Let's be clear: if you do nothing but the main quest and avoiding the many, many side quests this games throws at you, all you'll get is an hour long of a pretentious sisyphean chase with no closure. In fact, I only manage to trigger the last part of the game through trial and error since the clues provided amounted to giving you a map, pointing vaguely and telling you somewhere around there's buried treasure and to progress you're gonna have to find it. The ending is atrocious; I reloaded my save and relived the embarassingly bad final quest because I was absolutely convinced that the game bugged out when the credit sequence appeared way, way, way too early. There's more than enough material in the game to double if not triple the actual length of the game. The tale of a commoner searching for his wife in midst of a chaotic world. A rat civilization, an Arthurian inspired story of a prince raised by commoners who eventually proves worthy of the throne. An impressive political struggle between mice and rats, rebellion, and war. An ancient evil defeated in the past but risen again in search of revenge. Tons written about other parts of the world. Yet none of the above made it to the end, grasping only the edges of what could have been. The game literally pulled a Monty Python and the Holy grail ending, dragging all the lore into the shed and pulling the trigger with tears in its eyes.

I wanted this game to succeed and would easily fund any sequel the dev might be planning but the sad excuse of an ending was not able to overturn my unimpressed frown when I 'finished' the game. So, here's a few of choice words to the dev team, if any of them are reading;

- Do not built a world you are not prepared to see through to the end. And like, for ****sake don't waste my day reading through your impressively written lore if you're not gonna make it count. Putting a boat in near shore, telling me to use it to get to an island, but then not really letting me use it and the island doesn't exist. That's how this game felt at the end. Sequel baiting.

- Consider animating some parts of the dialogue. Or show us more impressive artwork of the scene. Anything would be better than a text dump.

- The title of this game. Well, there's a ghost, there's a tale, and there's a pun made of it in game. But you gotta be taking quite a lot of p*** to say any part of the game has anything to do with the title.

Ghost of a Tale is a wonderful, artistic, thoughtful game that combines beautiful graphics with an interesting story. 
The characters are surprisingly interesting and I found myself excited to encounter each new NPC, to see what they had to say and what quests they offered to me. There's a nice, wide range of characters, and each feels unique, with their own personality and their own important role in the story itself. I actually found myself smiling or even laughing at some of the humor mixed in.
The story, as I said above, is interesting. The creators have done a great job designing and building a world stuffed to the brim with tidbits of lore, and I was always happy to find another chance to read about it. There's this really awesome buildup throughout the story. Almost every tidbit of lore comes back in some way throughout the story, and there's even some really shocking plot-twists here and there. 
There are times when the story can make you laugh, then turn around a sucker-punch you in the feels right afterward. This game makes you feel for the characters, it gets you invested in them, and their plights, as well as the main character's.  
And that's an impressive feat considering there isn't a single spoken line in the entire game.
I'd be lying if I said the game was flawless. There are some bugs and glitches, and at times the game does really suffer from a lack of direction. 

Ghost of a Tale isn't the most amazing game ever, but in a time where most big-studio games are released feeling like unfinished pre-alphas, it's nice to find a game with the heart, soul, and passion applied that Ghost of a Tale does. 
And with that, despite all its flaws, Ghost of a Tale certainly manages to feel like a masterpiece.

I for one, would love to see what this development team can offer next.

The first thing you’ll notice about this game is how visually stunning and immersive the environment is. The atmosphere is incredible; you can stand on a parapet and just watch the sunrise, and you'll realize just how much more you need those candlesticks in this game than in Skyrim.

Don't think I'm all about pretty pictures, though: the gameplay has real depth, as do the characters: you can get really invested in them. One of my favorite things is that it's appropriate for anyone, showing that a it can be done without losing any appeal or depth. Don't always assume the game is steering you into a specific path, either; if you can figure it out, Tilo might be just as clever. There are some extremely long treasure hunts, and riddles to solve. In fact, the game's lore is quite important to the gameplay: you are playing a minstrel after all, and you may be called on to use your talents solve problems and clear roadblocks along the way. In Skyrim, learning about the setting was for flavor. In this, it's essential. Fortunately, the pertinent details are hyperlinked in conversations and broken down into snippets in a sidebar: the full details can be accessed later in the encyclopedia.

Like others, I am anxious for a chapter 2; this game's ending is somewhere between Descent/Halo 1 and Descent/Halo 2 in terms of suspense (possibly weighted towards the latter a bit).

[h1]TL:DR[/h1]
[i]It seems like a small mouse in a small dungeon... but it grows to be so much more...[/i]

[h1]The Good Stuff[/h1]
+A rich backstory full of lore. Enough is provided to understand the story, and the rest can be found across the map and read on your own time (However, I suggest playing all the lute tunes and reading the lyrics)
+Besides the main questline, there are multiple side quests that branch out the lore of the world and provide some extra bonuses to help you through the main story
+Beautiful environment and serene creatures in a dynamic world where time passes as you go about the game. Some stuff is only there at night, sometimes only during the day, some quests require timing even
+The soundtrack has an intrepid feel to it while also remaining subtle and peaceful; some nice lute and small string pieces
+The entire world seems small at first but slowly grows into a bigger and bigger map that is continuous and requires no loading screens to past between each region
+Saving requires you to hide completely out of sight, and although save slots are everywhere there are a few times when it becomes difficult to adequately save without issue
+Plenty of collectibles to find that provide lore, health, navigation, quest progression, restricted access or a nice little nose plug to complete your costume... no seriously there's a nose plug costume piece

[h1]The Ok Stuff[/h1]
=Stealth works fine in most aspects, but it can easily be bypassed by having some of the higher-end gear and simply sprinting past guards right in front of their eyes. I discovered this late game and although it's very useful for getting around, it completely disregards the core stealth mechanic
=Sometimes items are hardly visible to you resulting in essentially pixel perfect placement of Tilo and sometimes items are right there in your face and you can't pick it up until you line it up perfectly. I've never had a problem with being unable to acquire something on the ground however
=When saving, you have to scroll down on the save menu as the save slots don't appear initially when you hit F8
=So many keys going to so many different doors. It's fairly hard to keep track of them but it's usually not hard to find the one you need to further the plot line in the moment

[h1]The Bad Stuff[/h1]
-Camera angle is abysmal when moving around in tighter spaces. It revolves on its own and bounces around aimlessly as you try to navigate the underground parts of the game. Also freaks out when you leave dialogue scenes
-Quite a few parkour and platforming bugs where you can climb steep walls or have the inability to climb a simple step. Happens a lot in the latter regions of the game

[h1]The Noteworthy Stuff[/h1]
*Pay attention to the loading screens when you log into the game, they're quite useful
*Plenty of guides online and in the Steam forums in case you get stuck

50223298.review:
Since Witcher 3, probably this was the most memorable game I played for a very long time. The pros and cons in short:

Pros:
- Masterfully crafted story and character
- Beautiful graphics and amazing atmosphere
- Map design

Cons:
- Technical issues
- Bugs. Even game breaking ones.
- Some of the design decisions (see below)

The longer version (with minor spoilers):
The game's strongest point is it's story and characters. I got immersed into the world and setting from the moment I clicked on the new game. The quality of dialog is something that should be standard for certain games that advertises themselves as story drives experience, yet they are no where near as good as Ghost of a Tale. Despite the game takes place on a single island, the way the game presents it's world totally achieves the goal: it made me feel there is a bigger world outside of this island I was given to explore and I would very much want to see those places that the story only mentions. Also, give a cookie to the developer who came up with an idea of footnotes in the dialog window, more games with unique world should do that (looking at you, Pillars of Eternity).

The visuals look absolutely stellar, even if I needed to turn a few things off, like the depth of field and the motion blur to fully enjoy the environment and the work that went into it - altho, the visuals weren't perfect a few reasons I'll mention in the negatives. The character design and the enviroment design was one of the best I saw in any game, it absolutely sold me the experience that the game aimed for.

I also cheer for the map design, it's really well thought out. All the shortcuts, corridors and secrets are well-placed and executed and if you willing to pay attention of where you going, you can learn how to get from point A to point B pretty quickly and efficiently.

Now let's get over on the biggest negatives:
The game has a few issues with it's lighting, especially when I see light comes through walls and other solid objects - which especially looked weird, because the game uses volumetric lighting really heavily and I constantly bumped into places where I saw light rays in an otherwise complitely dark area.

The more serious issue is the game - despite being in the 8.33 version when I played it - has game-breaking bugs. I encountered one in the very end, like right before the finale. I fortunately managed to fix it with resetting my presets, but it was still jarring to encounter such serious issue.

Now the smaller problems:
The game is clearly not meant to be hard or too punishing - and I can overall say the gameplay is a bit bare-bones with a really little depth. It was enough to carry the story on it's back, but the game really lack variety of interesting things to do. Most of the fun comes from interacting with the NPCs and exploring, but otherwise, the mission design is really basic: fetch-quests and getting from point A to point B, which becomes even easier, once you aqiuired a certain outfit. If the story not immerses you, I can assure you, the gameplay won't keep you playing for even 2 hours, not even for 15-20. The day-night cycle while it was nice and boosted my immersion, wasn't really utilized, beyond certain NPCs spends their time at a different location at different parts of the day, which was really diasppointing, especially while the gameplay have stealth in it.
The one more negative I didn't like is the game sometimes really "forgots" to give you direction and you spend most of your time of figuring out where the hell you need to go to progress. This was especially frustrating at the end of the game where this problem got more and more apparent. It wasn't so terrible that I wanted to put down the game and never come back, but I admit I opened Google more than once to watch a video of where is the next place I need to go to avoid running around 2 hours aimlessly looking for something minor detail. I'm glad the game didn't have floating quest markers and stuff - just oh god please, a bit more direction for my lazy millenial ass would have been good.

Tied to this, one really serious issue is the game that it has a lot of side-quest completion tied to the main quest's progression - this becomes a really major issue when you have fetch quests or you need to find specific items. Here's an example: you found 5/10 required items to a side quest. After you find that 5 item, you spend an additional hour running around the already unlocked places to where are the rest of the items you need, maybe you missed a secret corridor or a door or something. You eventually going to give up and move to a different quest, only to find out that the rest of the 5 items you need for the side quest is in a complitely different area that gets unlocked if you progress the main quest. You just wasted one hour running around for nothing, because there is zero indicvation if you actually missed something, or the game wants you to do something the main quest and progress that. This is an issue of numerious side-quests and it's really frustrating.

TL;DR: if you like story driven stuff and you don't mind bare-basic and repetitive gameplay, buy this, if not, don't touch it.

This game. I'm kind of at a loss for words regarding where to start this review. As someone who grew up with movies like The Secret of NIMH and reading the Redwall series, and now a fan of newer entries in the rodent-fantasy genre like Mouse Guard, this game was right up my alley. That aside, from a gamer perspective, this is an amazing game. The controls are simple but all impactful, there's no fluff or ability bloat whatsoever. The controls and movement feel very dialed in, no floatiness or lag or other issues. The art is fantastic, whether it be a character portrait on a chat block or the in-game graphics themselves, all is far above and beyond for an indie title. The game is atmospheric and deep both visually and in terms of lore. Characters feel realistic and incredibly well written. Many games fail to really connect the player to the characters within the game, but I found myself genuinely caring about the cast of characters and wanting to know more about the entire game world. The amount of lore and backstory really fleshed out the world I was playing in and succeeded in creating the sense of a living world beyond the boundaries of the play area. Ghost of a Tale in no way feels like a one off game, it feels like a book in an epic ongoing series. 

The fortress in which the game takes place is a character itself. Most games have you clear out a fortress or ruins and move on to the next. GoaT however keeps you within the confines of Dwindling Heights and allows you the time to really get to know the place and all of it's inhabitants, learn it's every secret and fall in love with the keep and those dwelling within. The music is outstanding as well. I still can't wrap my head around a game this great being made by such a small team. Ghost of a Tale has achieved (in my mind) what many AAA studios fail to achieve time and time again. This game could very easily be the seed planted for an entire franchise. The only downside of GoaT is that there isn't more of it. I'm crossing my fingers for a sequel.

Overall, one of the best Indie games I've played. It's all-around an impressive accomplishment when you know how much work and how few individuals contributed to this title. The game is quite lore heavy with excellent world building, and the space you play in becomes very intimate. You'll know every inch of the keep, the dungeon, the sewers, etc. It's all very well crafted. The game runs very well with beautiful design and animations to boot. Game-play wise, I wouldn't say there is a whole lot to it. There's essentially zero combat, although a select few enemies can be damaged or killed with throwables. Generally, if a game has a poor story, I hope the game-play will make up for it. Or vis versa. Ideally both a great, but in this case I would lean more towards the lore and story being the main factor that carries the game. As there isn't much of a game-play loop here that I would consider compelling or interesting, but that isn't to say the game play is bad. I'd say it's just satisfactory.

Story-wise, the game has some very interesting fantasy elements, curious lore, and plenty of mysteries for the player to ponder, even post-game. This is the best single-player game I've played in the last couple of years.

First things first, if you are purchasing your game is that it's less Action/Adventure and more Quest/Adventure. There will be some platforming and you can stun/kill enemies with consumables, but you will spend most of your time talking to NPCs, exploring the beautifully crafted world and finding collectables. What gameplay is there could most certainly be executed better, but it's by no means bad in its current iteration.

The game isn't voice-acted, but it manages to create more emotional and fleshed-out characters than not only the "soulless" AAA games, but the overwhelming majority of other indie darlings. It does so through well-written dialogue, environmental clues and gorgeous portraits in the dialogue menu. 

This game has incredible worldbuilding. You are confined to a tiny fortress and its surrounding areas, but by the end of the game you will have a mostly-complete mental image of the larger world and its villains and heroes. Using footnotes in dialogue instead of simply adding pages to your lore book ensures that you are actually reading said lore. 

If you like Mouse Guard or The Secret of NIMH, you are almost certainly going to like this game. It is, however, different in tone to those two. The tone is less dark and more hopeful, and all the hardships, losses and deaths have their edges dulled through incredible dialogue, which manages to lighten the mood without ruining it, and various cartoony shenanigans.

Overall, it's hard to do the game justice without spoiling a ton of moments. I personally adored it. I bought it for some relaxing stealth/adventuring, but got a ton of emotional fulfillment and pure joy in their stead.

48894371.review:
Ghost of a Tale is a very densely packed Stealth/Fetchquest game. That may sound like a joke, but it really isn’t.

Ghost of a Tale stars Tilo, a mouse minstrel who has been unjustly imprisoned in the crumbling Dwindling Heights, a great fortress built over the tomb of the hero Dunlain, but which is today little more than a prison where rat soldiers who have screwed up one too many times are given jobs as punishment. One day, Tilo finds a key and a note hidden under a piece of bread delivered to his cell, entreating him to unlock his cell and sneak through the fortress meet with his anonymous benefactor on the top of the highest tower in the keep.

But Tilo is a tiny little mouse in a world full of rats, magpies, and other larger creatures. One of the first people he runs into, a frog, entreats him to murder a snoring guard, but Tilo refuses, on the grounds that he is no murderer – or indeed, a criminal at all.

And so the stage is set for a stealth game, as our cute little mouse protagonist scampers and sneaks his way around the world. This is a world akin to Redwall, where all of the people are anthropomorphic animals – but only slightly anthropomorphized. They walk on two legs, but Tilo will scamper on all fours when he runs, and they’re all designed to look rather like real animals.

It seems at first like the racism of Redwall is present as well – the rats are at first depicted as being rather mean, and the mice as good. But it quickly becomes clear that the rats are indeed the heroes of the setting, and that the mice betrayed them in ancient times to a terror known as the Green Flame. The mice you run into in the game are thieves, and it becomes clear when you read more about the world that a number of mice have been rebelling against the rats – and while their treatment as second-class citizens is perhaps unjust, a number of the rats seem to be sympathetic towards mice.

The game, thus, subverts the player’s expectations about a setting like this, and the game keeps doing so throughout. The whole game takes place in a very small area – a single fortress and a bit of surrounding wilderness – and there’s only about a dozen real characters in the game, but there is more to almost all of them than meets the eye. Thus, as you explore the keep and try to make your way to freedom and find your wife, you also learn more about the world and the people around you, and find that things are nowhere near as simple as they seemed. Everything you believed might be wrong, and your benefactor, Silas, warns you not to trust anyone – even him.

But Tilo is a kind creature, and the NPCs are so cute… how can you not want to help them out?

The weird thing about this game is that while it appears like it is a stealth game at first glance, it actually only is one for about the first quarter or third of the game – one of the first quests you get is a quest to sneak around the keep and gather pieces of guard armor to make yourself a disguise. Once you complete this disguise, weighed down in heavy, oversized rat armor, you pass yourself off as a runty new rat recruit who was supposed to be transferred in. At this point, it becomes possible to walk past and talk to every guard in the place, and the game goes from a stealth game to being focused on exploration and, ultimately, doing what amounts to fetch-quests for a number of NPCs.

What you enjoy about this game is probably not going to be the gameplay – sure, the stealth bit is decent enough, but the mechanics never really evolve because instead it focuses around disguising yourself to pass as various people to get others to help you out. The game is really mostly fetchquests and exploration, trying to find things for people who might help you escape from the prison or help to find your wife.

The real draw of this game is the writing. The fact that the whole place is pretty small means that a lot of what you’re doing is going back and forth, trying to find stuff or get people to give you stuff or convince them to do stuff, or just talking to people to learn more about the world. And the fact that the game world is so small means that, despite all of the backtracking, you don’t actually spend all that long between plot points – the game is pretty dense, and you’ll frequently complete tasks and go turn them in to get new fun bits of dialogue with people. The conversations are often funny, but can deliver emotionally powerful exposition; the hidden depths of characters are nice to see, and you end up caring about the core cast of characters because there are so few of them and you get fond of them by talking with them over time. From the rascally Gusto and Fatale, mouse thieves extraordinare who make you write a ballad for them, to Silas, your mysterious benefactor with ulterior motives, to the blacksmith Rolo, who seems to always be willing to sell you advice for a bit of coin, they’re a pretty likeable bunch, and Tilo’s own polite, kind character shines through and makes the player very much want to help him find his wife and escape from this place.

The game’s overall presentation is also very nice – the UI is generally attractive, and the character models are high quality and very detailed. The way Tilo stomps around in armor that is too heavy for him, tiptoes around while sneaking, scampers around while running, or awkwardly clambers into hiding places (where you can not only hide out from guards, but also save your game), is all quite fun to see. The art is quite good overall, and the characters are very expressive in some ways. Alas, the game is very much an indie project, which means that some of the moments which would have been more difficult to animate are instead simply given out to the player via a brief bit of emoting text, which is a little bit of a letdown – some of those moments would have been really powerful to see, but unfortunately, the game doesn’t let you, leaving them to your imagination.

There is, I think, a certain sort of person who is apt to be very charmed by this game – they will find the characters fun, the art style nice to look at, the writing very engaging and witty, and the characters will grow on them and make them care about their well-being.

But at the same time, there’s a lot of people who will simply not like this game – if you’re looking for a stealth game, this game is only briefly that, and overall, most of the gameplay is very basic and consists of simple exploration and doing what amounts to fetchquests for people.

For me, personally, I fall into the former camp – the writing and characters made this game work for me, and I feel like this was an indie project which chose to use its small scope to its advantage, creating a tightly wound plot with a handful of characters that the game made you care about and want to succeed.

48766809.review:
This is a real interesting game that combines a lot of influences from different genres in ways that work surprisingly well. It feels somewhere between an exploration-based game, a metroidvania, and one of those early CRPGs that's half adventure game...

The main gameplay consists of sneaking around an environment, that you gradually gain access to larger and larger amounts of as you gain access to items, in a way that's similar to the "backtracking with new abilities" gameplay of a metroidvania, but with sneaking in place of combat as the main "spice" to your traversal. I personally really enjoyed gradually getting more acquainted with the environment, and gaining more mastery over crisscrossing it, but personally I have a lot of trouble navigating in games so learning how to get around may have provided interest to me for longer than it would to someone with more spatial awareness.

Throughout this, you have a number of plot threads and sidequests to follow (mostly optional, but also mostly beneficial, and all interesting), to pick up on in each area as you make your way around, giving it that satisfying (and addictive) "let me just take care of this one other thing before I quit for the night" feeling. It feels almost like an adventure game in places, but the sort where the puzzles are mostly perfunctory lock-and-keys, with the challenge being more about getting to each thing you need rather than any demanding leaps of logic—like semi-open-ended PC RPGs often used to be, but again, with sneaking and navigation in place of the combat that they would have had as the spacing between story.

I'm delighted by any game that does away with violence as its main way of interacting with the world, and this game generally fits the bill—there is some killing of monstrous creatures, and occasional strategic knocking-out of guards, but it's fairly indirect, and happens rarely, as a punctuation rather than a monotony. There's still a fair amount of scary content—occasional jumpscares, and fairly frequent depictions of long-dead rat skeletons—but its whole vibe is firmly more on the side of "very spooky" rather than being "horror". It definitely bears mentioning that the protagonist is in near constant peril, but it's fairly manageable; this isn't a "one slip-up and you're dead" game, but rather a "find a way to compensate for your slip-up" game, which can keep your travels fresh and interesting even as you pass the same guard for the twentieth time—the situations are juuuuust dynamic enough that you'll mostly be improvising the ways that you respond to scrapes, rather than it being totally rote. (Don't expect too much, it's not a VERY complex simulation—the guards *are* as dumb as you'd expect in a sneaking game—but there's just enough room for spontaneity that it kept my interest, personally.) The game does do away with what seemed like interesting mechanics sooner than I'd have liked—a surprising amount of the game is spent not sneaking at all, actually—but there's still enough going on that the missed opportunities aren't really the end of the world or anything.

It's a longer game than I expected—it took me nearly 30 hours to 100% it, though I imagine one could sprint through much faster if you weren't interested in all the sidequests... It was extended a little by some crucial objects being frustratingly obscure (even with the help of the "highlight objects" ability you can acquire) but I still usually turned to a guide not too long after getting stuck, so that isn't a VERY inflated playtime.

You don't need me to tell you how gorgeous the atmosphere is, you can see the screenshots on the store page. If the look of that world is tempting you, it won't disappoint. The music is sparse but lovely when it's there; the writing is a little cliché but the characters are charming and sympathetic (even if the writer's scat fetish is indulged distractingly often).

It is worth mentioning that the game is still FAIRLY buggy at the moment, but this isn't too much of a concern, because 1) despite their frequency, the only bugs remaining seem to be minor (I hear there used to be some doozies, but I didn't hit any show-stoppers besides occasionally falling through the world), and 2) the devs seem to be still hard at work, cleaning up what bugs remain, so even these bugs will probably be gone before much longer.

Also, I *did* suffer from some motion sickness, in some portions of the game? The camera honestly is kind of clumsy and uncomfortable, and between the dim lighting and some of the vertiginous heights, I could feel my brain squirming to keep up as the camera lurched around, and I had to stop playing after a few hours in some of the worse spots. I'd say I'm slightly above-average in sensitivity to these things, but not *very* much so, so take that into consideration if it's something you struggle with.

Also, I feel obligated to say, this is one of those games that ends with its story half-finished—it's a satisfying ending, that really does nicely tie up the events of the game, but suffice to say the game ends as the character is only beginning the next leg of their journey towards the primary motivation they've spent the game pursuing (and another motivation picked up right at the end)... I felt a little bit cheated by this, but honestly, it makes an excellent "act one" to the story—I certainly wouldn't have wanted the game to be any longer, nor would I have expected it to be at a price this low—and if you go in knowing that this is act one (and assuming the devs are able to finish the story in a sequel someday) then I've got no complaints about the portion of the story included here.

Anyway—lots to love, and the complaints are honestly minor and, in my opinion, worth putting up with for a very satisfying and charming experience; I can't think of the last time a game felt like it suited me so well, which is saying especially much considering that spooky games mostly aren't my thing at all. But I love exploring, and I love learning, and I love cute mousies, so this game was an outright delight.

Of course a major aspect of stealth gameplay is the AI, which is passable, the guards are lazy and easily avoided by running and eventually hiding, this is of course pretty standard in stealth gaming (it would be awful if guards were actually diligent) and actually gets explained in game, as the guards at the keep are all posted here as punishment (its just an example of the little details). When it come to failing stealth there is no combat at all, which is a pro for me as it encourages you to be stealthy, combat in stealth games is never great as its either bad(as a last ditch option when all else fails) or good which takes away from the stealth gameplay.

But the game isn't really a stealth game, after a certain point you'll come across disguises you can use to fool guards and NPCs into helping you or leaving you alone (on top of other bonuses). This of course changes the game, taking away the stealth. But this works quite well as you get the most of the stealth in new areas, and then gain the ability to switch it off once you get to grips with the area and start backtracking through the castle. You also open up new dialogue and story options as you impersonate different people and there are sections of working out ways to get the things you need from people using the tools you have, its not particularly hard but it is fun.

But none of these are the main draw of the game, the main draw is exploration and if you're not into that for its own sake you might be better off letting this one pass, but if you are into that then its a wonderful game world to dive into and discover, with its history and characters, its lore and story and of course its gorgeous visuals. If however you want something more gameplay focused then you'll be out of luck as the game is quite simple. Still though have a look online just in case, as it would a shame to miss out on Ghost of a Tale has to offer.
