48621186.review:
Pros:

Amazing storytelling. This is top tier worldbuilding and lore. Like Redwall - I think most everyone who's read Redwall would compare the two - but with much more magic and mystery. In my opinion, Ghost of a Tale has the potential to take the top spot for my favorite medieval mouse-adventure story.

Stealth is fun. There are many ways to get around guards that wearing different costumes can help with. Stick to the shadows, sneak past quietly, run too quickly for them to see, or even just trudge along disguised as one of them. There are alternate routes everywhere that open up all the time as you progress. 

No loading times. The entire world is connected, and uses all available space efficiently. You really feel like Duinlan Heights is a place, and you'll be exploring every nook and cranny of it. Thankfully this is never once hindered by a loading screen. This isn't unique among video games of course, but it's still going in the Pros column.

Awesome writing. Not just the worldbuilding and storytelling, but the dialogue and the songs and the lore are all written in a fluid and believable way. Seith breathed life into the characters in Ghost of a Tale and you really feel that they could exist. Even the minor characters fit their roles well.

Atmosphere. Beautiful lighting and an abundance of detail helps bring Duinlan Heights to life. Whether you're in a shady forest, atop a tall tower overlooking the world, exploring crumbling ruins, or lurking in a dank sewer or crypt, GoaT really wants you to believe that you're there. 

Music. Your character is a minstrel, so of course there's going to be music. I've been humming "The Gilded Warrior" all afternoon, and I'm waiting for a cover band to actually put Tilo's songbook to words with vocals.

I think that's enough gushing about this game (which if it isn't obvious I already wholly reccomend) let's move on to the

Cons:

Framerate. All those lovely little details can slow down the action sometimes. Usually it behaved pretty well, but in more dense areas it was definitely noticeable. Not bad, but enough to make this list.

Camera. When you're in a tight space - and let's face it, you're a mouse scampering through tunnels in this game so that's going to be the vast majority - the camera will get caught on things. It will snap to face directly down at Tilo from above. It will spin around him at light speed. It's just a little too slow (but admittedly I never checked to see if there was an option to change that.) I'm not a fan of the camera.

Fetch quests. There are a lot of fetch quests in this game. In fact, that's all you ever do besides one gambling minigame. I'll be honest, with the story Seith is telling here I'm not sure what could be added to change that, but it doesn't help the fact that running around and bringing things to people ad nauseum is... well, nauseating.

Some stealth elements. While it's generally satisfying to elude guards like you're Tulong, there isn't really much to it other than getting out of sight and hiding in a barrel. They never check your hiding spots. It's more of an annoyance when you get spotted and have to take a detour to the nearest barrel or chest, but it holds up well enough to be considered valid gameplay. 

Gameplay duration/expectations. The game ends before the story is over and there hasn't been a sequel announced. Everything the story is building up to, the protagonist's main quest, is left unfinished. We don't find Merra before the game is over. 

Not enough abilities. Placing decoys, playing music on your lute to keep sleeping guards asleep while you sneak past, smoke bombs you throw at your feet with one button instead of using the finnicky aiming - the reticule is rarely where your projectiles actually land - maybe a portable crate a la Solid Snake. A lot of missed opportunities mechanically. The Ears clothing slot is never used. Why not a listening device to enhance your enemy awareness or help you crack open a safe? Maybe not all of these are good ideas, but the gameplay feels like it's missing just a little bit of polish.

Particle effects. In particular the Emerald Fire and the Red Mist just didn't impress me very much, nor did the Dying Light which obscures Tilo with its oddly opaque blue flames.

-------------

In my personal, non-professional opinion, Ghost of a Tale is an experience worth having. It has a few problems symptomatic of being an indie game, but it still stands head and shoulders above other similarly budgeted titles mostly thanks to its beautiful environs and rich writing and lore. The story is left unfinished and key characters are never met, but what is there is sure to whet your appetite for more. You'll fall in love, you'll have your heart broken, you'll laugh and you'll weep. You'll also occasionally be pulled out of all of that by a frustrating camera, some buggy enemy AI, and more than once by getting stuck on a ledge you should definitely be able to walk over with ease while getting lost - figuratively and literally - in the game's lovingly-crafted world.

Been awhile since I’ve played a game with such a well-written story, clever characters, and interesting lore. This game has such an understated feel to it that doesn’t feel contrived by taking the badassery and cranking it to 11. You play as a mouse, a creature with the largest list of natural predators in the world, everything is bigger, meaner and scarier than you.

As such, the stealth in this game may not be to everyone’s liking. This is not about sneaking around and murdering everything. You can knock some people out by throwing bottles on their heads or using environmental hazards. Things with helmets have bottle immunity, but their senses are worse so they’re easier to sneak around. Your best solution is to just get good at running and hiding. Be aware of your environment and all the places you can squeeze your little furry ass into; closets, barrels, etc.

I only had two problems with this game. 1) the camera could be a pain in the ass, sometimes cleaving to the back of Tilo’s skull such that his head took up like 45% of the screen. The camera is also a little slow, but upping the sensitivity in the options alleviated that for the most part. 2) I really liked the thief set, but not a fan of the tricorn hat. If you’re gonna’ be a thief, you need to have at least a hood, maybe a scarf. Those are the rules. 

10/10 hope they make a sequel.

47939795.review:
At its core, it's a Metroidvania but with a focus on stealth and quests, and no combat with its setting and lore influenced by Red Wall books and The Secret of NIMH.

The handcrafted world is wonderfully realised, as you traverse inside crumbling castle walls, overgrown ruins, murky dungeons and peaceful woodland.

The characters are charming, and the conversations often lead to reward, with a key mechanic being costume changes to affect outcome (your character is a minstrel, with some theatrical talents to maintain disguise).

The game encourages exploration and immersion, UI interference is kept to a minimum.

The stealth is simple to pick up, but very effective and I say this as someone who thinks he wants stealth in games but often finds it fiddly. Not so, here.

There are things to find and collect (so many things are purely optional, but can make life easier for you), but it's not a Ubisoft collectathon.

Everything feels purposeful and fits into the universe, and the lore is actually a joy to read (as well as often useful for clues).

if you like Red Wall, Metroid, stealth, this game is worth picking up. If you have kids or want something with no combat, even more so.

47810555.review:
I love it when an indie game gives us the quality of a huge triple A game and Ghost of a Tale at many times does that. 

[b]Story[/b]

The star of the game is a minstrel mouse named Tilo who finds himself in jail in a castle/dungeon of sorts and he has to figure out what happened to his wife. His journey is quite a sentimental one as you discover things from the past that lead to your current situation. Theres a number of interesting characters that you'll meet, that can guide you in your quest. The story is quite impressive considering the scope of the game and I truly felt emotional regarding things you learn. This game is clearly meant to be just the start of his adventure and a sequel will follow or at least I really hope so. 

[b]Gameplay[/b]

The gamepaly is basically a stealthvania of sorts, sneaking around in an interconnected world with no loading whatosever. Some may find this a chore of a game, since you're basically just gathering things to progress and I am the kind of person who really dislikes fetch quests and this is the reason why I avoided the game for so long but I was certainly not bored or annoyed by these quests. Its like they fit with the world and the lore and everything, besides the fact these quests will guide you through the overwhelming map. I really enjoyed exploring everything the game had to offer. At its core, its a stealth game, avoiding guards and helping others however theres also certain armors and upgrades which you may aquire that will lessen the difficulty of stealthing around. One thing I will have to say is that I can hardly call this an RPG. Far from it. 

[b]Atmosphere[/b]

As I've mentioned its one big open ended map with a decent amount of secret passage ways to discover and interesting locations to explore. You'll get to see every location since most of the main quests will take you everywhere. The locations are well designed and theres a natural flow of how the leveles are so nicely connected to one another. The map isnt big but theres plenty of interesting and pretty locations to explore such as the catacombs or the forest. The details on each character is what I was impressed. This is the work of a few people and it surpasses many huge games in this regard, specifically the main character. Well done on the clothing and animations. The game also has a day/night cycle which is quite an impressive feat for a handful of people. 

[b]Sound[/b]

There is no voice acting in the game sadly but it wont be missed. The dialogue text will still offer emotional impact. The music is well composed, especially the songs Tilo can sing and as for the rest of the exploration/dialogue songs, they're good enough. Cant really complain. Sound effects are pretty much standard and theres nothing outstanding or bad about them. 

[b]Conclusion[/b]

Ghost of a Tale surprised in ways I didnt expect. Yes there are fetch quests and that may upset or bore people but they feel natural and not forced as if they're part of the game not just to fill your time pointlessly and while there is no voice acting the story is still emotionally written. A really great stealthvania with an emotional story that I really enjoyed. I wanted more but I was still pleased with what I got and I do hope we get the sequel to Tilo's adventure. 8.5/10

47785890.review:
This was one of those games where I just really connected with the main character.
Amazing game and an absolute hidden gem on steam.

Graphics:
Beautiful, and screenshot worthy. They have a photomode where you can engross yourself with the game's Stunning visuals

Map:
Open world but not a big map. Its small in comparison to other open world games, but so dense and so amazingly made. Dark souls-esc checkpoint/shortcut system. 7 map sets/areas so a continous change in scenery.

Gameplay:
Stealth orientated. There is no combat besides throwing some things, if that could be considered as such. It is a very passive type of game. There is a lot of back and forth that takes place, as quests will require you to go to the several areas to help complete them.

Characters:
As mentioned, I have never bonded with my character as much as I have had in Ghost of a Tale in a long time. There is a lot of dialogue between characters and the main characters in this game are amazingly created. Each have various amounts of personalities and backgrounds. Heck, you could even bond with what's supposed to be your enemies if you go along that path.

Choices/Interactions:
The game was suprisingly good when it came to how it adapted to your decisions. In terms of gameplay I'm not certain much changes according to what you do, but the dialogue is affected. Even some things you do out of dialogue can affect dialogue in the future. So be quite careful how you play it. If you stick to main quests you will have different dialogue compared to if you did the side quests as well.

Is it worth the price?
For what its worth I would say this was extremely worth it. Its not expensive and its a nice game to play if you want a nice quiet, immersive, relaxing weekend with a bit of puzzles along the way.

Comments:
-I found myself to be lost in many situations because there is no hand holding by the game. Whatever questions you may have you need to interact with the characters to find out, and sometimes they don't. So whenever you're given information, its best to pay attention and not skip dialogue.
-Every now and then I had a bug where the camera bugged behind me and I'd get lost for a decent second but I'm not entirely sure if it was just me or thats actually something in the game. It wasn't bad to the point where it ruined the experience though.

Praise to the devs:
I really enjoyed this game. I love the characters, I love the story, I love the gameplay, the scenery and the graphics. This was a great game to end 2018 off with.
Thank you SeithCG and your team, I look forward to supporting your future projects.

47759159.review:
I had long been awaiting to get this game. From the trailers and online material it looked like a very visually stunning game, and to that point it did not disapoint. The graphics are absolutely amazing and very well detailed and in that respect I'll give them 10/10 for graphics. 

The game play however, may or may not be everyones cup of tea. The game is 100% single player - which is great for those gamers who enjoy a good story line or like a bit of critical thinking to achieve quests. The game offers almost no assistance when looking for quest items or people. The game drops hints by talking to other characters, but you may want a pen and paper handy because often times once a clue is given, it is not always able to be accessed again and wont necessarily show in your journals - this makes paying attention to detail important in this game. However, even if you enjoy that kind of things, there are some points in the game where you just have to guess or get lucky to find out how to finish a quest, as there are not always hints to help you figure it out, this can get frustrating. So those of you who like spoon-fed quest progressions, this games not for you. 

VERY MILD SPOILER ALERT
I'll do my best not to give anything away here, but the story line is kind of lacking. It seems as though the story progresses in an almost sparatic manner and doesn't leave much to grab players in being truly invested in the story. The story line of the game progresses with your character looking for his wife, and then about 2/3 of the way into the game, the quest lines take a whole different direction and frankly I was very dissapointed by the way they summed up the story. Which brings me to my final complaint of the game - lack of content. For a roughly $30 game I expect more content - I shouldnt be able to complete every quest, gather all the extra stuff and beat the game in less than 12 hours of gameplay, that was REALLY dissapointing.

 In summary; fantastic graphics and not buggy at all, game looks beautiful and functions very smoothly. Gameplay is fun but lacking in additional content that I feel should've been implimented into the game; and the storyline itself left much to be desired. A nice PG single player game, overall 6/10.

This is the first time I have been moved to write a review for a game.  

Let me preface by saying that stealth games are NOT one of my preferred genres.  I standardly only play hard-core strategy, ARPG's or open world/ sandbox RPG's (usually modded  for extreme difficulty). I also tend not to care about plot in my games as I can get that much more effectively from a book and I prefer to role play my own plot while gaming.  What is so impressive to me about Ghost of a Tail is that I love it for precisely the things I don't usually care about in games.  Namely, it's very-well implemented stealth mechanics and it's immersive, surreal plot and world.  

I took a chance on this game because I was a fan of Brian Jacques, Redwall books and this game looked like it could be a story ripped from those pages.  And OMG was this so much more than that.  As other reviews have said, the world and environments are beautifull.  Every area oozes character, personality and charm. I gradually stopped, simply trying to accomplish the next task needed to progress the plot and found myself lingering in a beautifull courtyard watching leaves blow in the wind, or trying to find ingenious ways to climb to roofs so I could get a better view of the world.

The various characters you meet and interact with are charming, witty and eccentric. I  am one of those people that gets tired of reading dialogues and just skip them.  But I started looking forward to more interactions with these characters.  I started pausing to laugh or reflect on what they say before picking my responses.  

At first I thought, "Ok, pretty world.  I guess I'd like to see what the other area's graphics are like."  But as I played, the story began to subtlly flesh out and the characters gradually became more and more interesting untill I suddenly realized that I was fully immersed in this world and that I didnt want to beat it too soon.  There are a great number of unanswered questions and mysteries as you progress in the game.  I found I wanted to know who someone really was.  Or who I could actually trust.  Or what events had happened to get my character to this place.  And as the game drew me in and I became steadily more curious, A suprisingly deep ammount of lore gradually became available. You also gradually learn your own story as you play.  Most things in this game are reaaly well implemented in an organic and natural way. 

The stealth mechanics:  Very nice, tight implementation of stealth.  Not too tense as to detract from interest in the surroundings and environment and not too lax or simple as too be boring.  For me, being not a fan of stealth games, it was a very nice balence.  Hiding, throwing, sneaking, stamina management, moving objects, tools and different outfits that actually effect interactions and gameplay.  Very fun:).

Ghost of a Tail is not without flaws.  There was a cave ceiling with unfinished textures and a few obscure areas where I fell through the geometry, but there were very few of these and all of them were in obscure and out of the way areas-usually because I climbed way outside the world perameters.  

I would highly recommend this game for those that can slow down a little and play it for its immersive story, fun stealth and beautiful world.  It is not a fast-paced game with immediate gratifacation.  It will take some patience and investment, but it will be worth it.

My favorite aspect though by far is the characters and dialogue, let me tell you, they are just an absolute treat to read through. Another aspect this game handles seamlessly is the lore. You can tell this was carefully thought through and there's a whole world and history out there that you don't know about. As for gameplay, it controls well enough for what it is. There's little to no combat, and the game is very stealth heavy. We as modern gamers are so used to following quest markers and icons that when a game actually forces us to think and remember where that room was, or where that NPC was, or to follow dialogue directions instead of on screen arrows, it throws us off, but when you actually take a second to think, it's really not that hard. It's definately old school in that sense, although it's not near as hard as games back then, but I digress.

"...you're a brave Mouse, Tilo the Minstrel"

Summed up: An utterly captivating experience. The ultimate fantasy mouse sneaking and eating simulator RPG. The UFMSESRPG, if you will.

It's a little rough on the technical and performance side, but if you can stomach that, this is an engaging and beautiful little adventure, with very strong worldbuilding, attention to detail and a gentle yet haunting atmosphere.

What starts as a heavily stealth focused prison escape, avoiding guards, sneaking into different parts of a fortress, snagging keys and food, quickly expands into a broader game of disguises, exploration, conversations and puzzle solving. 

Much like the gameplay, the story quickly expands and unfolds, adding weight, detail, meaning, purpose. The characters reveal new sides of themselves, colouring their actions, explaining their motivations. Their dreams, their fears, their regrets and painful memories. Their mistakes. It's all surprisingly powerful stuff and you grow to love them all a little bit. It makes you wanna see Tilo find his path just a little bit more.

The game world is relatively small, but there is a Souls like feel to the lack of handholding, as you venture further and further down winding corridors, stairwells, basements, rooftops, caves and forests and catacombs, the pathways and passages crisscrossing and looping back into each other and opening up new shortcuts and secrets, as you keep returning to previously visited areas. If you absolutely hate backtracking, consider this a fair warning.

There's a host of great characters to interact and help or avoid, and the whole thing is just incredibly charming and engaging in every way. There's even a tiny bit of choice on what to say and who to help. It's nothing major, but it adds a little bit of extra on top of an already engaging narrative.

Now, there ARE technical issues and little bugs you might come across. This is a GOOD looking game, but playing it a little longer, you can tell the team is small. So just keep that in mind if that kind of stuff REALLY bothers you. 

The enemy AI isn't particularly smart, making the stealth a lot easier than it initially seemed (thought there is an achievement for completing the game without guards spotting you, and that will take discipline). The puzzles can be obtuse and will leave some wandering aimlessly not know what to do or where, but there, again, is a Souls like appeal to it: the game trusting you to search and explore for yourself, making the discovery of a new key or an item or a piece of clothing or a bit of narrative so much more rewarding. And should you get stuck, there are NPCs that will point you in the right direction should you need it.

At the end of the day, this is a compelling glimpse into a fantasy world I deeply want to see more of. The animal characters are all endearing, brought to life with lovely portrait art and animation, and written with great care and wit. The crooked architecture and gorgeous skyboxes are dreamlike and perfectly fitting of the tone of the world. The combination of exploration, sneaky theft, puzzle solving and no outright combat proved completely irresistible for me and I loved all 20 hours of it. Here's hoping there will be another chapter in Tilo's tale as this is a wonderful opening act.

[h1] Experienced on the Oculus Rift with Xbox 360 controller. VR Review. Spoiler-free Review. [/h1]

[i] Note for VR: this game does [u]not[/u] run natively in VR but can with a downloadable mod. You also need to download a prior version of the game. I will include a step by step at the end of my review. [/i]

Before I mention anything else, this is one of the best story focused, quest-driven, single player games I have played in VR. It's not as good as Hellblade: Senua's sacrifice, but it's up there, just one notch below. The game took me about 24 hours to complete the main story and some side quests. I did not complete every side quest although I did attempt nearly all of them to some degree. I did try to complete the game without looking online for answers, but did have to do just that for some quests after being stuck for a bit.

I developed red marks on my forehead from having my HMD on my face for many hours at a time (they're gone now). This game will test your VR limits because you'll want to finish the game, but it is a daunting task in VR. You'll need to take breaks while at the same time, not let too much time pass by before you forget where stuff is. This is a small world when you think about it, but it seems big, maybe even bigger in VR. It kind of feels like Dark Souls 1, because as you go you'll encounter shortcuts traversing the world, a secret passage that you didn't know was there. 

The graphics are absolutely stunning. When your mouse (Tilo) gets a new costume, there's just a cuteness overload. So you'll definitely want to get those, but of course, the pieces are hidden and strewn all around the game world. The environments look great. This mod really shows how detailed the world is and how much love these devs put in making this game world. Lots of little details that you'll probably miss playing this game 2D. About the only things that didn't look great was some of the textures on the harbour/ shore, low light areas, and the bees. Each area looks different and it's just amazing to discover it in VR.

Despite the amazing VR experience, there's lots of flaws with this mod. So it's not for everyone. You'll have to put up with lots of bad things to enjoy the good. Probably the most annoying thing is that the Control C, Control V, F5 doesn't always work and you'll have to try several times (don't worry if you don't know what that means, you will know). You also can't see your aiming reticles so you'll be firing blind most of the time. Luckily, you can still hit most things with just a little practice without any proper aiming. 

Whenever you hide, which you'll be doing often, for whatever reason these comfort options turn on that create blind spots. Those will be annoying but you'll learn to live with them as there's not much you can do about it. Unfortunately, they sometimes stay on your VR headset display even after you've left the hiding spot. You may want to try Control C, Control V, and F5, but it doesn't always fix it. You may just want to scoot your head closer to your sensors or farther away. Just moving your head around will fix the issue although it may be uncomfortable. 

If you move your head around, you can get into situations where the game tells you you're out of bounds. That's annoying as you'll have to move your head until you land back within playing bounds. You can also clip through objects and see far off into the map. Depending on your video card, you will get low frame rates per second. Mine got as low as 22, especially in the harbour area and the end fight. Usually, I ran at 45 frames per second. When the game hits low frame rates, your walking speed will feel it and it's painful to play for that reason although it's actually not painful to watch like it does in other games with faster movement.

The last negative is that you're playing an older version of the game, so you'll have to deal with some bugs. The biggest one for me was that certain stuff wouldn't show on my map like the location of things even after paying off the smith. Don't worry if you don't know what that means, you will. I did also have a missing object, but simply completely exiting the game and restarting did the trick.

VR Rating 7.5/10. Amazing mod overall. I wish SeithCG would make this game native VR. This mod shows how amazing the VR experience would be in this game. If you love VR, I recommend you take the steps below to experience this game in VR. If you're wondering, I rate on a bell curve, so a 7.5 is actually a very good score. I gave Hellblade an 8.5 if that gives you some frame of reference.

[olist]
[*]Buy the game. 
[*]Download the VRGIN mod 1.1 by Eusth on Github (google VR Ghost of a Tale for link). 
[*]Run Steam console (see YouTube videos if you don't know how). While in Steam console, download an older version of game 7.08 (type this command "download_depot 417290 417291 3656326342022463498" without the quotes. Find the downloaded file in your steam downloads (usually under c drive, check program files x86, content, app_ , depot or search for GOAT). 
[*]Copy above downloaded files directly in your GOAT steam folder
[*]Unzip mod files. Copy files directly into your GOAT steam folder.
[*]Move GOAT.exe unto IPA.exe file. That makes a command prompt show up, which creates a new startup option for GOAT. Pin this new shortcut to taskbar for easy starting.
[*]Start Steam VR.
[*]Then start the new shortcut GOAT. Wait until game starts before doing next step.
[*]Type Control + C,  Control + V,  then press F5. (you may need to do this more than once in that order).
[*]You should be in VR. If you see clouds or skies or you're not positioned correctly, Repeat Step 9.
[/olist]

[h1] Good but flawed, waiting for a sequel  [/h1]

I gotta say the game surprised me. It was being developed for like 5 years but the news never reached me at all, then suddenly Steam recommended it for me and I decided to buy it. 
It's not a very long game - unless you get lost all the time, your first playthrough shouldn't take more than 10 hours.
For some reason, all the reviews and descriptions call it an action-RPG, which is balderdash. It's a stealth game with some RPG elements (levelling up your health/stamina, getting some new gear -which acts primarily as disguise- and learning some more or less useful skills).

Now as far as gameplay mechanics go, it's not too shabby but nothing special either. You sneak, lurk in shadows or hide in barrels/chests, distract or temporarily knock out your enemies (you're no murderer, alright?) and fetch stuff. Where the game really shines is its story, characters and lore. 

The game world - Dwindling Heights Keep, where the entire game takes place - seems intimidating at first and you will get lost a lot, but will soon find out that it isn't THAT large and soon enough you will see yourself doing plenty of backtracking to get new items, unlock previously locked areas and discover shortcuts. By the end of the game, the place will surely grow on you as you memorize every single room and corridor. It has its charm and for a lack of better comparison, it reminds me of the mansion in the first Resident Evil game - a place where everything is hostile to you, and yet it starts to feel like home. Same stuff right here. Even your enemies (whom you can eventually trick to think that you're one of them, and thus, talk to you) will start to feel like your buddies, too.

As far as quests are concerned, they're not very inspired, generally you have to steal/fetch/find something and that's it. There's one quest where you're serving tables in a mess hall so that's pretty unique, I think. What matters the most about the quests is all the story and dialogue behind them.

And as far as those things go, it's pretty great. The characters are all unique and interesting in their own ways, some have much more to them than it may appear at first (Silas and Fatale being the prime examples), the dialogue itself is very pleasant to follow, thanks to simple yet satisfying writing style - no excessive dramatism and purple prose, which are all too common in modern games, the lines feel organic and natural, with even some jokes mixed in. 

The lore about which you can learn from dialogue and in-game codex is pretty creative and fun to read about, with more focus on relations beetwen the races, customs and traditions, rather than stuff like wars, heroes and villains. Really gave me the feeling that there's a living world somewhere out there and the urge to get to know it better (even though I'm not generally fond of Redwall-esque animal kingdom stuff)

It's not without flaws, though. Like I said, the gameplay mechanics are nothing to write home about. Your adversaries are so dumb sometimes you just wonder if they have to be told to inhale and exhale or else they will forget to breathe (the game does tell you that they're mostly the biggest losers out there, story-wise). Almost feels like an old Tenchu game. Searching the barrel in an otherwise empty room to which you've fled is above their pay, it seems. Overall, once you get the grasp on controls, enemies become more of a nuisance than an actual threat, with a few exceptions.
Also,  the game was mostly created by one guy, which shows at times. While the graphics, sound, attention to detail and level design are all top notch, sometimes the game falls short, particularly when it comes to bigger story events (enemies bugging out when fighting each other, NPCs not reacting properly to recent events etc.).

Another issue is the lack of replayability. One thorough playthrough is enough to get almost everything out of the game.
I managed to get all but one achievement (which I believe is bugged) in my first (and for now, only) playthrough so you definitely won't come back for extra challenges or anything like that. You may play again so that more early-game stuff makes sense because you now fully understand the story, but other than that it's a game that you won't play more ofter than once every few years or so.

As for the bugs and technical stuff...I did encounter one game-breaking bug but it was taken care of recently and the support did fix my savefile. Other than that, nothing major. The game also runs smoothly in 60 FPS all the time.
The game definitely shows a lot of promise and I'm sure we could expect a lot from potential sequel/DLC.

Cons: You have to want to invest a lot of time figuring out all the maps, and the perks you get from certain items (*1). Once you've done that, a second play through will be MUCH more enjoyable. Some minor glitches (*2). Level design is very confusing, but I feel as though that was on purpose. I often find myself running around for a long while trying to remember how I got to one specific place just to give up and google it, along with 90% of all ingame items and locations (*3). That does encourage exploration though, however, doing so is not really possible without certain gear that you acquire later on, which can be very frustrating not being able to, nor know how to complete a mission. Missions are very non-specific in how to go about or solve them, even the main story line. A LOT of guess work is needed, or looking it up. While this harkens a mindset back to how Morrowind was played, they give you even less to go on here, which most times is hella confusing, and down right frustrating. More specific information for certain items and story lines would be outstanding. If you fail to complete some certain side quests by a certain point in the game, that's it. You're done. You'll have to restart a new game to complete it and get the achievement. While it IS only a 20ish hour game, a second playthrough only attempting to get those quests completed isn't sooooo bad. 

*1: Items, for the most part, besides health regen, do not indicate their uses. Such as, when you collect a full outfit, the game does not let you know the perks of wearing the outfit, which for some, are NEEDED to finish a quest. While some are slightly obvious, like wearing the pirate costume when speaking to the pirate to further along a story line, or wearing the thiefs outfit to further along a story line, there are other perks that you gain while wearing the full outfit that the game doesn't even hint at, such as when wearing the Ranger outfit the guards wont attack you. Things like that would be SUPER useful to know as you need certain outfits to get to certain areas. Some hints about items and outfits will go a LONG way.

*2: Minor glitches. There will be a few times when a dialog box will not appear, or a wall is in the middle of a passage way that wasn't there before. A simple save and reload at the closest save point 9/10 times alleviates this issue. SAVE. OFTEN. Every chance you get. If you've gone 100ft from your previous save point, SAVE. AGAIN.

*3: There are in game maps which show mission specific items and locations, but the maps are useless sans for which direction to go in (North, South, East or West). They do indicate whether the item or location is above or below you, but the maps are so poorly done that you will never be able to figure out how to get to that location using the map. Nor do they indicate which part of the level, above or below you, that the map is drawn. For instance, they show a hallway that only exists on the 3rd floor, you can't see what is on the second or first floors (other rooms, other hallways, stairwells etc). This, combined with the confusing level design gave me the most headache when trying to complete side quests. The poor map design does not guide you to locations you KNOW are possible to get to, but can't figure out. The ability to leave marks or something like that on the map would be super useful. 

Other: 20 hours in, beat the game with only half the achievements unlocked. And only JUST started to barely memorize the first 2 playable areas. A Second Playthrough is needed to get a full grasp of the game. I feel as though the Devs know this cause the option to Start A New Game is right there during the pause screen. 

All in all, it is a VERY well done game visually, aesthetically, and replayability. All the characters are unique and charismatic, and the art style and drawings are superb, which is nice considering the only time you ever interact with any of the characters is through a dialog box. Once you figure out what all the items and outfits are for the game becomes way less frustrating. But with that in mind, Id give it a 7/10 for some minor glitches and the headache of trying to figure the maps and what most of the items are for. It is a finite game, with definite story beginning and end marks that you may miss if you progress the wrong story line too quickly over the others. But again, a second play through should be much more enjoyable once you know what you're doing.

Not much to say (or too much really). Being a gamer since 1987 when I got my first taste of videogames, Ghost of a Tale is one of those games that restore my faith in the gaming industry. It revives that passion that I felt long ago in the NES/SNES/N64/PS1/PS2 era. You know, back when developers made games out of love and passion for them. You somehow think that is all fading with huge AAA developers and publishers taking the "Business" approach as their priority, but as long as there are still small and passionate indie developers, the industry will never lose its soul.

As for the game itself, it is a beautiful thing! A very rich and engaging story that it is given to you in a very oldschool style. No voice acting, just a lot of very interesting lore to be picked up as you explore or speak with NPC's. It feels like the old Zeldas or Okami. The way the whole game works screams the old N64 golden age of open-world fantasy adventures. It is not a difficult game, but it does not hold your hand either. No markers, compass or nothing. You get you clues and hints by listening, reading carefully and learning the map the old fashioned way.

Now, it might be oldschool in how it works, but visually, this game is a modern as it gets. Graphics are gorgeous, characters designs are rich and realistic, with very charismatic "toony" depictions in dialoge boxes. As an artist myself I got to give props to the master mind who drew the "toony" versions of the characters. They look straight out of a classic Disney movie.

What struck me the most is the light/shadow effects. I have honestly not seen a game THIS good looking. It will make you stop what your doing and just hand around the forest or courtyard to admire the beauty around you.

Audio is phenomenal. Appart from the sound effects, it is the music what really holds on to you since the very first moment you start the game. This game needs an OST release ASAP!

Constrols are fine. Take a bit used to and you might get stuck here and there regarding how items and inventory are handled.

As for the gameplay itself, it is a lot of fun. It's mostly exploring, item hunting, stealth and such. Enemy NPC's aren't really that hard though. this is not Metal Gear. You eventually learn that A) They can't run and B) they have masive blindspots. So after a while, it is just an annoyance rathen than a difficulty or a challenge  having to walk around them. On the bright side, there is a point through the game were you can interact them, and they all have pretty funny things to say.

This game also runs amazingly smooth for the most part. It has its hiccups here and there, as well as a bug that defaults to 30FPS everytime you run the game, despite you have 120FPS selected. Checking another FPS setting and back to 120fps fixes it. Other than that, I noticed slight hitches in some areas, which I attribute to the game loading the environment. definitely not game-breaking or distracting. For the most part, I got 120FPS solid at max settings and 1440p (I can only imagine how amazing it would look in 4K), which is more than I can say from many games that are all over the place.

Another complain is that this game is a bit too short. Took me 11 hours with about 80% of everything done (17 total of playing around with graphic settings, test runs, starting all over a couple of times). But then again, this is the kind of game that you don't play once. You go through the learning and getting used to process the first time, and then enjoy it at its fullest the second time.

It's hard to recommend a game since most youngsters might not find it appealing. If you only care about grabbing a gun, going online and cuss at other randoms, this game is not for you. If you are a true gamer at heart an appreciate the industry as art, I have no idea why you haven't gotten this yet.


Oh and... Silas... Damn Silas, I love you <3

43520523.review:
This game was great! I just beat it earlier this morning and I have to say, this game was just what I needed. I loved it! With that said, I don't really write a lot of these reviews and am hardly an interesting writer, but I'm going to try to keep things legible and avoid spoilers.

[u]What I liked[/u]
The visuals and music are perfect for what they need to be. If you grew up reading Brian Jacques' Redwall books, you will feel  pretty at home with the aesthetic that they're trying to achieve here. Regardless of whether or not you are familiar with them, the most basic idea is that you play as a little mouse minstrel escaping from a jail controlled by rats, while also trying to find the whereabouts of your missing wife.
As little Tilo, you face the challenges of being smaller and weaker than most everything in the world and deal with it through cunning and a good deal of stealthing. The world lore is great and you see it reflected very well in the characters you interact with, and all the places you visit feel genuine and put down with a good bit of lore or story relevance. How willing you look into the lore is still up to the player, through clues in books or notes you find, or through the songs you play as a minstrel, which feels much less invasive than other games which rely on random audio logs or unrealistically written journals (like the ones that literally write in a change in the state of mind of someone turning into a zombie).
It should also be noted that a lot of the character interaction in this game is fun and well-written, as the characters you meet go through their own respective arcs, I felt myself growing a genuine attachment to them with a few good laughs and surprises throughout.
This game excels in being a place where you just want to go around; ranging from places like gorgeous forest settings as a backdrop to grand architectural spectacles of ages past, to the dark and ominous ruins of the underground. Everywhere you go has a little bit of grand mystery to it, and accidently wandering into a new place has all the raw feelings of awe and caution to them. The graphics do well in making this happen, with lighting and shadows being a major component, additionally making light a precious resource especially at night time.

[u]What I didn't like[/u]
WIth how much I liked about this game it's only fair I also bring out things that it fell just a little short on. The stealth mechanic sometimes can throw you out of the experience just as much as it does put you in it. There are a lot of moments where you don't feel like you should be seen but end up getting noticed, just as much as there are times where you don't get noticed when you feel like you should be, which I feel is due in part to how stealth itself works in the game. Sound and line of sight are both triggers that fill up a gauge that indicates whether or not a guard has spotted you or not, so the stealth becomes more or less a game of 'how much am I willing to push the limit to get to where I need to go' and less about effectively using cover or a clever use of items. The escape mechanic is also relatively simple in that you just have to 1) lose line of sight of your pursuer and 2) get into a hiding spot, and successfully making it into these hiding spots immediately makes your pursuer lose interest, which at times makes you wonder how that worked or if the guard was just [i]that[/i] dumb or lazy.
Additionally, the 3rd person camera does tend to stick hard onto Tilo and doesn't exactly accomodate chase sequences well in that a lot of times you can run into a wall or dark corner and just immediately be confused, fighting the camera along with your pursuers. While it can be said that because it's a stealth game and your [i]goal[/i] is to avoid getting caught, it won't necessarily be easy, and will likely happen at least a few times in your first phases of the game where you're trying to get your footing.
Games nowadays do rely on a lot collectible and/or fetch quest objectives to kind of extend their game, requiring a lot of back and forth between locations; though while exploring the settings in this game is a wonder, this game is no exception to that trope. It does have the benefit of opening interesting secret passages and shortcuts to people willing to look (some are outright just spelled out for you), yet this only makes this job feel less tedious, but not painless. Ghost of a Tale also has a few quests that can be initiated but not completed until you progress well enough into the story, so just keep that in mind if having hanging quests bothers you as a completionist.
The many fetch quest objectives even conflicts with the awesome character interaction as some conversations do end up with a job for you to do, but it wasn't enough to make me outright hate any of the characters.

[u]Overall[/u]
To conclude, this game was a wonderful and decently paced adventure that I would be willing to come back to. It delivers a fun, fantastical story that I would love to see future installments of, be it books or visual novels, or even future games like this.  It's an awesome work that I feel is a wonderful vision into the creator's imagination that, despite some of its gameplay flaws, I just can't help but want to see more of. And without much more to say without spoiling anything, I'd like to rate this game a solid [u]4/5.[/u]

As a much weaker mouse, you have no chance fight the rat guards, but sneak pass them. Later on you get the chance to disguise yourself as a rat guard, giving you more freedom and let's you concentrate on the many quests.

While the game features a helpful quest journal, it doesn't hold your hand by pointing you to the next location to solve the next sub step of your quests. Attention has to be paid during conversations, but usually the quest log will remind you of the most important facts.

I do recommend this game, but with a few caveats in mind below.

For the most part I enjoyed my time with Ghost of a Tale.  It's an extremely charming game with gorgeous environments some beautiful worldbuilding and an engaging story.  Seriously one of the prettier PC games I've played in 2018 despite being an indie project.  You can tell the dev put a lot of heart into the universe they were crafting and I appreciate the pop-out terms glossary which made it simple to read more on a topic if you care to (I always cared to).  The characters you engage with are fun and well written.  I particularly loved Fatale.  I enjoyed the stealth gameplay and Tilo's movements and actions all felt snappy and natural.  

Despite all these immediate positive comments about this game that spring to mind there are a few negatives that cloud my time with it.  The quests you receive can be a little nebulous, and occasionally the suggestions in the log may not do enough to nudge you in the direction you're looking for.  This seems to be a concious decision and something that most players can work through but it's something to bear in mind.

I do not dig the game's stamina system.  There's no fast travel, and I can deal with this in a game if I can move quickly throughout the game world.  That's not the case here.  By the end of the game you're frequently having to cross multiple zones to do quest turn ins and even with outfits set up for optimized stamina regen (and upgraded stamina training) I still felt like I was frequently having to stop wait for Tilo's stamina bar to regen so I could sprint off again.

What does more grievous harm to the game, I feel, is the final encounter.  At the culmination of a game whose strengths involve music, conversation, subterfuge and thievery is a mission that deals with none of these. Instead, it involves a combat encounter where you are moving slow heavy explosive objects while enemies that are quicker than you chase you down to swat you and detonate them all while you're working on a time limit.  Meanwhile the AI that is ostensibly there to assist you and run interference does anything but that. It is an incredibly frustrating finale which, at this time, has prevented me from seeing the game through to completion and likely is going to result in my resorting to YouTube to see how the story ends as I no longer have the patience to do it again.  It really doesn't help that there is no autosave at the point of no return and the game forces you to run back from the nearest spawn point half a zone away.  

The finale mission is an unfortunate dark spot because of the 14 hours I played of this game I enjoyed 13 of them immensely.

I'm rarely compelled to write a review, but this game is an inspiration. To put it short: 'Ghost of a Tale' is a masterpiece. Go ahead and buy it. Tell your friends to buy it too. More thoughts:

Hideaki Itsuno recently said that the art style of his upcoming game was meant to convey "Quality at a Glance", meaning one screenshot or clip would be enough to convince that the game is a cut above the rest and worth your time and money. That idea, Quality at a Glance, is what came to mind when I saw a screenshot of "Ghost of a Tale" while browsing Steam---from one screenshot I could tell that it was set apart from anything else on the market in terms of presentation. It looks like the kind of game I expected to be playing when I bought a high-end PC, the stuff of dreams. I bought it immediately and was not let down! Having played for a dozen hours or so, here's some highlights:

-Texture detail is insane
-Crazy foliage density (with dynamics!) and, from my experience, zero pop-in on default settings.
-The most effective use of Sub-Surface Scattering in any videogame, ever.
-BEST FUR IN THE BIZ
-Incredible dynamic lighting effects and probably the most impressive day-night cycle in a game to date.
-Animation quality that would make even most AAA studios blush.
-Physics effects are so fluid and consistent that I'm now wondering if they were all animated by hand...

Overall this is one of (if not THE) most beautiful looking games I've ever played and would recommend it on that pillar alone, and on top of that the SSS-tier quality of writing, charming and memorable characters, labyrinthine world design (I hate to make Dark Souls comparisons, but...), and light platforming gameplay with a very satisfying gamefeel puts Ghost of a Tale in GOAT territory. A lot of games these days feel fleeting and consumable, but I will remember 'Ghost of a Tale' forever.

If you showed me a screenshot of this game I would have assumed it was some AAA Sony project or the like, so finding out that it was made in Unity by a very small team (Only one full-time developer, if I'm not mistaken...) was a real shock! It's a real inspiration to me as a dev and proves that indie games don't have to look like a lazy mess of flat polygons: that through enough dedication and skill anything is possible.

Good job Seith, and thank you for all the good times I've had with your game. You are an absolute BEAST of a game dev and I will be sure to follow your work going forward. Cheers!

I am confident that Ghost of a Tale wins "Biggest Surprise of 2018" for me, even though it just hit July.  I'd never even heard of it until I saw it on sale for 20% off, bought it on a whim, and spent the next 22 hours of my life enraptured by the incredible tale of Tilo.

Ghost of a Tale is a casual difficulty stealth game, very forgiving unless you're going for the (frankly crazy) "don't alert any guards ever" achievement.  Fortunately, you can save-scum the hell out of it if you're that kind of person - the game gives you ample opportunities to save, and the load times are lightning fast with an SSD.

The primary draw is the beautiful world-building, supremely written cast of characters, outstanding dialogue and possibly the most lovable protagonist in the history of media - Tilo, the mouse minstrel.  The game should not be dismissed as a children's tale, as you will find yourself going down some dark paths as Tilo unravels the story of the world, and the rodents around him.

There's a rudimentary leveling system in the game where you gain health and stamina as you go, but the real progression comes from the costumes you unlock, which allow you to move more freely in the world, or gets you access to things you couldn't reach before.  It is masterfully done, but I don't want to spoil too much.  On to the something else.

There's a bit of a thing going around in gaming reviews, has been for a few years.  You probably thought you'd be safe from it here.  You probably thought "This is a game about a mouse minstrel.  Surely, nobody is going to make THAT comparison."

But here we are.  Dark Souls.

No, come back!  You aren't going to be dying every five seconds, restarting from bonfires or fighting giant monsters with your lute.  The way the lore is presented in-game is extremely reminiscent of the Souls series - through item descriptions, area design and a lovingly detailed, hand-crafted world that is now a hauntingly beautiful shadow of its former glory.  The game also is full of clever shortcuts between areas that would make Miyazaki proud.  Exploration is encouraged and rewarded.

I ran into a couple of bugs that didn't take much away from the game for me.

-At one point, I reloaded a save to find myself falling to my death, so I had to reload one from 3 minutes earlier.  There are a lot of save points.
-There's a graphical glitch when getting into and out of hiding spots, or when the camera clips into too much terrain, that causes it to spaz out a bit.
-There's a guy you can pay to help you solve puzzles or give you the location of certain items, which he will mark on your map.  In one case, there was no mark where the item was, which forced me to tab out and google it.

Simply an outstanding game, well worth your time and money.

Wow! Where to begin? This is mainly the work of one person? I've seen AAA teams of hundreds produce games that can't hold a candle to this.

First of all the overarching lore, is just fantastic. It's like the Redwall book series brought to life, and I love the way that the game starts in media res, and there's all this background lore so for once you don't feel like the entire game world revolves around you, but that you're just a small piece of what's happening.  And where this story ends it feels like it's a world that still has so many tales to tell. 

Graphically, you can't really fault it, and it feels like it fits the world so perfectly. The main character in particular is well designed and animated, definitely one of the cutest protagonists out there. The world itself is also designed very well, with plenty of little secrets and shortcuts to unlock as you explore. 

The game advertises itself as an action rpg, but it's more like a stealth adventure game, with mild combat in a few places along the way. It fits with being a mouse that you're not this overpowered warrior. There are a few skills you unlock that make it a bit more 'rpg-like', but nothing like a full blown rpg.

The missions are basically your usual series of fetch quests and busywork, but the story behind them is interesting enough, that it never feels like you're grinding to no end.  I also like that the game doesn't always spell out for you exactly what to do at every point. There's a character in game who can help you out for a fee, but it's very much a game you need to spend time exploring for yourself.

The only downside is that you will need to do a fair amount of reading, but that's more or less expected with a fantasy based adventure game.

I was very interested in this game from when I heard about it and this is a rare case where what I wanted was what I got. I really hope that more people play this game and that in turn helps motivate a sequel or two, especially if the same level of attention to details is applied. So yes, if this looks like a game you're interested in, then definitely consider buying it, this has given me more enjoyment than just about all the 'AAA releases' I've played from the last few years.

This game was hands down the best single player experience that I had within at least the last 10 years of gaming.
The characters not only look absolutely fantastic, the story around each one of them is wonderfull, inspiring and you can feel that the person who came up with all this, the whole lore of this fantasy universe, just LOVED what he was doing.

To give it a bit more structure:

Graphics: 
absolutely gorgeous, you see that the dev has a ton of experience in high profile animation movies.

Music: 
lovely, very atmospheric, and just the right ammount. You don't hear music all the time, but they just nailed it with how they did it.

Gameplay:
the overall feeling of control is perfect, the character reacts on spot when you give an imput (I played with controller), great platforming, a nice mix of stealth and non stealth gameplay that, at a certain point in the game, you can change on the spot to your liking in most zones (using a very ingenious and absolutely ADORABLE system), leaving you with three options of gameplay, stealth, a stealth "light" where you can get caught but don't get attacked but get other penalties, or an easy mode where you don' get attacked by a majority of the "enemies" at all, also with a penalty. The stealthmode is a bit basic, its simple line of sight and "making noise", but those mechanics are solid and work very well. The hiding mechanic is not light based but a more classic approach that got used in more classical stealth games, aka, hiding in and under furniture.

Quests:
There is a plethora of quests you can do, that mostly are fetch quests. What sounds boring isn't at all though. Through questing you get access to a lot of fantastic lore and character backgrounds, one of the major things this game has going for it. The second thing is that these quests help you to learn your ways through the world you play in, and omg, what a world that is!

Gameworld:
It's not an open world game from the get go, although you don't have any loading screens between the different zones. To get through the world, you unlock certain doors by following the main quest. The world is full of shortcuts that you open along your way through the story, wich helps a lot, since you will revisite these places again and again on your journey through this game.
This doesn't get monotonous though. The different gamestyle approaches you can chose from to mix things up, the absolutely astonishing world design that is on par with Dark Souls 1, if not even better (yes, I just said that!), the gorgeous graphics and an overall "right" feel throughout the level design doesn't make you get bored but gives you a sense of "beeing at home". The whole worldmap is designed with love for details, nothing feels empty or out of space.

Story:
I mentioned it already, the story is very compelling, almost like a good book that you just can't put aside. You can sense that this whole universe is the baby of someone who put a lot of love into the lore, the small lore within the game and it characters, and the overall lore that you only scratch on through reading item descritions and dialogue. Behind all this lies a huge world with lots of details that leaves you longing for more, it doesn't help that the end of the game is somewhat open, not cliffhanger open, but "I really want to know what will happen to all these interesting characters, that I got so attached to, now" open. (Just in case the Dev reads this: You better start working on a sequel, or start writing some books, because if not, I can't guarantee you that I won't go all "misery" on you when I ever meet you in person!).
Don't want to spoil anything, but there are some really unforseen turns and dramatic revelations happening, that literally had me going "OH MAAAN; YOU DIDN'T!!!!" in front of my monitor, thank god I was playing alone, though the cat look a bit weird at me... not the most proudest of moments in my life.

TL;DR:
This is a gem of a game that everyone with a sense for exploring and good story should play.
It's price is more than justified, the overall quality of the game is great, and the mere fact that this is mostly the work of one person (with a bit help from others: GREAT JOB EVERYONE) is just mindboggling!

It does have it's flaws, yes, there are a cupple of bugs and glitches, I encountered 2 in the 17ish hours it took me to get through the game blind (could have been faster, but I was very torough and didn't want to miss anything), but both could be resolved by a simple reload and yes, you can get a bit lost on your search for items to finish quests, but if you read carefully that shouldn't be a problem, every quest tells you pretty much what to look out for, and in worst case there is an easy to access, in game help for the cost of just a few florins.
The most important thing to keep in mind is save often and on different slots, but thats pretty much RPG standard for the last 30+ years, so that should be no problem.

43040413.review:
Wonderful and beautiful game, even more so for an indie studio. I enjoyed every second of it.

Art assets employed in the making of this game, are just fantastic, especially the area design, excellent lighting, 3D character models and animations, 2D character portraits and visual effects. Story and lore are deeply fleshed out through dialogue and additional footnotes. Interaction with NPCs are a strong highlight due to well-written dialogue which gives the NPCs strong personailities. One sweet detail was how NPC's portrait would change depending on their mood or what they're talking about. 

It's more of an stealth-adventure-RPG rather than action-RPG, considering how there's little actual combat invovled and your only offense is throwing certain consumables against foes. Furthermore, unlike monstrous opponents, humanoid opponents can only be knocked out. I would have preferred if the option to fight was available, considering all the weapons littered around the place, missed opportunity really (maybe in the next part where Tilo has to fend for himself?)

There are some bugs, but nothing near game breaking. Some examples include getting hit by a guard's halberd while he's in the Idle state, sometimes being unable to interact until I reloaded, containers highlighted even when empty.

Some flaws are the lack of voice acting and some backtracking. Perhaps its left up to the player to imagine the voices, but I feel that the player and NPCs capable of combat should be given a basic voiceset catering for attack, hurt and death/knockout states. Although one can unlock shortcuts and safe routes, backtracking can get a bit tedious, but once I got familiarised with the layout travelling became much easier.

In summary, I would describe as a solid adventure RPG where you play as a Bard/Rogue multi-class character, who mainly relies on pacfist, trickery and stealth solutions to solve quests. Hopefully the story of Tilo gets continued!

42307281.review:
While the description of this game being an RPG isn't wrong, be warned it's not an RPG in the same sense that Final Fantasy is with stat screens and combat and level ups and the typical RPG tropes. This is actually a Role-Playing Game, where you are meant to imagine yourself in the hood (not necessarily shoes) of the character Tilo. The game outside the roleplaying begins as primarily a stealth game then shifts to more of an adventure as you become a master sneak. Combat is definitely not a focus for this game (there's really only one 'fight' in the game and it's less of a fight and more of a frantic puzzle). Don't expect Metal Gear Solid stealth complexity either. The stealth is fairly simple to understand and master and there's a way to avoid the need to be stealthy entirely after a certain point. The world is highly immersive and you are expected to pay close attention to the lore and details that almost every character speaks about if you want to play the game well. 

That being said, the game is incredible. As far as immersive roleplaying in a fantasy world, only enormous AAA games like Skyrim and The Wticher have done what this game has done on a much smaller scale made by a much smaller team with a much smaller budget. The game really makes you want to be able to explore the world they've built beyond the scope of the game and luckily they've set up the ending to have some decent potential for a sequel while also keeping it largely conclusive so you're not left with a sheer cliffhanger that basically says "See you next time!" Yes, there is a bit of an 'up in the air' ending, but if you pay attention to the lore, that's actually a pretty fitting ending too. 

Theres only a few problems in this game. The first is that sometimes you have to look for the smallest item that could be absolutely anywhere in the play area. There are tools in-game for finding items more easily whether that's a map with an icon on it or clues that characters mention, but even with those sometimes it's a pain to find the item. Eventually you can get the ability to 'see' interactible items but only after getting a few of these hard to find items in the first place. This can be very frustrating if you are new to the style of game this is. If you've played point and click adventures you can know that everything hinges on one small item that you may not spot even on repeated journeys through the area. This is not a game breaker though as if you need it, a quick google search will likely find you your solution. The second problem is that since the game was made by a small team, there are some seams in the environment here and there that betray the immersiveness of the game. The team appears to still be actively fixing these, so, if you find one, be sure to take a screenshot and share it on their forums so it can be fixed.

The draw of this game is the story and world building. There are many memorable characters, plenty of twists in the story, and gorgeous art direction. The controls feel good, and the animation is fluid, which is great, because the majority of this game is running around.

That is the most unfortunate part of this game. The gameplay is mostly running around looking for stuff. Progression is mainly looking for keys to unlock doors/chests, and performing fetch quests while dodging guards and various hungry creatures. The level design is unfortunately very confusing to navigate, and the maps you get sadly don't help as much as you'd hope. You may not mind running round aimlessly though, as the world is pretty stunning at times.

I really must stress that I enjoyed the story so much that I was willing to not only finish the main story, but complete the vast majority of the side quests along the way. The characters are just that likable and the writing is genuinely solid. The pieces of the plot fall together at the end of the story in a very satisfying way, and when the end credits rolled, I was ready for a sequel.

All in all, this is a basic game with really good writing, and you should go in knowing that the story and the environments are the draw and not necessarily the gameplay itself. Also, be prepared to read, and don't skip anything.

TL/DR:  A must-purchase if you enjoy adventure games involving these sorts of fantasy settings and creatures. The narrative and characters are wonderfully realized. The stealth mechanic makes an interesting immersive experience, but leans on the side of very forgiving for those who have an aversion to that sort of tension. If there is an area that could use some improvement; I would suggest perhaps a better visual indicator for finding items nearby that can be picked up/interacted with.
.
I have heard the game compared to Redwall in themes due to the mouse-and-rat centered narrative. However, I found after an hour or two of playing that the narrative is on a more complex and nuanced level. This is not a game where species are portrayed in a carte-blanche "All mice are good" vs. "All rats are evil" sort of fashion.
.
Dialogue is interesting and well-written to each character, and supplemented by clickable Terry Pratchett-esque footnotes to help fill in details. Although nothing is overtly graphic or explicit with intent to shock -- topics discussed can range from mature, heart-wrenching, and even playfully ribald at times.
.
If you enjoyed Redwall, the Rats of NIMH, or other such timeless tales of timorous types of cunning creatures, please do yourself a favor and pick this one up.

This game is adorable and I really had a lot of fun exploring its world. 

I think that, first and foremost, this game is a story driven exploration above anything else. Its secondary genre would make it a stealth game. It does that first part increidbly well, and the artistic direction of the game and level design is super interesting. It sort of falls short on the stealth mechanics, but I'll get to that in a second.

From what I understand, this entire game was made by one guy. It's usually pretty impressive when its done by people like Toby Fox, Austin Jorgenson, or Eric Barone, the people who designed all their respective 2D Pixel Art games (Undertale, Lisa, Stardew Valley). BUT WOW. THIS GAME?! The amount of time I imagine it would have taken to design such a vibrant, high rendered 3D environment and the models and animations for all the unique critters, just WOW. 

So with that in mind, any faults this game has really pale in comparison to the amount of effort that went into this game and for it to not turn into a complete disaster. My only critisms are small ones usually, and the biggest critism is that the Stealth portions of the game are kind of boring/easily manipulated. You can pretty much just dash past guards and jump in a barrel. It kind of breaks up the flow of exploring environments though. For example, probably the most tedious example was for an optional quest where you have to gather mushrooms from the forest but there's a guard patrolling the path. You're already spending a lot of time searching carefully from these mushrooms just to have your search disrupted because you have to run and hide. But, again, it wasn't enough to ruin the game for me. 

I imagine that if the creator had a full team of developers behind him, he could create a mindblowing 20 hour AA adventure game focused primarily on exploration and its characters. The stealth doesn't need to go away, it just needs to be redesigned and utilized appropriately (sections of the game that don't require you to throughly search them).  I REALLY hope he follows through with another game with a team of people to help his vision, because there's so much potential here.

41597824.review:
As a header, or perhaps a TL;DR, this is a finely written game with some very interesting mechanics and really is worth playing if you have patience, especially for anyone who enjoys story-based games, some degree of stealth gameplay and puzzle solving, but it's not without some gameplay flaws and hitches.

Right, now for the real meat of the review.

Ghost of a Tale is a well presented, very interesting in its world building, undeniably pretty game. As a whole we should cover some details on both the positive and negative scale, because it'd be easy to say one crucial thing and ruin the review despite how true it is, so please read on after this; Ghost of a Tale's stealth system isn't very good.

If I haven't scared you off or offended you (in which case, I'm sorry), but it is very barebones. It functions alright, literally a line-of-sight detection effect mixed with motion and proximity. However, a core mechanic of having items of clothing offer bonuses means that it doesn't take long for you to find things that allow you to almost entirely circumnavigate the sneaking aspect, albeit if you actually do a solid job at exploring and finding said items. Even if you are spotted, the AI isn't especially bright, and very easy to escape from.

I should also provide another criticism here that I did encounter some glitches, such as falling through the floor a couple of times, including a repeatable one involving an elevator late game, as well as a (thankfully) single crash to desktop.

RIGHT, enough with the negatives. Yes, the gameplay mechanics are lacking....beyond that though? I could sing this games praises for hours and still think up other things to compliment.

So, for context; You're a mouse in a world where all manner of smaller creatures have civilisations, legends, heroes, lore and just a little magic in the mix. You're imprisoned and seperated from your wife in a fort run by rats, who compared to you are towering thugs, more than twice your height who you have no realistic hope of fighting. However, you soon find some folk who're willing to talk to you and you begin getting involved in all manner of goings-on around the fort in the hopes of finding your wife.

You're a mistrel/bard, a musician and traveler (your wife a dancer to add to the show), and a core part of the games is both a repetoire of songs you can sing/play, while learning more as the game goes on, often the game making you pick appropriate songs for a given moment based on the folks you talk with. As you'd imagine you don't/can't fight, but with wits, sneaking, guile, the occasional thrown bottle at a rat guards cranium and some puzzle solving, you engage in a number of tasks for the various figures around the fort who aren't out for your blood. The world isn't huge, literally a fort and the grounds around and below it, and I was glad to see a great deal of interconnectivity with it.

The graphics are very solid, atmospheric and fitting. There's some good details, which really does show off what the Unity engine is capable of. Lush foliage, pretty well detailed character models, gorgeous god-rays and the like. It's marred by some odd seams in the textures and ground rubble here and there, but it's easy to ignore unless you're especially critical. The lighting's pretty solid too, as there are times and places where you really do need to use the light sources provided.
What I adored the most visually is the art for the characters when talking. Very well drawn and coloured, hugely expressive and very fitting.

The sound's good. I found it very quiet to begin with for some reason, but tweaking the volume mixing fixed that. The game has no dialogue, which goes the same for the 'singing'. However, each song has a tune that you can fit the lyrics into. Otherwise it's fairly minimalist, good environmental effects and the like.

The story seems simple to begin with, but rest assured, it was one of the things that really stood out as things went on. There's a fairly limited cast of characters, what with it being based in a fort, but every one of them is very unique and has a lot of hidden bits of dialogue based on certain outfits as well as other lines in terms of the story. You'll frequently find yellow tinted text in conversations that you're given a prompt to look deeper into which yields very interesting morsels of lore and history in what's a very surprisingly fleshed out world. I really do hope a sequel is on the table, because there's so much more of this game that makes it seem special.

With a bit more refinement in the gameplay and a little more polish in the seams and textures, if another game is made by this group, I will buy it in a heartbeat.

A third person adventure game where you play a mouse minstrel named Tilo in a Redwall inspired fantasy world. Tilo's escaped his cell with the help of a mysterious stranger and sets out to find his missing wife, Merra. Gameplay mostly consists of fairly forgiving stealth, exploration, fetch quests and a few basic puzzles. That may sound dull but fortunately the world is stunningly beautiful, with a ton of lore to be discovered and a host of interesting characters to interact with. The gameplay, while simple, is servicable and when paired with the narrative and was more then enough to keep me interested for the 10-12 hours it took me to complete my first playthough (I didn't do all the quests or find all costumes).

Unfortunatly, along with the lack of depth in the game's mechanics, there are also a fair few bugs. Most are superfical, objects not placed properly, bad animation transitions, etc. However I did experience a crash to desktop and a bug that droped my framerate to 1 FPS when interacting with some objects in the Catacombs. For anyone experiencing that issue, pausing the game will restore the framerate. It's annoying but not a dealbreaker.

In spite of its flaws, I'd still wholeheartedly recommend Ghost of a Tale. Definitely pick this one up. Especially if you're a Redwall fan.
