41276633.review:
If you were going to buy this game just because it has good art direction, you won’t be disappointed. Dwindling Heights is a beautiful environment to explore from the lush foliage of The Northern Slopes, to the murky depths of The Catacombs. The game also features painted portraits by Jerome Jacinto who did art for Tooth and Tail & Armello. These portraits make dialogue more expressive, and characters more memorable.

If you were looking for an elaborate stealth/action game however, this is not it. The guards are easy to outrun, easy to outsmart, and easy to over power (given they are not wearing a full set of armor.) The real challenge is not alerting them in the first place! They get alerted when they hear or see you too much. Avoiding them takes patience, memorizing their patrols, and a little cheese (no pun intended.) If the developer were to make a sequel, this is the area that needs the most improvement.

Although I was let down by the stealth, the game compensates by including a variety of interesting, plot-related challenges. I had to solve a cryptic puzzle to open a secret door, research a book about ports so I could send prisoners to a safe location, climb to seemingly inaccessible places to find pieces of a costume, etc. 

The second biggest issue are the bugs. I had to reload a save because I didn’t die when I fell down a bottomless pit. My cursor broke every time I changed the resolution. These bugs made me paranoid I might lose a bunch of progress, so I followed the game’s advice and kept multiple saves just in case. Thankfully I never ran into a game breaking bug.

Despite these issues, I really enjoyed myself. I look forward to returning to this world, and seeing what Periclave has in store!

I purchased this thing on a whim because, well, it looked interesting and I recall seeing something about it a year or so ago. Not truly expecting much, I sat down Saturday morning, loaded it up, and I'm fairly certain I did not set it down until Sunday night dictated I rest for work.

The Pros:

The story is compelling and weaves you through what is, admittedly, not a very large map. However, following the branching narratives and story arcs, you quickly forget that you're looping through the same places and it becomes a wonderful environment that suits the story well. It's not too large and far from too small.

The game itself does teach you the basics, but really there's a lot to discover. I won't say there's 0 handholding, but really it felt like the old games I grew up on where you learn how to do the basics and then dive right in. Dynamic movement, refinement of controls, and proficiency are entirely up to the player. I will say that halfway through day 1 when I swapped to the controller, I was grateful I did. The controller scheme suits the game's playstyle significantly better than keyboard and mouse, and I'm certain there's a lot of exploration and indeed sneaking about that was easier with the incrimental input available on the control's joypad that is not shared by WASD/Mouse.

The art style is breathtaking. I spent more than one instance standing from a parapet or windowsill enjoying the vista and the sounds. Turning the music off at night just brought the ambience of the environment to the forefront, and I would highly recommend playing both with the music (for the intended cinematic feel the music brings) and without to just really savor the environment and sound. Bonus if you have a nice headset with surround or any other directional sound feedback device.

In the end, I spent 11hrs and missed a full completion by 1 quest (2 of Faustus' mushrooms proved difficult to find). I've never felt compelled to do that on a first playthrough, but this one was an exception and rightfully so. Completing side-missions was not a difficult task, and I found them to be enjoyable and really add depth to the narrative that was playing out.

The Cons
...and I use that word lightly and perhaps incorrectly. There's a few small issues that I noticed throughout the gameplay, but they were far from game-breaking.

1) At one point, wearing armor upgraded only once, I swapped to the thief's outfit for some narrative dialogue and then swapped back. The armor bugged and I was able to run/sprint/hide at normal unhindered speed. This effect vanished when I died and reloaded from a quicksave point.

2) There was a gap in the floor texture in the tomb beneath the magpie after opening the doors to the ledge in the tapestry room.

3) The rope that hoists you up from the lower to the upper level in the caverns by the shore had a gap between it ant the knot holding it to the bucket. As the bucket rose, the gap slowly vanished. Lowering it opened up.

4) When you surrender the pirate hat after collecting the set, the statistics drop from 7/7 Costumes Completed to 6/7 Costumes Completed. 

5) From time to time during Quest Dialogue or when viewing books, the video would freeze. I could still press controls/input and hear the menus opening, closing, and so forth, but the video would just halt. I would have to close and restart. This would happen infrequently, perhaps four times on my total playthrough, on a 4k monitor with max settings, powered by a 1080GTX, windowed mode, Windows 10, both with mouse/keyboard and controller.


And...really that was all I saw on the first playthrough. #2 will probably be far more thorough and my Designer's eye will start to be the lens I look through.


Bravo Zulu, SeithGC. This one's an instant favorite.

Highly recommended. This is the sort of game that you leave feeling empty because you can no longer play it for the first time. The environment is beautiful, and the story is rich and intriguing, with character one easily falls in love with. The side quests are also plentiful, and tie into the main story in a way that lets you ignore them if you wish, but also follow them without having to divert too much attention from the main game.
A personal win for me, though it might not tickle your fancy, is the lack of handholding. Items and clothing can be found relatively easily through context clues or the blacksmith, but there are less obvious tasks given to you, that will require you to remember a lot of hints given in dialogue, and these hints are not written down anywhere (as of version 6.51), so it's hugely helpful to keep a notebook at hand at all times. I was also pleasantly surprised at how many instances where you could find answers to a question by looking around or analyzing the context.

On the negative side, the game can run a bit poorly on occasion, especially in the forest areas (the far tower specifically), and in areas with a lot of torches. The lack of handholding can be seen as a problem for many, though, as I said, I personally enjoy it. The forest areas also suffer from a lack of save points, as there are very few hiding spots, or characters to talk to. The catacombs and other areas with open fire also reduces the frame rate massively.

For a price tag of 25 dollars, this seems to be a good investment for many hours of entertainment. A very typical fantasy RPG, but a very good one.

Finished in ~20 hours total. Well worth the $25! I'd definitely back a sequel.

Things I liked:

- It's very pretty to look at!
- The level interconnectivity and the feel that everything is truly part of one big world is near Dark Souls-level good. There are tons of shortcuts that you open up as the game progresses (provided you pay attention), which really impacts the back-and-forth gameplay.

- The game does not hold your hand. There's no mini-map, no quest objectives, no golden shimmer around objects with which you can interact. It's a bit of a throwback, and I found that refreshing.
- There's just enough lore that you get a real sense of the world in which you're playing without having to read seven hundred books as you play through the game.

Things I didn't like so much:

- Yes, there's a lot of back-and-forth fetch quests. I didn't really mind that, although there were a few times where it proved pretty tedious, especially since I encountered a bug that wouldn't allow me to pass through an opened door in the harbor, meaning I had to go the long way every time. Just beat this game for the first time, as somebody who went into it knowing so little about it to the point I had forgotten I had it on my wishlist (or when I had even added it), I was very very very pleasantly surprised with what I got. It's by no means perfect, but I'd say it's my favorite game I've played so far this year.

NEGATIVES:
- Enemy AI is pretty stupid. They can easily detect you yet if you turn a corner, it's like you're invisible to them.
- At points it feels as though a cutscene or some sort of cinematic should play, but instead you just get a textbox explaining what you would be seeing. Understandable though, considering the game was developed by about 3 people (not including the music and 2D art).
- I had less than 10 crashes during my entire playthrough, typically when I was trying to save. Luckily I was saving often, so it wasn't too bad for me. Be warned though, save at any chance you get.
- Maps can be a bit confusing at times, as can quest objectives.
- The later segments of the game don't seem like they got as much attention as the first 1/3 or so.
- Some sidequests, and even main quests, can feel a bit tedious, but not grating enough to where I wanted to stop.
- Just the ocassional small bug, but I never had any that were game-breaking.

POSITIVES:
- Absolutely stunning in terms of design, lighting, atmosphere, overall graphics, as well as in sound design. The world truly feels lived in, and you genuinely feel like a tiny mouse in a rat's world (like, everything is clearly designed for someone twice your size).
- Memorable characters, and charming dialogue.
- A wonderful world filled with lore to learn about. If you're a fan of Morrowind, the game has a system during dialogue where you can open entries and read about what the characters are discussing. Does wonders for immersion and world building.
- While the enemies can be pretty stupid, stealth still feels excellent and works as intended.
- Attention to detail is astonishing.
- Loads of sidequests to complete, and plenty of replay value.
- Music is delightful and generally very fitting.

I recommend this game if you're looking to get lost in the world of a fun, replayable stealth game with RPG elements and a great story. Think "Secret of Nimh" with a bit of Thief or Metal Gear. Despite it's flaws, the game was delightful the whole way through. I hope to replay it again soon and probably annoy my friends into playing it.

A nice Action/Adventure game with RPG elements, [i]Ghost of a Tale[/i] follows the adventures of the minstrel mouse Tilo in search of his missing wife Merra. The gameplay revolves around basic stealth and disguise mechanics with very little combat (you’re a mouse, what did you expect?), thus aiming for players in search for a story-driven game rather than player looking for the next killer stealth game. Play-time can be expected to last roughly between 10 and 20 hours depending on the degree of completion.

The game progresses through dialogue and item collection while navigating the maze that is Dwindling Heights and evading the rats guarding the place. Most of the puzzles will not prove difficult to solve and even if for some reason you can’t figure out one or you can’t find an item, a [i]deus ex-machina[/i] NPC can offer hints in most cases.

As many people pointed out, the game is imperfect. Though as of now most of the game breaking bugs have been squashed, the game still needs some polish in order to correct graphical anomalies like holes in the terrain, floating rocks, and the last cutscene which I couldn’t watch properly because the camera was stuck underwater the whole time. But, honestly, you just have to take one look at Tilo and all of the problems this game has will vanish from your sight.

All in all, this game offers a refreshing light-hearted experience and a welcomed respite from all that is wrong in the world. 10/10 would like a sequel.

What a mixed bag this game is. 

On the positive side, the world itself is breathtaking, and surprisingly interconnected. I expected a more linear style of progression, where you move past Zones and NPCs once you've gotten what you need from them, but throughout the entire game you're constantly cycling back to places you've been and people you've talked to. You end up finding all these secrety hidey-holes and passageways that connect all the far-reaching areas of the map in cool, quirky ways. I can't tell you the number of times I've absentmindedly been running through a tunnel and come to the end like, "Oh THIS is where I am!". Perfect example of a smal world done right. 

Equally, the writing is divine. I was coming off a pretty big Skyrim kick when I started Ghost of a Tale so I thought I was going to be BLAZING through any books/texts I came accross in the grand Bethesda tradition, but nope. Concise, quaint, readable paragraphs make you WANT to read them. You can get the sparknotes lore from this game so easily, and if you want more, you have your clickable yellow text conversation option that's not really necessary, but still fun. I think it's the mark of any good RPG to make you care about the world beyond completing the game/collecting everything/getting the achievements/etc etc. 

I'm going to spare any comments on the art, bc I think what needs to be said has been said. It's beautiful, end of story. You feel like you're in a Brian Jacques novel, traveling through a post-apocalyptic Redwall abbey. It's a stunning world. It's got a very Guild Wars 2-esque light and shine about it. 

The costume system is fun and great, although I would've wished to see them all have equal purprose. You definitely spent more time in certain clothes than others. 

To the negatives, there's a lot of logistics I wish had been tweaked. I wish opening the menu paused the game (like most games). Sometimes there are little UI snaffus that end up needing a re-load. I glitched into the basket up to Silas's watchtower and lost a TON of progress. Sometimes the sound effects would glitch out, but the music would stay, and I'd need to hop in a barrel and pop out of the game for a second.

On a larger scale, the quest structure is a little off. You're never given any indication which quest you should be pursing, only that you have main quests, and side quests. Turns out, you can inadvertantly lock yourself out of a lot of sidequest content by completing too many main quests! 

Also, there is no reason on God's green, 2018 earth why any game should have a checkpoint-based save system. Yes, the hiding to save fits with the aesthetic, and no, it's not the most frustrating thing in the world. But it's an unnecessary inconvenience at best. It doesn't add anything to the game overall! (EDIT - Someone has clarified down below that it accommodates consoles + a small dev team which is an excellent point. Consider the aforementioned a light critique at best, and a moot point at worst. Certainly shouldn't stop you from getting the game.)

The last big negative I'd drop is this, it's short for the price. If you're gaming on a budget, you should not buy Ghost of a Tale. I know it's beautiful, and I don't want to devalue the work of the devs, especially since I know nothing about development! But if you have to put yourself in that truly terrible mindset of "I Only Want A Game With A Lot Of Playtime, Because I Can't Always Be Buying Games", then you are going to be sorely dissappointed by how fast this all goes by. If you're on a budget, and you're okay with a less-occuppied experience, then honey, buy this thing. 

[spoiler] The ending sets it up for something big. I want a sequel. I want sequels. But I'm worried with how long it took for the funding for this game to come together that that may not be a reality. Fingers crossed though, god knows they'd get money from me.[/spoiler]

41028293.review:
[h1] Spoiler free review, with a short and longer version: [/h1]

[b]TLDR version[/b]

Buy this game if:

+ you don't want stealth to be a key component of your gameplay
+ you like lore elements heavily based on long-winded text 
+ you love that a slow and repetitive backtracking will be the 90% of your gameplay
+ you want to play as a cute minstrel mouse

Don't buy this game if:

- you were looking for a stealth game, as [b]THIS ISN'T A STEALTH GAME[/b]
- you wanted a "fast" paced game, [b]NOT BASED ON EXCESSIVE SLUGGHISH BACKTRACKING[/b]
- you like logical gameplay consistency while playing a game

Time required to finish the game: 12 hours /  7-9 hours  when community guides will come up
Time required to complete it at 100%: 18-20 hours

[b]Verdict: 4/10[/b] 
Horrible,clumsy and unfinished game, full of weird inconsistencies, boring and repetitive quests extremely based on item fetching, item hoarding paired with an excessive backtracking and - more importantly - plagued by the "forced" slow mobility, which i will explain in the more detailed review down below.

[b]Detailed version[/b]

Don't be deceived by those fancy screenshots posted on the store page; this game looks extremely nice on the store letting you believe that the whole game is based upon stealthing through the way, giving you these kind of feelings and impressions:

http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=1340883359

But be also aware that the game itself isn't completely patched (yet) and needs a significant fine tuning and many fixes, as shown here:

http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=1340883055

Let's see why i gave this game such a negative rating:

[b]1- The excessive backtracking[/b]

There are good kind of backtracking in games such as: Hollow Knight, Hyper Light Drifter and Owlboy (all already reviewed in the previous months/years by me) and...there's this one. 
This game is made by 90% of backtracking on foot while looking for hidden items and clues, sometimes too well hidden and never marked on the map, unless after a good coin spending at the local shop, which won't grant you the whole visibility of all these items you were looking for. 
Most of the time you will have to go to point A to point Z, and after speaking to the guy at point Z you will be required to go back again to that same point A to fetch something else like a good doggy would do. Over. And. Over. Again.
On the top of that... [u]the main character isn't able to cover great distances because of a really dumb mechanic, which will be shown down below.[/u]

[b]2- The wretched, stupid idea of combining the health-stamina bar into a single one[/b]

Your health bar and your stamina bar are the same thing and they share their grim fate, meaning that if you get hit by an enemy, you'll loose health and stamina at the same time and by loosing health you'll be prevented to run away, allowing your enemies to kill you with ease and reducing your stamina even more while chasing you down.
This is quite infuriating, both for stealth and not stealth sequences.
Someone could rightfully say: but this is a stealth game, just sneak past them LUL!!!
[b]The harsh reality[/b]: you don't have tools to get past guards, you don't have neither supernatural powers to dispatch them nor that tools that allow you to move way faster or in a sneakier way, so the "sneaking" is extremely hard or undoable.
Note that i'm not saying that this game needed to be a mouse version of Dishonored. Far from that.
The exploring part is even worse: you'll be breathless after running for few meters and it'll take a lot to recover the stamina to keep running in order to be able to explore and backtrack, while trying to not to get bored to death, [u]while trying to find that darn precious item you're required to bring in[/u] in order to progress with the story.

[b]3- The inconsistency of skills, items and stealth mechanics[/b]

[u]Skills[/u]: they're not skills. At all. They're just boring and predictable passive abilities such as a faster stamina recovery and reduced damage when falling from the higher grounds. These skills...don't serve any purpose. Having them or not don't make your gameplay more fun or variable, like it happens in the Styx's series or in Dishonored, it's just a gimmick to fill your free text space in your inventory.

[u]Clothes and costumes[/u]: those stats granted by most costumes are mostly worthless, as those bonuses that they provide aren't worthy at all and are hardly appliable. The brighest example: the fire resistance. Unless you're planning to swim into a oil lantern 24/7, this stat bonus is blatantly useless. The only good thing that comes from costumes are the visual effect of them and the fact that wearing those costumes can trigger optional dialogues and side quests, which sadly you might be induced to do.

[u]Broken stealth mechanics:[/u]: The game DIES right after leaving the prison cells that you see in the steam store page. If this game was based upon proper stealthing into closed areas, the game could have been great.
[u]What you get instead[/u] are guards that get more suspicious when you use the stealthy footsteps and not when running, brutal and abupt framedrops while talking to NPCs or while pickpocketing them or even during quicksaves. You often will have to explore while stealthing, making the whole thing insanely boring and stressful, especially if you're going for the "undetected" achievement as you'll be always without stamina or with low HP, preventing you to run away from your enemies or enviromental perils.

[b]TO SUM UP:  Why giving this game a 4/10? [/b]

1- The game is clearly unfinished, as there are blank spots all over the menù  and in the story itself. There are even body item slots -showed in your inventory menu - that are never used in the whole game (which i've completed at 100%); 

2- the backtracking is insanely clunky, badly optimized and boring, as many events take place during some precise parts of the day/night which you will have to wait patiently (unless you find a bed to skip the waiting) while wandering around while searching for that cursed item you desperately need to complete a main quest

3- the stealth is nonexistent and illogical

4- the skill/item system is shallow: items that are used only once most of the time, foods that were supposed to be used to prepare potions (according to their ingame lore) which eventually never came up with this functionality at launch

5- The story was actually nice (and the secondary characters too!!) but it gets explained way too abruptly in the end. Animations or even short cinematics are totally absent, forcing the game to explain everything through text only, which leads me to think that they've ran short of time and money during the development

6- Enemy variety is nonexistent, except for 3 nice NPCs

41021865.review:
What Ghost of a Tale is, is hard to pin down. It has RPG, adventure and platforming in equal doses, but it's not really committed to any of those styles. It's a mixup of Dark Souls style of level design, Hitman styled costume stealth paired with traditional stealth mechanics and roleplaying elements that give you levels ups after certain experience thresholds have been reached. It's a weird experience,  certainly like nothing I have played before. So, what Ghost of a Tale really is, is deeply flawed but still competent game, and if you can stomach the many faults it has you might find an experience that stays with you.

Ghost of a Tale begins at a keep of Dwindling Heights, giving you only a brief backstory to go on with before it pushes you out of your cell door. The whole game happens in this prison and it's surrounding areas, and even though it might sound like a small premise, the map is large enough to give you room to explore. This is also the area where the game shines brightest. It has amazing map desing, combined with graphics that make you wonder how only a team of few developers managed to pull it off. The map loops to itself in surprising ways and gives you shortcuts that cut down backtracking. I have played only a small amount of Dark Souls but I can confidently say that people who love it will find joy in mapping and exploring Dwindling Heights. 

The artwork and graphics further sell the impression that this is indeed a story book from olden days brought back to life and now drawn to your computer screen. Character models and their animations are absolutely fantastic. They are full of detail and you can see the hours and love put in to them. Music doesn't fall far behind with few good tunes that don't take away from the experience by being just awesome music, but play in the background and enhance the experience. By visual standards, this game is a master piece.

Which brings me to the unfortunate section of "bad" in my review. The game is buggy as hell. Keep in mind that I don't really mind about bugs. Sometimes I even find them hilarious, and I do understand that no software on earth, no matter how much testing it gets, can be perfect. Heck, this game was made mostly by three guys, and if I understood correctly, most of the work was done by only one of them. But there still is a line, and this game goes way past it. The bugs range from graphical bugs like textures disappearing so you can see through the map to bugs like the one I encountered when I bought food from NPC, and because the NPC didn't have that item in her inventory,the game spawned them in and left big yellow text as a memento of that moment to my screen. Permanently. Until I restarted. Sometimes your character gets stuck to certain objects and geometry, sometimes if you go through a door enemies in the previous room disappear completely and spawn back in when you go back, and sometimes controller won't work as it should (like the one time when the triggers didn't register any inputs until I restarted the game). And this is only a brief recounting of all the ones I encountered. The final part of the game suffers most from these since it includes stuff that the game certainly isn't good at, and tops it off with combination of previous bugs and AI that isn't all that bright. During the ending sequence I was watching the "cutscene" under water, because the camera bugged out. Way to leave the last impression. These are indeed nothing game breaking, but still stuff that gets you drawn out of the experience. Hopefully, these will be fixed over time since these are bugs that CAN be fixed with patches.

Also the game mechanics can be a bit tedious. I loved running, sneaking and jumping around, the character feels great to control and even though sneaking gets kind of forgotten after a certain point of the game, (because you get costumes that fool the guards, more stamina so you get away easier and you learn to trick the AI) at the start of the game these segments can be really tense. Game could do with more depth to these mechanics but since these are not the focus of the game I don't mind that too much. At the end I had lots and lots of food stored in my inventory, and the only deaths I countered were at the beginning when I was still learning the ropes, a few stupid mistakes in a rare instakill platforming segments and the finale, which is it's own can of worms. There's also a LOT of backtracking, so in the end your going to know this keep like your own pockets. I did enjoy this, but I can see why you can start hating it, escpecially the game doesn't give you specific locations on where to go, and you can search an area for a good 30 minutes before you find the specific spot.

The game took about 10 hours to complete, and I did do most of the side content. I loved that there was no objective arrows to guide you, so everything you did you had to do yourself. Or buy information from a certain blacksmith who can mark locations to your map. Not too helpful, since the game doesn't always change to correct map when you go to different area. He can also give hints about puzzles, but only if you have money to pay for it. I found this a great way to implement help function in the game, these hints are never free so at least you have to give something in return for those tips, other than your pride.

So, in conclusion? I loved this game. It has it faults, yes, but the lore is so fascinating, and we don't see this type of fable stories too often in gaming. The game's Early Access roots shine through in wrong ways but for every bug there is a wonderful story/character beat. It's also absolutely stunning to look at. This game is definately NOT for everyone, but if you can look past it's flaws you can find something truly beautiful. I certainly did.

Ghost of a Tale is an adventure/stealth game in a world ruled by rats. However, you do not play a rat, but rather a minstrel named Tilo who has been imprisioned for sedition because his wife refused to dance for the Baron. When you awaken in your cell, you discovere under some stale bread, a key and a note from a benefactor somewhere in the keep who needs you assistance. In avoiding detection you find your benefactor, and from here you embark on your journey though Dwindling Heights (Formerly known as Duinlane Heights) in a quest to find your beloved Merra. 

Now, before you jump into this wonderfully rendered game, you will need to read some of the ingame books in order to understand the circumstances of the characters in the game. You need to READ AND COMPREHEND. If you don't, you won't understand what others are wanting from you. Some outfits also have social modifiers to them, wich you can learn about by reading the entries on them, the most obvious is that dressed in the armor, you appear like a scrawny rat, as as such, can move about in the game, unchallenged. 

While the game has been finaly released in March of 2018, it is still a little buggy. Sometimes you are unable so get out of hiding places, other times you are unable to pick up certain items, and if you find yourself in too tight of a spot, the camera will glitch out. Most of these glitches are easily remedied with a restart, or simply moving Tilo to another place.

Another thing to know is that there is no real combat in this game. Sure, you can indirectly kill spides, or knock out a rat or two, but if you think you're going in with a sword, you got another thing comming. It's a stealth game, and apparently, in this game, mice aren't exactly know for their courage.

My first complete play-thru after release took about 16 hours to complete. This is because early reliance of the full suit of armor (needed to disguise yourself as a really small rat), is heavy, and requires modifications to allow you to move quickly. This can be done by focusing on the quests assigned to you from the Commander. Also, finding keys is important too, as most of the shortcuts in the game are locked or not too terribly obvious. You don't need to do all the quests in the game to finish it, but doing quests will give you benefits, such as special pieces of clothing, or as I previously mentioned, modifications to the armor.

There is also leveling in this game, but this is mostly tied to your health. The higher your levels, the more health you have, thus are a little more durable in case you fing yourself discovered by a very unfriendly rat that would like to pound you flat.

And lastly, while this is a complete game, it seems like this game is the start of a larger saga, as at the end, Tilo sails away to find his wife who is supposedly on the Isle of Periclave. I look forward to it's sequal.

40951949.review:
Ghost of a Tale is a beautiful experience bogged down by a lot of tedium that ruins the experience.

You play as Tilo, a mouse that's jailed in a castle who finds a key under a loaf of bread allowing him to escape his cell. Now you must find out who rescued you and why, and more importantly, find out what happened to your wife Merra and your son Bryn. Along the way you meet a variety of characters and are given a lot of backstory of the world Tilo lives in.

Let me start by saying that the art in this game is absolutely beautiful, the character models and animations are gorgeous and the world matches perfectly. The visual fidelity is AAA. The sound matches pretty well and the soundtrack is lovely. The handdrawn art for the dialog for all of the characters is just as beautiful and lively. I loved just looking at this game.

However, the gameplay itself is not on par with the other elements. The game is primary a stealth title, there's almost no action, but the problem is that the stealth isn't that good. Sneaking around is easy, but Tilo is very slow and sneaking makes him even slower. It tests your patience a lot. The worst part is that sneaking around doesn't really benefit you in most situations, guards are slow and you can easily get to areas they can't access due to their larger size or inability to climb. Sneaking around is effectively pointless and doing it isn't rewarding.

The game is very "aimless," in that you're left to your own devices to figure things out. It's kinda nice, because it has this open feel but sometimes you'll get majorly stuck trying to figure out just where the hell to go or what to do. The quest log helps, but sometimes it's incredibly vague ie, "Go here to meet X" but where exactly in the area you have to go isn't clear. And a lot of the areas are large and winding. Being that Tilo runs out of stamina incredibly quick and takes forever to regain it, you'll be jogging back and forth around these areas more than you'll like. Keys are also insanely annoying, some keys are given to you via quests, some are just found on walls, some are stolen from guards and some doors can be circumvented by clever jumping or alternate paths. This gets you wondering what you should do when you find a locked door, should you look for a key? Find a way around? Or just wait to get further into the story to be given a key? While this sounds like it gives the player options, finding the right option can lead to a lot of time wasted just trying to get by a gate or door.

The gameplay isn't varied enough, all quests boil down to typical fetch quests. "Go here and get X, Y and Z," "Find X amount of Y item." Blah blah blah. One quest has you finding 30~ mushrooms, it's excessive. Bringing these items back will usually net you some information, another fetch quest, or a key. It's a really repetitive cycle and mostly feels like padding the game out.

Some areas of the game are incredibly under utilized, especially the Northern Cliffs and Shore areas, they're quite large but almost no quests take place in them and there's nothing to do other than run through them. It feels like they ran out of time implementing them properly.

This complaint is minor, and won't bother most people, but there's a little too much lore in the game for me. The game fleshes itself out very well in it's texts and it makes the world feel properly alive. However, when you spend most of your time reading and clicking through text over and over it breaks up the pacing of the game and brings it to a halt. This is also compounded by the fact that the game has a lot of names, locations and even it's own made up phrases that are presented in yellow text and clicking will bring up another dialog box with a paragraph of backstory on that single word. It's great, if that's your thing, but it became overwhelming for me trying to piece everything together.

Lastly, the game is too long. Around the 7 hour mark I felt like the game should have finished already as it showed everything it had to offer in regards to gameplay without changing anything up at all. But it didn't for another 5 hours. By the end I was wondering if I should just give up and uninstall as I was having little fun getting to the end. I soldiered on to find myself tasked with the most miserable "final showdown" I've had to endure in a game and an ending that didn't resolve a major question I wanted answered (presumably to make a sequel). I was disappointed.

For an indie game this is an ambitious work of art and should be praised for that alone, but sadly there's a LOT of fat that needs to be trimmed to refine the experience into something that doesn't end up feeling like a chore.

40939872.review:
If I'd been asked to consider or describe a game as "Soulsborne sans combat" a week or two ago, I would have simply been befuddled. Combat is a pretty integral part of that third-person romp through atmospheric lands. Now, however, that sticks in my mind as an accurate, boiled-down description of the gameplay in Ghost of a Tale.

I adore this game.

I've seen some reviews that focus on the stealth aspect, which is not entirely invalid, but that matters less after the first third (or so) of the game, when a disguise allows free movement through previously-guarded areas. There are some puzzles here and there, as well as things to find. That leaves the main thread of gameplay being the heavy emphasis on exploration of areas that interlock and curve back on themselves in ways that are fun to uncover.

The atmosphere is definitely there, it not as bleak and lonely as a Souls game. A nice feature lets you get a pop-up with further details on lore terms as they come up in conversation (rather than needing to dig through menus) and there is a weight of that history hovering over the present, both in setting and characters. I found the handful of major NPCs all game across as very genuine. The player gets insights into the protagonist's history as collectibles are found, but he starts to see some of that through new eyes as well. As Tilo is a mouse minstrel, we also get his book of songs - one that is revised and added to over the course of the story and makes a very nice touch.

Early on, I felt the distinct lack of voice and immediately thought, "Man, this could have been that much better." Looking back after completing the game, however, I'm less sure. That might have been a design/budget decision, but for as much as I wanted voice to start with, I wasn't bothered by the absence by the end. Some of those lines would have been difficult to deliver with the proper emotion and I find myself wondering if filling in the gaps mentally (as one must with a book compared to a movie) might have actually added to the experience.

Technically, I had a few problems along the way. Three or four times, I got Tilo and the camera stuck in a spot for several seconds. There were some occasions of being able to see sky instead of terrain until I moved close enough. I also hit a progress-blocking bug with a quest - thanks to a note on Steam, I was able to email my save file and get a fixed version back in within an hour (on a Sunday). There have been update patches coming out frequently these first few days after release fixing most of the major issues. Given the game was largely developed by one person, I credit the response time more than I blame for the bugs in the first place.

I don't consider it a spoiler (though some might) to say the ending does not wrap everything up. To me, it felt satisfying in the way that a short first novel of a series might. There are revelations and developments. There's a climax. The main threads of the story, however, are still there and the door is wide open for continuation.

And I find myself sincerely hoping it comes.

Whether you are a fan of the classic animal adventure stories like Redwall, Wind in the Willows, and Disney's Robin Hood, want to spend some time exploring a beautiful seaside fortress, or just want to dress a mouse in adorable little costumes, this game is more than worth it.

[h1]Regarding bugs[/h1]

Please don't be scared off by the possibility of glitches or bugs. Yes, at the moment, it is a little bit buggy, but they are generally very minor things and the vast majority have easy workarounds. In the few instances of players running into more serious issues, you can send your save file to the devs and they will personally fix your individual save file and send it back to you. Where else can you find that kind of customer care and service?

If you need any further convincing, look at the rate of patches. This game has been out for 7 days, and there have been 9 patches. [i]Nine.[/i] That is more than one [i]every day.[/i] By the time I'm done writing this sentence there'll probably be another one. Nowhere can you find a more devoted and hardworking developer.

===================

To end with, I'd like to list a few of my favorite aspects and little details that speak to the incredibly high quality of this product:

[list]
[*]The environment is just unbelievably detailed and un-video-game-like. You know how in even the biggest budget games, in so many cases you will run into blurry textures and flat meshes? There might be incredibly nice-looking foliage, but you can see the ground is a plain flat mesh with a basic texture underneath.

I haven't found a single spot like that in this game. This is possibly the single best usage of tessellation ever: every single pebble sticks out of the ground. Every single brick and rock stick out of the walls with real depth. There are no flat, fake looking or blurry surfaces anywhere in this game. It's an almost surreal experience when you are so used to what a video game "looks like," to suddenly be wandering through something that feels like it is built out of actual real-life objects instead of meshes and textures.

[*]On top of that, the collision and player control are fantastic. Despite the ridiculous three-dimensionality of the world, movement is supremely smooth. I am constantly surprised when, expecting to get stuck bumping into a rock protruding from the ground, Tilo instead scampers right over it. You know, exactly like any game character should, but never does. Other devs, please take note.

[*]Classic platforming is certainly not a major part of the game, but perhaps it should have been, because jumping and climbing is just as smooth and enjoyable as walking and running. I would kill to get a better look at how this works under the hood along with the meshes and colliders on the rocks, because my gosh the way I was able to clamber my way up from the bottom of the utterly natural looking rocky hills in the shore area to the top blew my mind.

[*]Last but not least, foliage. It would be one thing if it was [i]only[/i] some of the most lush and beautiful foliage ever rendered to a screen in real time, which it certainly is. But the interaction just knocks it out of the park. I swear, if all you could do in this game is run through ferns and watch them brush out of the way and then cheerily bounce and snap back into place, it would be worth it.
[/list]

This is what I'm talking about. This obsessive attention to the smallest detail and the dumbfounding sense of presence and place and believability it results in. This world feels real, and I don't want to leave it.

Anyone who knows me would tell you that this game is basically made for me... and not *just* because of the amazingly cute protagonist (though honestly that would have been enough to get me to buy it in and of itself). When I get to play as an amazingly well animated character like that, my enjoyment of a game immediately goes up considerably... yet even with that taken into consideration, I can't recommend this game.

I'm sure this review will get buried beneath the slew of positive reviews with <5 hours of playtime, but for the few folks who actually see this, I hope I can shed some light on the things they aren't telling you.

The art direction in this game? Inspired. It's clear that a huge amount of effort went into creating well-crafted, well-animated art assets and the love that the modelers and artists had for this product shows. It's by far the best thing about the game. The first half or so of the game's world is incredibly well done - detailed, stylized, believable... I was feeling quite fully immersed in this world and its characters and the story. So what changed?

If I had to guess, I'd say the developers got about half way through making this thing and got bored, or ran out of time, or ran out of money, or something, and just scraped the second half together. There are bugs - holy shit are there bugs - and some of them systematically dismantle the experience from its core.

Anyone who only played the first 3-5 hours of the game probably never encountered any of this, and will read this and think I'm crazy for not recommending this game, and if I'd only played 3-5 hours, I'd be right there with them, but once you get to the middle / end of the game, the lack of polish becomes readilly apparent. Holes in the world geometry abound. Leaving the pathways and going to explore the outdoor areas of the game - particularly the 'Shore' area - is just asking to fall through the world. It's clear to me that basically no testing was done in this regard, because you don't even have to try to do it. Luckily, when you fall through the world, the game puts you back on the surface - or, it tries to. All three times this happened to me, the game put me back under the world and created a loop of falling - respawning - falling that forced me to alt+F4 the game and restart it again to continue.

A lot of sounds are just flat out missing. Music exists in some areas and not others, and when you transition between them the music track starts playing in the middle and is quite jarring. There are events that should have sounds associated with them (ringing bells, for instance, or combat happening mere feet from your character) which make no sounds at all. Coincidentally these sounds are primarily missing from the second half of the game - see a theme developing here? No dialog is voiced, and some of it really could have used it. In fact, there's no cutscenes of any kind except the ending which only qualifies by the barest definition of a cutscene, and while the sounds that *do* exist are very well done and really add considerably to the experience, the ones that are missing will pull you out of the game and destroy your immersion.

Speaking of dialog, dialog loops and sequence breaks frequently create nonsensical situations. I'm going to try to be spoiler-free here in case, after reading this, you still want to play this, but there's an encounter near the end of the game wherein a rather monumental event takes place, and a number of guards in the prison the game takes place in watch it happen (or... should, in theory? They were standing literally 10 feet from it...). They then proceed to not react to it in the slightest. This may not sound terribly egregious, and without major story spoilers I can't really illustrate why it is, but trust me when I say that it's completely immersion destroying.

Hopefully you don't just click through the dialog and skip that monumentous story event, but if you do, it's okay - after the event takes place, you can go and talk to an unconcious character and the game will *play the entire event again as if it never happened*, with unconcious characters talking to you, conversation repeating, and those characters getting knocked unconcious again. This is clearly not intended.

The final encounter in the game is the most uninspired, infuriating thing I've experienced in recent memory. Imagine that you're playing Mario, and you're comfortable with the mechanics of Mario and how the game operates, and then in the last level, the game switches to the N64 Superman game. This is the closest approximation of this shit-show that I can make without completely spoiling the story, but but let me assure you that it is utterly ridiculous how contrived it feels. Not only that, but you're required to utilize some objects to complete the encounter. There's about... 8 of them, if I had to estimate, and when you use one, they're consumed. You need to use 3 of them successfully to proceed (why is it always three in these situations? It's like the magic number of gaming bosses.) Here's the rub - if you fail the encounter, and use the 'Load Last Save' prompt that you're given when you do, any of those objects that you used previously *are still gone*. On my third attempt at this steaming pile of an encounter (which I should add is basically a die roll as to whether you can successfully do it, due to a restrictive timer mechanism and utterly unpredictably laughable AI), there were only two of these objects left, and I had to close the game entirely and re-load it to try again.

The ending... well, let it suffice to say that there is no conclusion to the story. It's basically a 'To be continued...', but there's not enough content there for it to conceivably have been a cash grab to promote a sequel... it honestly feels like they got to the end of the game and decided to just not include any real conclusion. In fact, at the end of the game, things are *more nebulous than when it started*, which is kind of a feat in and of itself.

They had a few golden opportunities for branching storylines and a satisfying ending here. There were three scenarios I was speculating would be the end as I was playing, and I was excited to see if my speculation was correct - I would have been better off just not playing the last 20 minutes of the game and writing my own ending, instead. This lack of story wrap-up combined with utterly ridiculous immersion destroying game system choices (dialog is all handled via the game's equivalent of popup boxes, which pause everything else while they're taking place, and the game decides to, while you're being chased by multiple NPCs who're actively trying to kill you, suddenly pull you into a 5-6 line dialog between three characters... on MULTIPLE occasions... in the span of 2-3 minutes, during this ending...) completely ruined the amazing experience that the first 5ish hours of this game brings.

If you feel you must play this game, I wholeheartedly recommend that you stop when you reach the Shore area for the first time. Maybe even the Slopes, because that's where the problems really start becoming apparent. Just stop there, write your own ending in your head, and suffice to say that no matter how ridiculous your version of events is, it will be better than what the team behind this thing actually decided to include.

TL;DR: Bugs. Sequence breaks. Frustrating design choices. Ruined immersion. First 3-5 hours are amazing, one of the best gaming experiences I've had in the past few years. The second half of the game is a smoldering dumpster fire with little hope for redemption. You've been warned.

Absolute labor of love.

Ghost of a Tale is a wonderfully crafted adventure platforming game which focusses solely on narative, world building and lore.

Graphics are top notch, but it's not the technical aspect in which this games excels but in the design.
It's like you're wandering through the set of a Jim Henson Redwall movie (I seriously wish that were a thing though.)
The level design and interconnectedness  of all areas without any loading screens are a massive bonus, as it adds so much to the believability of this little world. That feeling of traversing an area, looking up or down, recognising an area you have been playing around in for hours and going "ooh, this area is overhere?" is one of the things that drew me to games like Dark Souls and Gothic/Risen.

Game play is, as far as these kind of games go, wonderfully executed, even though all missions can be downplayed as 'fetch' quests, it's the narrative and lore you get as a reward that make it all worth it.
The game can easily be ran through alerting all guards (which has little consequence besides achievements), or played Thief style, sneaking around, swapping costumes and distracting guards by throwing around stick and bottles.
Also, having absolutely zero combat, is a nice change for once.

The music is wonderful, yet doesn't always work in the areas it play.
[strike]As for sound (and music), it seems that either it is still very buggy, or there simply was no time spend implementing most sounds, as vast amounts of actions (cutscenes, elevators, hatches, etc) simply lack any sound.[/strike] This seems to be fixed in the last patches (6.5 and up)
The sounds that are there do their job well enough (not much sound design you can do when it comes to opening steel caged doors or throwing items.)

The pacing might be slow for some people though, especially for those that have little patience and can't be bothered to collect the costumes that make traversal less obnoxious (in the sense of getting detected or stamina regeneration.)

All in all, having played the beta multiple times and finally finishing the final game, I'm left with wanting more as the world is so lovingly crafted and I want to learn more about it and Tilo's role in it.

Despite being a 'fetch' quest adventure game, a big thumbs up, loved every minute of it.

Now this is what a great indie game is! It has amazing visuals, good animations and is very well optimized despite using Unity (which is known for poor perfomance in 3D games).

To me Ghost of a Tale is like Arkham Asylum meets Dark Souls meets Hitman with cute antropomorphic mice and somewhat less cute antropomorphic rats for enemies.

As in Arkham Asylum, you go around a keep on an island and carry out a variety of tasks. As in Dark Souls, you find new equipment sets and open passageways connecting locations you already visited and creating shortcuts: level design in Ghost of a Tale is truly amazing. Finally, as in Hitman you avoid being seen or put on a disguise to move freely among your enemies.

Alas, you can see Ghost of a Tale could use a bigger budget: the game lacks voice overs, has poor sound design (some sounds are too loud, too quiet or missing at all). I believe the authors planned to have songs and voice-overs (because why would you make the hero a minstrel otherwise?), but there're no resources to implement.

But worst of all, the game has quite a few bugs. Some of those are minor (like rats sometimes not going back to sleep when you wake them), some are more severe (like quests not progressing). On top of that the camera can be quirky and default controls are somewhat unusual (thankfully, you can remap even gamepad bindings).

Anyway, even despite its flaws the game is great and is definitely a nice choice whether you look for a game to play with your family or a game you could play solo and go for hardcore achievements such as never to be detected by an enemy.

This game is labelled as an action RPG, but as is mentioned in detail, the focus is on immersion and exploration to the point that I'd call this an exploratory scavenger hunt. For the most part, it does do a good job at that while telling a solid story.

The gameplay itself revolves around finding items to advance - I'd argue that even the included stealth elements and limited combat just serve as obstacles to get to new locations to search for the items needed to progress the story. It isn't easy either, as item highlighting ranges from limited to none, and the environments have a lot of detail and care put into them that make it easy to miss what needs to be picked up.

The game demands a good bit of attention paid to it while exploring, and that works just fine, as the atmosphere and presentation of the story throughout is top notch. I can certainly say I wouldn't have enjoyed the game if it was just a raw video game collectathon. As it is, I'm giving it a thumbs up.

With that said, there are some issues that made it a weak thumbs up.

Much of the game made me feel like it wasn't quite ready to get out of early access. I didn't run into anything game breaking, but there were plenty of small janky issues between camera jittering in small nooks, regular animation hiccups, etc. Some design elements also seem questionable or underdeveloped, such as losing the ability to revisit NPC dialogue topics. Good information and hints are lost if you forget or didn't write it down yourself, save for reloading a save to before when that dialogue was chosen. Even so, these are relatively minor grievances, and the developer appears to be working on various bug fixes that will hopefully continue until there's a fine polish.

The bigger issue, and the reason why my thumbs up is weak and hesitant, was the feeling of disappointment I got from the story. Big plotpoints did not resolved satisfactorily, or even at all - in fact, it felt outright incomplete, as though there's a missing final act.

Even with its flaws, if you like atmosphere and story while exploring a game's every nook and cranny, I'd recommend giving this one a shot.

40861215.review:
Hidden gem of the year. There's an exciting trend happening in PC gaming right now where we see Indie purity of expression meeting Triple A production values. This game epitomizes that. 

Right off the bat, you can tell this is made by an ex-Dreamworks veteran. The animation and art design feel like a Pixar movie and Redwall book had an adorable baby. The graphics are spectacular (can't believe this is made in the Unity engine). The controls are fluid (played using gamepad) and intuitive, so much so, the controller often fades from thought, leaving an immersive link between yourself and the character. 

Gameplay is a relaxing, yet engaging mix of stealth (Splinter Cell as a mouse anyone?) with some thoughtful puzzles and immersive world exploration. There are no MINIMAPS and NO OBJECTIVE MARKERS, and the game is better for it. Instead of mindlessly clomping towards an objective marker, you learn to navigate and explore a beautiful world, drinking in the detail. The immersion is heightened as a result. That said, once collected, there are maps you can quickly pull up without going to a separate menu. This is the perfect combination between keeping the focus on the environment, but also giving you some handy orienteering tools.

The writing is tight, punchy, and entertaining. There is no spoken dialogue or lip syncing and I absolutely prefer it that way. When someone talks, you enter a conversation window where the words appear over time (typewriter style) mimicking the natural delivery of speech. It's surprisingly effective and combined with the colorful and concise writing (no monotonous monologues), I wouldn't opt for high quality voice overs and lip syncing even if it were an option. This is a great example of turning a constraint into a boon.

The best part of the writing is the footnote system. Rather than relegate important information to a clunky codex buried in another menu, the game makes use of footnotes. During conversation, when a word or piece of lore comes up, you can toggle a footnote to read more about it. This makes the lore come alive in an efficient and engaging way without feeling like a chore. It sure is nice for the information you're curious about to be readily available at the same time, on the same screen as the conversation it's relevant to. It seems like a simple thing, but I can't think of a single game that uses the footnote system. Groundbreaking.

Lastly, this game oozes with character. With so many run of the mill clones out there, this game is refreshingly unique and original. This game is easily worth the price of admission for its uniqueness alone. Ontop of that, I haven't experienced any bugs (playing the full release), the game performs incredibly well, and the level of polish exceeds that of many AAA games (Final Fantasy 15 to name a contemporary). It's so good, I almost feel bad only paying 25 bucks for this gem. These are the kinds of developers that deserve our support.

An absolutely fantastic game, even more so considering the size of the team working on it. There's lots of things about it I'd like to critique, like how the stealth falls through pretty much entirely as soon as you get a disguise, how easy it is to escape enemies when spotted. It shows that the lead dev started game development only five years ago.

Nonetheless, all these flaws are minor when you actually play. The visuals, the designs, the story, the characters, the world, it's all so well done, so finely crafted, dripping with charm. This game is a labour of love, and you can tell.

The level design is especially notable. It's reminiscent of the original dark souls (take a shot), as you find new places, and find new shortcuts throughout. It can get labyrinthine at times, but you will often enough acquire maps that help you navigate.

Next up I'd like to commend the writing of the game, and the music that accompanies it. Throughout the game you meet a great many colourful characters, and interacting with them is a joy. Throughout conversations, they will mention lore-related topics, and you can get a quick lore snippet explaining what's being said. Read all of them. The lore draws you in, and has humor sprinkled throughout in all the right places. The pacing of the story is spot-on (I never felt like the ending just snuck up on me.)

As you play a minstrel, you will occasionally be asked by characters to play songs. If you read the songbook in your inventory, you might pick up on the fact that you'll occasionally have to play a song appropriate to the situation. Despite there being no voice acting in the game at all, the melody holds up by itself and as the lyrics accompany the song, you can just hear it play in your head. Again the writing is to be commended, as the songs range from heroic tales to shantys to satire to mockery to rude songs. Every one is a delight.

On the whole I'd say that there are some decisions in terms of gameplay I disagree with, but I will still strongly recommend it.

40814611.review:
There are major spoilers for the main plot of the story ahead. Please read at your own discretion.

--

This game was like love at first sight for me. When I first played the Early Access back in the summer of 2017, I was instantly encapsulated by the wondrous scenery and breathtaking attention to detail. Every character felt distinct, with their own cute quirks and amusing dialogue, but not without some sense of dramatic gravitas every once in a while. The missions, both the main story missions and side missions, were fun to play through, and the story developed in such a gripping and natural manner that I could not help but keep playing to see what would happen next. And all of this is still true for the game.
For the first 6 hours.
Once you clear the catacombs, it becomes painfully obvious the rest of the game was rushed in order to make a viable release. The game starts to become more focused, more narrow, which is odd considering how open-feeling the first half of the game was. Certain quests that were immediately accessible in the Early Access version are now delayed later on into the story in order to give the player 'something' to do as a distraction. This is because, if the player buckles down and focuses on completing the side missions as soon as they get them, they will find that the story can be played through fairly quickly. Granted, I have already played through the first half of this game in Early Access, but because of how much has changed for the release version, I would argue my completion time of only 10 hours (not counting the six I played in Early Access) is probably going to be the average, give or take depending on how much they take their time or rush through. Note, that I did not complete all the side objectives, and there are certain challenge runs (don't eat anything, don't get caught, etc.) that will certainly lengthen the playtime of potential fanatics to possibly 20+ hours.
But the reason I can't recommend this, is because of two reasons.
1. The game is quite buggy for a "final" release, and is frankly inexcuseable at this point.
2. The game is outright not finished.
The first part is easy to explain, right? There are many issues with platforming, sound, and even dialogue in some cases, as well as the occasional save issue. At one point there was one particularly nasty sequence break I ACCIDENTALLY preformed, in which I skipped the Catacombs segment ENTIRELY. However, because of how linear the game's progression is, I still had to go back and complete the section in order to advance the main story.
The second part, on the other hand, is far more personal, and just outright insulting. As I mentioned earlier, it becomes clear in the second part of the game that much of the content feels rushed in order to reach the release date, however it gets even WORSE in the third part, near the end. Sections at this point lose any sense of polish, and start to feel like something you should see in an Early Access title, not a fully fledged release. There are no sounds for monsters, no new music, no new side missions, you are railroaded to completing the main story at this point, and while the story is still certainly gripping, I cannot imagine it holding the attention of the average gamer long enough for them to finish the game.
[SPOILERS]
But the worst part is the ending itself. After finally figuring out where Merra, the protaganists' wife and MacGuffin, is, you unearth a pirate treasure on the shore which is revealed to house a crystal of the Green Flame, an apocalyptic force which arguably set in motion the events for both the lore and plot of the game. After defeating the crystal (with the help of your friends), you learn that the crystal is only a representation of the Green Flame's power, and the Green Flame itself is still housed at Periclave, the same island where Merra is supposedly trapped. It all lines up perfectly, and after tying up all the loose ends, you sail away in the rowboat to Periclave, and....
The credits roll.
That's it. You wanted closure? Too bad, have a credits screen.
This game is just objectively not finished. There is NO reason for Periclave to not be the final section of this game. Like, imagine if a movie ended this way. People would be PISSED, and rightfully so. This type of cliffhanger ending is just not condusive to good storytelling, because it is in no way satisfying or even worthy of being called a "final" ending for the game.
I love this game, I really do, and I imagine I will certainly come back to it after a few weeks to go over the game and get 100 percent, complete all the achievements and challenge runs, and maybe even speedrun it. But, for the average consumer, I cannot recommend this. In the future, if Periclave is added and the final parts of the game polished up, then I will certainly recommend this.
But, seeing as this is a "full" release, I doubt that will happen anytime soon.

Well, a game I bought with low expectations to be honest, however, it blew my mind during the first hour of gameplay. If you don't want to read any more and want a tl;dr:, well, if you enjoy old school exploration, adventure games just go ahead and buy it. Now for the wall of text.

Before reading the review, let me tell you that I have learned this game will be released in two weeks so I decided not to play any more until it is released. So I have only 1.6 hours spent on the game as I am writing this review.

First of all, setting and gameworld is really cute and stylistic. The feeling of being immersed in a fantasy world is there. The way the environment and characters are created is just a mixture of realism and fantasy. Actually, when I first started I thought it was going to take place in dungeons, but nope, it actually has a big enough world to explore. That surprised me a lot. I don't even know if there are other places as well.

Now, most games have collectibles just to keep players in the game with no real value, like trinkets and stuff which add nothing to the game once found. However, this game does an amazing job with collectibles. Everything you collect actually serves something or adds to the depth of the game. Books add to the lore, costumes add to the character stats, foods and items can be used for various purposes and even mini-quests (not side-quests mind you) are fun to do and serve a purpose to further establish the lore. I actually solely explored the area during the two hours I played because I was so immersed in the game world that I totally forgot about the mission. Another great job there.

Another positive part of the game is that writing is good as well. Some jokes really made me giggle and characters are properly-built. No character so far made me think "hmmm why the heck should I care about this character?". They feel like a natural part of the game world. Collectibles that add to the lore are well written as well, there are just so much detail that if you like reading, you will have a fun time in this game.

One more thing I enjoyed is how well the game world is built. So many hidden areas, passages, things to discover etc. makes it actually fun to traverse the map. It is not dull by any means. Actually, it is so cleverly built that even backtracking isn't an issue for me and believe me, I don't like backtracking at all. 

The only thing I don't like is that performance is a bit wonky. I honestly would not expect such a game to have performance issues. Ambient Occlusion completely obliterates performance for me and with it closed, I can play with around 45-60 fps, however, at some areas or while looking at certain objects, fps dips down to 20-30 so it is not really a stable experience. Anyway, it doesn't really hurt as it is not a competitive multiplayer game or anything, you can simply ignore.

Long story short, a brilliant game in a time where not many well made games exist. I will wait until the full release before playing any further. Well done to the developers, I genuinely enjoyed this brilliant game.

As of now the game isn't finished and hasn't realeased. so keep that in mind when reading this.


     First off the positives. This game is suprisingly pretty. I wasn't really expecting the visual effects, etc... that were delivered, especially in a title that isn't yet finished. Theres a nice bit of "cute" humor like you would expect ou, well frankly, any games with animal protaganists. It may not be unique but damnit I enjoy that crap. The controls seem relatively decent, with the exception of if your being chased by a guard in which case they can, for some reason, get sluggish. Its not enough to pose a problem though. It was a nice touch that you had to collect outfits to "fool" specific npcs and not just for the one typical "pose as a guard" kind of quest. Also, I was pleasantly suprised that the outfits actually ended up having stat bonus' attributed to them.

The only complaint I really have at the moment is that the stealth aspect is a little too... easy... You can casually walk behind guards and as long as you stop a little every so often theyll never have any clue. Oh, he just rounded a corner, Fuck it, lets sprint towards that direction and as long as we don't round the corner he's clueless. I will admit I may be being picky here because the protaganist is a mouse and, as such, the term "quiet as a mouse" would be relevant.

It really is a shame that I was unable to play this game, because from what I can see by the trailer and screenshots alone, Ghost of a Tale is truly gorgeous and unique in its own right.

I am in love with the concept of the game as well as with the nicely rendered medieval setting that you play in. The hiding mechanic for avoiding enemies is also a great touch to the game and contributes to its dangerous, ominous atmosphere. 

To my disdain, my old laptop was ultimately unable to run this game properly. The menu lagged, and I struggled to configure the settings, but more often than not, this ended in my screen freezing for a long time. When the game itself finally loaded, the application terminated due to incompatibility issues. Of course, this is not a problem with the game; it is a problem with my computer. Overall, I am highly disappointed that I was unable to play. I requested a refund to make up for this inconvenience.

So like I said, even though I did not have the luxury of experiencing the gameplay firsthand, I am intrigued by the concept and how imaginative the whole thing is.

9/10 is my rating for this game. If your operating system can handle this game, unlike my dinosaur of a laptop, I definitely recommend picking up this gem while it is still in Early Access!

So far, this game has everything I like about a game. It doesn't punish you, stunning graphics, tons of areas to explore and lots of things in the game world to find. Somewhat linear, but has bit of a sandbox feel to it. You can choose to follow the path, or go left, right, or even back to explore areas you couldn't previously unlock if you want to, but all paths do require doubling back to the path. Not a lot of 'combat' in this game. You can hit enemies with bottles to knock them out and that's about it from what I've seen so far--but then, I really like to explore every nook and cranny of an exploration game, so I may just not have progressed far enough yet.

The biggest con is that the game does have weird bugs when adjusting graphic size, and sometimes when it launches or you tab out of it, it'll launch only the window, but not the contents and make it kind of a pain to exit out without navigating with your keyboard. But it's still in development, so I'm sure it'll only keep getting better.

The gameplay is fun as a stealth game, it accomplishes the stealth well with several tools/places to hide which can give you the flexibility to play how you want. The quests amount to collectathons, this is fine as you can accomplish these as you move along the main story. This segways into the next point, the story, it's good and is relatively intriguing and makes you concerned for Tilo and his family. My only gripe with the game is probably the lack of voice acting, this is probably an intentional design choice and either way I am fine with or without it as it does not detract from the story or gameplay. Overall, I am satisfied with this early access purchase and look forward to what the full release may bring.
